Sometime around 2350, Kiz was severely damaged in an earthquake and subsequently covered with red enamel tiles in the reconstruction, thus leading to the School's now-famous moniker.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Scarlet Spires'</ref>
The symbol of the Scarlet Spires is a three-headed serpent.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Three-Headed Serpent'</ref>
==Participation in the Holy War==
In 4100, the then-Grandmaster of the Scarlet Spires, [[Sasheoka]], was assassinated by the [[Cishaurim]], who believed the Scarlet Spires responsible for [[skin-spies]] discovered in [[Shimeh]]. Sasheoka's successor as Grandmaster, [[Hanamanu Eleäzaras]], sought vengeance, and waged a secret war against the Cishaurim for ten years. When a [[Holy War]] was announced against the [[Fanim]] by [[Maithanet]], Shriah of the [[Thousand Temples]], in 4110, the Scarlet Spires agreed to offer their support.
The Scarlet Spires wished to minimize their involvement in the conflict, as they were few in number and significant losses could reduce the standing of the School. As such, they took to the field only when Cishaurim were present among the enemy forces.
==Known Members== * [[Amrezzer]] (Grandmaster) * [[Calasthenes]] * [[Ekompiras]] * [[Girûmmû Tansiri]] * [[Hanamanu Eleäzaras]] (Grandmaster) * [[Hem-Arkidu]] * [[Heramari Iyokus]] (Grandmaster) * [[Inrûmmi]] * [[Khui Shinurta]] (Grandmaster) * [[Madarezer Ukrummu]] * [[Myrathimi]] * [[Naïn]] * [[Narstheba]] * [[Nem-Panipal]] * [[Ptarramas]] * [[Rimon]] * [[Sampileth]] (founder) * [[Sarosthenes]] * [[Sasheoka]] (Grandmaster) * [[Saurnemmi]] * [[Thirûmmû Sek]] * [[Ti]] * [[Tsotekara]] (Grandmaster) * [[Yutirames]]
==References== <references/> [[Category:Schools]]

'''Shir''' is an ancient city-state on the [[River Maurat]] that served as the original capital of the [[Shiradi Empire]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Shir'</ref>
Shir was razed to the ground by [[Xiuhianni]] invaders from [[Jekhia|Jekk]] in the fifteenth century, and the capital of the Shiradi Empire was subsequently moved to [[Aöknyssus]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Shiradi Empire'</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Cities]]

[[File:Istyuli_Plains.png|thumb|400px|The Istyuli Plains in 4109.]]The '''Istyuli Plains''' are a vast and largely semi-arid tableland running from the [[Yimaleti Mountains]] in the north to the [[Hethanta Mountains]] in the south, and from the [[River Aumris]] in the west to the [[Cerish|Sea of Cerish]] in the east. They utterly dominate central-northern [[Eärwa]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 455, 'Istyuli Plains'</ref>.
The Istyuli Plains were once the breadbasket of Eärwa, teeming with villages, towns and farmsteads feeding the great nations of [[Kûniüri]], [[Sheneor]], [[Akksersia]] and [[Aörsi]]. Millennia before that they formed part of the [[Reach]] or dominion of the [[Nonman]] [[Mansions]] of [[Nihrimsul]] and [[Siöl]].
During the [[First Apocalypse]], those nations were laid low by the teeming masses of [[Sranc]] unleashed by the [[No-God]]. Since the end of that conflict the Sranc have remained in firm control of the plains. The [[Great Ordeal]] of [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]] marched onto the Istyuli Plains in 4132, planning to breach the armies of Sranc to reach and destroy fell [[Golgotterath]].<ref>''[[The White-Luck Warrior]]''</ref>
==Cities== * [[Sakarpus]]
==Natural Features== * [[River Aumris]]
==References== <references/> [[Category:Plains]]

'''Sakarpus''' is a city of the [[Ancient North]] located in the heart of the [[Istyuli Plains]], and, aside from [[Atrithau]], the only city to survive the [[Apocalypse|Old Wars]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Sakarpus’</ref><ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Apocalypse’</ref>
Last part of ''[[The Sagas]]'' is “The Annal Sakarpa,” or “The Refugee’s Song” as it is sometimes called, the strange account of the city of Sakarpus during the Apocalypse.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ''‘Sagas, The’''</ref>
Sakarpus had been beseiged five times since the time of the [[No-God]],<ref>''The White-Luck Warrior,'' Chapter 4</ref> but never succumbed, not until the Men of the [[Great Ordeal]], under [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]]’s command, conquered the city in 4132.<ref>''The Judging Eye,'' Chapter 1</ref>
==Kings== * [[Hûruth V]] * [[Varalt Harweel II]] * [[Varalt Sorweel]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

'''Dagliash''' is the ancient [[Aörsi]]c fortress overlooking the [[River Sursa]] and the Plains of [[Agongorea]]. It changed hands several times in the wars preceding the [[Apocalypse]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Dagliash’</ref>
At one point during the war, [[Seswatha]] was crucified on the walls of Dagliash by [[Mekeritrig]] and tortured with the [[Agonies|Cants of Agony]]<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 2</ref>. However, he survived and eventually escaped.
Dagliash was built atop the ruins of [[Viri]], one of the Nine High Nonmen Mansions of Eärwa.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

The '''Kyranae Plains''' are a fertile region drained by the [[River Phayus]] and extending from the southern [[Hethanta Mountains]] to the [[Meneanor|Meneanor Sea]]. Its peoples have given birth to three great empires: ancient [[Kyraneas]], the [[Ceneian Empire]], and most recently the [[Nansur Empire]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kyranae Plains’</ref>
==Cities== * [[Cenei]]
==Provinces== * [[Sudica]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Plains]]

revision.comment: Added information on the formation of the Ring Mountains.
revision.text:
The '''Ring Mountains''' are a northern mountain range that encircles [[Golgotterath]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ring Mountains’</ref>
Not a natural geologic formation, the Ring Mountains were created during [[Arkfall]] when the [[Incû-Holoinas]] crashed into [[Eärwa]]. As the Ark-of-the-Skies began to crash, the Inertial Inversion Field reached into the earth and pulled up the landscape in a failed attempt at slowing the descent of the ship.<ref>''The Unholy Consult,'' Chapter 14</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Mountains]]

'''Cingulat''' is a [[Ketyai]] nation of the [[Three Seas]], located on the northwestern coast of [[Kutnarmu]], just south of [[Nilnamesh]]. <ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Cingulat’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Nations]]

{{Character infobox | name = Anasûrimbor Ganrelka II | titles = High King of Kûniüri | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]'' | lived = 2104 - 2147 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Kûniüri]] | gender = Male | occupation = High King of Kûniüri | relatives = [[Anasûrimbor Nanor-Ukkerja I]] (ancestor)
[[Anasûrimbor Celmomas II]] (father)
[[Anasûrimbor Nau-Cayûti]] (brother)(?)
[[Anasûrimbor Moënghus]] (descendant)
[[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]] (descendant) }} '''Anasûrimbor Ganrelka II''' was the successor of [[Anasûrimbor Celmomas II]] and the last reigning High King of [[Kûniüri]].Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ganrelka II, Anasûrimbor’ Ganrelka was Celmomas II’s heir, and took part in the [[Second Ordeal]]. He was present at the disastrous [[Battle of Eleneöt Fields]], where Celmomas was struck down, but was rescued from danger by five knights of [[Trysë]]. In 2147, following the complete annihilation of Kûniüri by the unopposed Horde of the [[No-God]], Ganrelka and his court escaped to the hidden fortress of [[Ishuäl]] in the remote [[Demua Mountains]]. While the utter secrecy of the fortress’s location prevented the No-God from assailing it, Ganrelka and all his family—save his bastard son—perished of the plague within months.''The Darkness That Comes Before,'' Prologue ==References== [[Category:Anasûrimbor]] [[Category:Characters from Kûniüri]] [[Category:Kings]] [[Category:Norsirai]]

The '''Demua Mountains''' are an extensive range located in northwestern [[Eärwa]], forming the frontier between [[Injor-Niyas]] and what was once [[Kûniüri]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Demua Mountains’</ref>
==Fortifications== * [[Ishuäl]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Mountains]]

The '''Ûmeri Empire''' (also known as '''Ûmerau Empire''' or simly '''Ûmeria''') was the first great nation of [[Men]], encompassing the length of the [[River Aumris]], founded after the overthrow of the [[Trysë|Trysean]] God-Kings c. 430<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Ûmeri Empire'</ref>.
==Cities== * [[Etrith]] * [[Lokor]] * [[Sauglish]] * [[Trysë]] * [[Ûmerau]]
== Known Rulers == * [[Avalunsil]] (Empress, reigned ?-ca. 860)<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Avalunsil'</ref> * [[Carû-Ongonean]] (third God-King, reigned ?-588)<ref name=":1">Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Carû-Ongonean'</ref> * [[Cel-Ongonean]] (reigned ?-ca. 917)<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Aulyanau the Conqueror'</ref><ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Kûniüri'</ref><ref group="Note">Cel-Ongonean is never actually stated to have been a ruler of the Ûmeri Empire, but it can be assumed this was the case, since his defeat at the Battle of River Axau directly led to the beginning of the [[Cond Yoke]].</ref> * [[Iswolor]] (King, reigned ?-?)<ref>''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 3</ref><ref group="Note">Iswolor is not confirmed to have been a king of the Ûmeri Empire, but it is likely this was the case, as it is mentioned he died in the Plains of Agongorea, "his bones as old as Ûmerau".</ref> * [[Nincaerû-Telesser|Nincaerû-Telesser I]] (fourth God-King, reigned 588-642)<ref name=":1" /><ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Nincaerû-Telesser'</ref> * [[Nincaerû-Telesser II]] (God-King, reigned ?-668)<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Great Library of Sauglish'</ref> * [[Nincama-Telesser]] (God-King, reigned ?-ca. 661 or later)<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Emilidis'</ref><ref group="Note">Nincama-Telesser is mentioned to have lived from 574 to 668 in ''[[The False Sun]]''. As the same dates of birth and death are given for Nincaerû-Telesser II in the Encyclopedic Glossary, it's possible they were intended to be the same individual and the name "Nincama-Telesser" is either a mistake or an alternate name for Nincaerû-Telesser II. If the dates given in ''The False Sun'' are not considered canonical, it is possible that Nincama-Telesser instead reigned between Nincaerû-Telesser I and Nincaerû-Telesser II.</ref> * [[Wulta-Ongorean]] (Emperor, reigned ?-?)<ref name=":0" /><ref group="Note">Wulta-Ongorean is never actually referred to as a ruler of the Ûmeri Empire; this assumption and his title of Emperor are based on the fact that his daughter Avalunsil became Empress after his death.</ref>
==Notes== <references group="Note" /> ==References== <references /> [[Category:Nations]]

[[File:Ce_Tydonn.png|thumb|400px|Ce Tydonn in 4109.]]'''Ce Tydonn''' is a [[Norsirai]] nation of the [[Three Seas]], located north of [[Conriya]] on the eastern shoreline of the [[Meneanor|Meneanor Sea]], founded in 3742 in the wake of [[Cengemis]]’s collapse.
==History== The first mention of the Tydonni is found in [[Casidas]]’s ''[[The Annals of Cenei]],'' where he mentions their raids across the [[River Swa]]. Descendants of the White Norsirai refugees from the [[Apocalypse]], the ancestors of the Tydonni are thought to have occupied the southern regions of the [[Dameöri Wilderness]] for centuries, prevented by their native fractiousness and infighting from causing much difficulty for their southern [[Ketyai]] neighbours. However, at some point in the thirty-eighth century, they united into one army, and with little difficulty they attacked and overwhelmed the people of Cengemis at the [[Battle of Marswa]] in 3722. The Cengemi were subjugated by the Tydonni, who settled down in their land. But it wasn’t until King [[Haul-Namyelk]] finally succeeded in unifying the various Tydonni tribes under his absolute authority in 3741 that Ce Tydonn proper came into existence.
==Culture== Perhaps the most peculiar and distinctive predilection of the Tydonni is found in their racial beliefs. ''Ti dunn'' literally means “struck iron” in their tongue, reflecting their old belief that their people have been purified and pruned by the ordeal of the Apocalypse and the crucible of their long wandering through the harsh Dameöri Wilderness. They hold that this gives them “privileged blood,” rendering them morally, intellectually, and physically superior to other races. They believe the darker-skinned races to be unclean and polluted, and look down upon them. This has made the Tydonni cruel overlords of their Cengemi subjects, who have often rebelled against them.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ce Tydonn’</ref>
==Fiefdoms== * [[Agansanor]] * [[Canute]] * [[Cuärweth]] * [[Gaethuni]] * [[Nangael]] * [[Numaineiri]] * [[Plaideöl]] * [[Sumagalt]] * [[Warnute]]
==Cities== * [[Marsadda]] * [[Meigeiri]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Nations]]
#redirect [[Ce Tydonn]]

'''''Isûphiryas''''' (“Great Pit of Years” in Ihrimsû) is the great work chronicling the history of the [[Nonmen]] prior to the [[Gates of Eärwa|Breaking of the Gates]]. In all likelihood it is the most ancient text in existence.
Sometime in the fourth century, a copy of the ''Isûphiryas'' was given to [[Cûnwerishau]] by [[Nil’giccas]], the Nonman King of [[Ishterebinth|Ishoriöl]], as part of the ancient treaty between their two peoples—the first between Nonmen and [[Men]]. During the reign of the God-King [[Carû-Ongonean]], five [[Ûmeri Empire|Ûmeri]] translations of the ''Isûphiryas'' were bequeathed to the [[Library of Sauglish]]. Four of these were destroyed in the [[Apocalypse]]. The fifth was saved by [[Seswatha]], who delivered it to the scribes of the [[Three Seas]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ''‘Isûphiryas’''</ref>
==Excerpts== ‘And [[Inchoroi|they]] forged counterfeits from our frame, [[Sranc|creatures]] vile and obscene, who hungered only for violent congress. These beasts they loosed upon the land, where they multiplied, no matter how fierce the [[Ishroi]] who hunted them. And soon Men clamoured at our gates, begging sanctuary, for they could not contend with the creatures. “They wear your face,” the penitents cried. “This calamity is your issue.” But we were wroth, and turned them away, saying, “These are not our Sons. And you are not our Brothers.”’<ref>''The White-Luck Warrior,'' Chapter 4</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Written works]]

The '''Xiuhianni''' are one of the [[Five Tribes of Men]]. They are a black-haired, brown-eyed, olive-skinned race that still dwells beyond the [[Great Kayarsus]].
According to ''[[The Chronicle of the Tusk]],'' the Xiuhianni refused to follow the other four tribes into [[Eärwa]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Xiuhianni’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Races]]

{{Character infobox | name = Anasûrimbor Nanor-Ukkerja I | titles = High King of Kûniüri | nicknames = Hammer of Heaven | appearances = mentioned only | lived = 1378 - 1556 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Kûniüri]] | gender = Male | occupation = High King of Kûniüri | relatives = [[Anasûrimbor Mygella]] (descendant)
[[Anasûrimbor Nimeric]] (descendant)
[[Anasûrimbor Celmomas II]] (descendant)
[[Anasûrimbor Ganrelka II]] (descendant)
[[Anasûrimbor Moënghus]] (descendant)
[[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]] (descendant) }} '''Nanor-Ukkerja I''' (“Hammer of Heaven” in Kûniüric from Ûmeritic ''nanar hukisha'') was the first Anasûrimbor High King. His defeat of the [[Scintya]] in 1408 led to the founding of [[Kûniüri]] and began what most scholars regard as the longest-reigning [[Anasûrimbor Dynasty|dynasty]] in recorded history.Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Nanor-Ukkerja I’ Over the course of his long life (he lived to the age of 178, the reputed result of the [[Nonmen|Nonman]] blood in his veins), Nanor-Ukkerja I extended Kûniüri to the [[Yimaleti Mountains]] in the north, to the westernmost coasts of the [[Cerish|Cerish Sea]] in the east, to [[Sakarpus]] in the south, and to the [[Demua Mountains]] in the west. At his death, he divided this empire between his sons, creating [[Aörsi]] and [[Sheneor]] in addition to Kûniüri proper.Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kûniüri’ ==References== [[Category:Characters from Kûniüri]] [[Category:Kings]] [[Category:Anasûrimbor]] [[Category:Norsirai]]

{{Character infobox | name = Carû-Ongonean | titles = God-King of the Ûmeri Empire | nicknames = | appearances = mentioned only | lived = ? - ? | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Ûmeri Empire|Ûmeri]] | gender = Male | occupation = God-King of the Ûmeri Empire | relatives = }}
'''Carû-Ongonean''' was the third God-King of the [[Ûmeri Empire]] during the [[Nonman Tutelage]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kûniüri’</ref>
Among his notable achievements was the founding of the [[Library of Sauglish]], ''c.'' 560.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Great Library of Sauglish’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Kings]] [[Category:Characters from the Ûmeri Empire]] [[Category:Norsirai]]

'''Numaineiri''' is a populous and fertile fiefdom of interior [[Ce Tydonn]], located to the west of [[Meigeiri]].
Numaineiri warriors are known to paint their faces red whenever they believe themselves doomed in battle.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Numaineiri’</ref>
The Earl of Numaineiri is [[Eorcu Othrain]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Othrain, Eorcu’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Fiefdoms]]

'''Meigeiri''' is the administrative and spiritual capital of [[Ce Tydonn]], founded in 3739 about the [[Ceneian Empire|Ceneian]] fortress of [[Meigara]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Meigeiri’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

{{Character infobox | name = Casidas | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = mentioned only | lived = 3081 - 3142 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | gender = Male | occupation = Philospher
Historian | relatives = }} '''Casidas''' was a famed philosopher and historian of [[Near Antiquity]], best known for his magisterial ''[[The Annals of Cenei]]''.Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Casidas' ==References== [[Category:Philosophers]] [[Category:Writers]] [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Characters from the Ceneian Empire]]

The '''River Sursa''' is the river system that once formed the crucial frontier between [[Agongorea]] and [[Aörsi]] before the [[Apocalypse]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Sursa River’</ref> It is no accident that the word ''sursa'' came to mean “front line” across the [[Ancient North]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Aörsi’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Rivers]]

The '''Satyothi''' are one of the [[Five Tribes of Men]]. They are a black-haired, green-eyed, black-skinned race predominantly concentrated in the nation of [[Zeüm]] and the southern extremities of the [[Three Seas]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Satyothi’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Races]]

'''Ishterebinth''' (“Exalted Stronghold” in Ihrimsû) is the last-surviving of the [[Nonmen|Nonman]] [[Mansion|Mansions]], located west of the [[Demua Mountains]].
Known as '''Ishoriöl''' (“Exalted Hall” in Ihrimsû) in the ''[[Isûphiryas]],'' Ishterebinth was considered one of the premier cities of the Cûnuroi after [[Siöl]] and [[Cil-Aujas]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ishterebinth’</ref> The Mansion was founded by Siöl, the House Primordial. In time Ishoriöl became known as the House Eschatological. It later eclipsed Siöl both culturally and economically before the latter was destroyed in the [[Breaking of the Gates]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Siöl'</ref>
By the year 4132, all the remaining Nonmen of Ishterebinth have joined the [[Consult]] save for their last King, [[Nil’giccas]], whose pride drove him to abandon the Mansion and become an [[Erratic]] instead.<ref>''The White-Luck Warrior,'' Chapter 15</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Mansions]]

{{Character infobox | name = Shaeönanra | image = Fallen.jpg | titles = Grandvizier of the Mangaecca | nicknames = Gift of Light
Cheater of Gods
Shauriatas | appearances = ''[[The False Sun (Atrocity Tale)|The False Sun]]''
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' | lived = 1086 - present (?) | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Ûmeri Empire|Ûmeri]] | gender = Male | occupation = [[Mangaecca]] [[Sorcerer]]
Grandvizier of the Mangaecca
Founder of the [[Consult]] | relatives = }} '''Shaeönanra''' (“Gift of Light” in Ûmeritic) is the current Grandvizier of the [[Mangaecca]] and one of the founders of the [[Consult]]. Shaeönanra was the son of a treasurer and grew up in [[Ûmerau]] at the time of the [[Cond]] Yoke. Demonstrating an aptitude for sorcery at a young age, he was taken in the [[the Schools|Schools]] and soon became a rising star within the Mangaecca. He was also a cunning political mind, and kept a network of spies in the Cond Empire. As the Grandvizier of the Mangaecca, he led the School to unprecedented heights. According to legend, Shaeönanra went mad while studying the [[Incû-Holoinas]], and his subsequent acts saw him convicted of impiety and his School outlawed in 1123. [[File:FalseSun.jpg|thumb|left|300px|The Glorious Pupil, Titirga, Grandmaster of the Sohonc, shines the famed Day Lantern on Shaeönanra, Grandmaster of the Mangaecca and dread leader of the Unholy Consult.]] The greatest prodigy of his age, Shaeönanra claimed to have rediscovered a means of saving the souls of those damned by [[sorcery]]. He reputedly spent his life investigating various soul-trapping sorceries in the hope of avoiding passage to the [[Outside]]—and to great effect, given that he allegedly continues to live some three thousand years afterward, though in an obscene and unnatural manner. By the fourteenth century the [[Trysë|Trysean]] annals began referring to him as '''Shauriatas''' (“Cheater of Gods” in Ûmeritic), instead.Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Shaeönanra’Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Shauriatas’ === ''The Unholy Consult'' === When [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]] entered [[Golgotterath]], he was shown not what he expected, but two Larvae, one of which was Shauriatas, or Shaeönanra. A group of [[Dûnyain]] [[Thought Dancers|Thought-Dancers]] appeared, winking both grovelling Larvae out of existence. They explained they had taken the Consult over from within, and that all but Shauriatas had given in to their demands, and therefore he was the only one to be severely punished.''The Unholy Consult, ''Chapter 17 ==References== [[Category:Characters from the Ûmeri Empire]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Consult members]] [[Category:Characters from Golgotterath]]

'''Nron''' is a minor island nation of the [[Three Seas]], nominally independent but in fact dominated by the [[The Schools|School]] of [[Mandate]] in [[Atyersus]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Nron’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Nations]]

'''Mehtsonc''' was the ancient administrative and commercial capital of [[Kyraneas]], destroyed in the [[Apocalypse]] in 2154.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Mehtsonc’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

The '''Secharib Plains''' are the vast alluvial tablelands that sweep north from the [[River Sayut]] in [[High Ainon]], noted for their fertility (sixty- to seventy-fold crop yields) and dense population.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Secharib Plains’</ref>
==Palatinates== * [[Eshganax]] * [[Eshkalas]] * [[Hinnant]]
==Cities== * [[Moserothu]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Plains]]

'''Galeoth''' is a [[Norsirai]] nation of the [[Three Seas]].
[[File:44-365.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Galeoth Warrior by [http://spiralhorizon.deviantart.com/ SpiralHorizon]]][[File:Galeoth.png|thumb|400px|Galeoth in 4109.]]
Following the [[Apocalypse]], countless thousands of [[Meöri Empire|Meöri]] refugees settled the environs north of [[Huösi|Lake Huösi]]. Though nominally tributary to the [[Ceneian Empire]], surviving records indicate that the “Galoti,” as the Ceneians called them, were a fractious and warlike people. At some point in the thirty-fifth century, sedentary kingdoms began to displace the pastoral tribes along the [[River Vindauga]] and [[River Sculpa]]. Galeoth proper did not arise until ''c.'' 3683, when King [[Norwain I]] reputedly concluded twenty years of campaigning and conquest by having his captive foes butchered en masse in the reception hall of [[Moraör]], the great palace complex of the Galeoth Kings.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Galeoth’</ref>
It is a commonly-believed legend that the famed fractiousness of the Galeoth derives from a curse laid on their Meöri forefathers by the [[Nonmen|Nonman]] King [[Gin’yursis]], who was betrayed and killed by the hero [[Nostol]] and his Meöri comrades after the [[Battle of Kathol Pass]]. In actuality, Gin’yursis was not so discriminate; he placed his curse on all [[Men]].<ref>''The Judging Eye,'' Chapter 11</ref>
==Fiefdoms== * [[Agmundr]] * [[Gaenri]] * [[Gesindal]] * [[Kurigald]] * [[Nergaöta]] * [[Usgald]]
==Cities== * [[Oswenta]]
==Natural Features== * [[Parrhae Plains]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Nations]]

{{Character infobox | name = Gin’yursis | titles = King | nicknames = Wight-in-the-Mountain | appearances = ''[[The Thousandfold Thought]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Judging Eye (Book)|The Judging Eye]]''
''[[The White-Luck Warrior]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Great Ordeal]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The False Sun]]'' (mentioned) | lived = ? - 2152 | race = [[Nonmen]] | ethnicity = | nationality = [[Cil-Aujas]] | gender = Male | occupation = King of [[Cil-Aujas]] | relatives =[[Risaphial]] (nephew) }} [[File:Wightinthemountain.png|thumb|300px|Wight-in-the-Mountain by Quinthane]] [[File:Gin'yursis.JPG|thumb|300px|Gin’yursis after becoming the Wight-in-the-Mountain at Cil-Aujas.]] '''Gin’yursis''' was the [[Nonmen|Nonman]] King of [[Cil-Aujas]] during the [[Apocalypse]]. Gin’yursis was alive as far back as the [[Nonman Tutelage]]; his greatest student was [[Sos-Praniura]], who founded the [[Mangaecca]] in 684.Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Mangaecca’ In the autumn of 2151, Gin’yursis allied with a band of [[Meöri Empire|Meöri]] led by the hero [[Nostol]]. The forces succeeded in holding back the Horde of the [[No-God]] at the [[Battle of Kathol Pass]], which would be the only victory during the [[Years of the Crib]]. However, the following spring, the resentment of the [[Men]] towards the Nonmen led them to betray their allies. The Nonmen of Cil-Aujas were massacred, including Gin’yursis. Common legend holds that the famous fractiousness of the [[Galeoth]] is due to a curse placed on their Meöri forefathers by Gin’yursis. In actuality, Gin’yursis was not so discriminate in his dying; he cursed all Men.''The Judging Eye,'' Chapter 11 However, because Cil-Aujas was a [[topoi|topos]], Gin’yursis survived past his death as a ghostly apparition, the Wight-in-the-Mountain. He continued to haunt the halls of Cil-Aujas until 4132, when [[Mimara]] exorcized him using a [[Chorae]] and her [[Judging Eye]].''The Judging Eye,'' Chapter 16 ==References== [[Category:Cûnuroi]]

The '''River Sayut''' is one of the great rivers of [[Eärwa]], originating in the Southern [[Great Kayarsus]] and draining into the [[Nyranisas|Nyranisas Sea]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Sayut River’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Rivers]]

'''Caraskand''' is a major city and great caravan entrepôt of the southwestern [[Three Seas]]. It is the administrative and commercial capital of [[Enathpaneah]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Caraskand’</ref> Caraskand was the site of a [[Battle of Caraskand|pivotal battle]] in 4112 between the host of [[Kascamandri ab Tepherokar]], the [[Padirajah]] of [[Kian]], and the [[Holy War|First Holy War]] under [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Battle of Caraskand’</ref>
The city is built on nine heights, five of which surround its central quarter known as the Bowl.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘The Bowl’</ref> The Heights of the Bull are the location of the Fama Palace, the residence and administrative seat of the [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Warrior-Prophet]] during the First Holy War’s stay at Caraskand.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Heights of the Bull’</ref><ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Fama Palace’</ref> The Sapatishah’s Palace is located on the Kneeling Heights.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Sapatishah’s Palace’</ref><ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kneeling Heights’</ref>
Caraskand’s outermost fortifications are known as the Triamic Walls, and were raised by [[Triamis the Great]] in 2568.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Triamic Walls’</ref> Two of its main gates are the Gate of Horns, and its northernmost gate, the Ivory Gate, so named because of the pale limestone used to construct it.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Gate of Horns’</ref><ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ivory Gate’</ref>
Caraskand also houses the [[Csokis]], a derelict [[Inrithism|Inrithi]] temple complex located in the great campus of [[Kalaul]], which was the site of the Warrior-Prophet’s Circumfixion beneath [[Umiaki]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Csokis’</ref><ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kalaul’</ref><ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Umiaki’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

'''Annand''' is a province of north central [[Conriya]], known primarily for its silver and iron mines<ref name=":0" />.
"All the silver in Annand" is a common [[Three Seas]] expression, meaning "pricelessness"<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Annand'</ref>.
The Palatine of Annand at the time of the [[Holy War|First Holy War]] was [[Ersa Kushigas]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Kushigas'</ref><ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Ersa Kushigas'</ref>.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Provinces]]

The '''Meöri Empire''' (or '''Meörn Empire''') is a lost nation of the Ancient North.
Founded as a trading stronghold by [[Akksersia]]n colonists c. 850, the city of [[Kelmeöl]] grew rapidly, and its people, the Meöri, progressively asserted more and more authority over the neighbouring White [[Norsirai]] tribes. By the time [[Borswelka I]] was declared King in 1021, it had become an agressive, militaristic city-state. By the time his grandson [[Borswelka II]] died in 1104, it had conquered most of the [[River Vosa]] Basin and had established trading contracts with [[Shir]] to the south through a series of forts along the [[River Wernma]]. Strategically situated, and without any regional competitors, the Meöri Empire, as it came to be called, flourished as a mercantile nation. It collapsed with the destruction of Kelmeöl in 2150 during the [[Apocalypse]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Meöri Empire’</ref>
==Cities== * [[Kelmeöl]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Nations]]
#redirect [[Meöri Empire]]

'''Girgash''' is a nation of the [[Three Seas]], located on the mountainous northern frontier of [[Nilnamesh]], and the only [[Fanimry|Fanim]] nation aside from [[Kian]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Girgash’</ref>.
The King of Girgash at the time of the [[Holy War|First Holy War]] was [[Pilaskanda]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Pilaskanda’</ref>. Under the [[New Empire]], [[Urmakthi ab Makthi]] became the Believer-King of Girgash<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Urmakthi ab Makthi'</ref>.
==Cities== * [[Ajowai]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Nations]]

'''Gedea''' is a governorate of [[Kian]] and former province of the [[Nansur Empire]]<ref name=":0" />.
Located between [[Shigek]] and the [[Unaras Spur]], Gedea is a semi-arid land with interior plateaus and semi-mountainous coasts. Historically, Gedea is primarily known as the battleground between ancient Shigek and [[Kyraneas]]<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Gedea’</ref>.
The Sapatishah-Governor of Gedea at the time of the [[Holy War|First Holy War]] was [[Ansacer ab Salajka]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Ansacer ab Salajka'</ref>.
==Cities== * [[Hinnereth]]
==Structures== * [[Dayrut]] * [[Ebara]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Governorates]]

[[File:Marine by quintvc-d865db9.png|thumb|300px|Cironji Marine by Quinthane.]] '''Cironj''' is a [[Ketyai]] island nation located at the juncture of all three of the [[Three Seas]], and possessing a strong mercantile and maritime tradition.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Cironj’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Nations]]

[[File:Cishaurim_sm.jpg|thumb|300px]] [[File:Mallahet by spiralhorizon-d7xx9ba.jpg|thumb|300px|The notorious Cishaurim sorcerer-priest, Mallahet]] The '''Cishaurim''' are the notorious priest-[[sorcerer]]s of the [[Fanimry|Fanim]] based in [[Shimeh]]. According to the Fanim religious tradition, the Prophet [[Fane]] became the first of the Cishaurim after he went blind in the desert. Given Fane’s claim that the true power of the [[Solitary God]] cannot be exercised so long as one sees the profane world, Cishaurim initiates voluntarily blind themselves at a certain point in their study, enabling to dispense the “divine water” of the “[[Psûkhe]],” as the Cishaurim refer to it. Little is known about the metaphysics of the Psûkhe beyond the fact that it cannot be perceived by the [[The Few|Few]] and that it is in many ways almost as formidable as the [[Anagogis|Anagogic]] practice of the [[The Schools|Schools]]. The [[Scarlet Spires]] categorize individual Cishaurim according to their power: Tertiaries, or those with only the most rudimentary strength; Secondaries, or those with strength comparable to sorcerous initiates; and Primaries, those with strength exceeding that of initiates (but still, according to the Scarlet Magi, short of the strength possessed by true Anagogic sorcerers of rank).Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Cishaurim’ As the Psûkhe is also known as the Water of Indara,Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Fane’ the Cishaurim are sometimes referred to as [[Indara-Kishauri]]: “Indara’s Water-bearers.”Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Indara-Kishauri’ In an interview R. Scott Bakker explains "Everything comes down to meaning in Eärwa. Where sorcery is representational, utilizing either the logical form (as with the Gnosis) or the material content (as with the Anagogis) of meaning to leverage transformations of reality, the Psukhe utilizes the impetus. Practitioners of the Psukhe blind themselves to see through the what and grasp the how, the pure performative kernel of meaning–the music, the passion, or as the Cishaurim call it, the ‘Water.’ As a contemporary philosopher might say, the Psukhe is noncognitive, it has no truck with warring versions of reality, which is why it possesses no Mark and remains invisible to the Few." ==Known Members== * [[Fane]] (founder) * [[Fanfarokar]] * [[Hab’hara]] * [[Hahkti ab Sibban]] (Heresiarch) * [[Hifanat ab Tunukri]] * [[Inkorot]] * [[Kisma]] * [[Anasûrimbor Moënghus|Mallahet]] * [[Meppa]] * [[Sartmandri]] * [[Seökti]] (Heresiarch) * [[Tatokar I]] (Heresiarch) == Spells == * The Scourge * The Lash ==References== [[Category:Schools]]

The '''Great Kayarsus''' is a vast system of mountain ranges that forms the eastern frontier of [[Eärwa]], stretching for several thousand miles.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Great Kayarsus’</ref>
[[Siöl]], the oldest and greatest of the [[Nonmen]] Mansions, lay under the northern Great Kayarsus, guarding a fortified series of passes leading east into the continent of [[Eänna]]. According to some historians, [[Siöl]] itself is the [[Gates of Eärwa|Gate of Thayant]], the shattering of which marks the beginning of dated human history and the commencing of the [[Cûno-Halaroi Wars]].<ref>Encyclopedia Glossary II, 'Siöl'</ref>
Aside from the Gate of Thayant, no other major pass linking Eärwa to Eänna is known to exist, although one in the vicinity of [[Jekhia]] in far north-eastern [[High Ainon]] is likely, given the history of that region and the cultural influence of the [[Xiuhianni]], the only one of the [[Five Tribes of Men]] to remain in Eänna.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Mountains]]

[[File:Sandstorm by quintvc-d6td5a7.png|thumb|300px|Sandstorm in Carathay Desert by Quinthane.]][[File:Carathay_Desert.png|thumb|400px|The Great Carathay Desert in 4109.]]
The '''Carathay Desert''' (also known as '''Great Desert''') is a vast arid region of dunes and gravel flats occupying southerwestern [[Eärwa]].
Large oases are primarily found along the eastern regions of the desert, but there are skeletal river systems throughout.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Carathay Desert'</ref>
The desert is known to the [[Khirgwi]] as “Ej’ulkiyah,” meaning “Great Thirst.”<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ej’ulkiyah’</ref>
==Natural Features== * [[River Sweki]] * [[Subis]] * [[Tamiznai]]
==Regions== * [[Chianadyni]] * [[Great Salt|The Great Salt]] * [[Khemema]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Deserts]]
[[Category:People]] [[Category:Settlements]]
[[Category:Settlements]]
[[Category:Geography]]

[[File:Daemori_Wilderness.png|thumb|400px|The Daemori Wilderness in 4109.]]The '''Dameöri Wilderness''' (or '''Meörn Wilderness''') is a vast tract of forested, [[Sranc]]-infested wilderness extending from the [[Ce Tydonn|Tydonni]] frontier in the south and running northeast of the [[Osthwai Mountains]] to the [[Cerish|Sea of Cerish]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Dameöri Wilderness’</ref> The [[Scalpoi|scalpers]], however, simply called it the “Long Side.”<ref>''The White-Luck Warrior,'' Chapter 1</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Plains]]

'''Domyot''', also known as the Black Iron City, is the administrative capital of [[Zeüm]].
The city is famed for the cruelty of its rulers and for its iron-skirted walls. For most in the [[Three Seas]], Domyot is as much a place of legend as [[Golgotterath]].
“Domyot” is Sheyic version of “Torumyan.”<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Domyot’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

The '''River Rohil''' is the easternmost of the three major river systems draining into [[Huösi|Lake Huösi]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Rohil River’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Rivers]]
[[Category:Geography]]

The '''River Sweki''' is the so-called “miracle river,” revered as holy by the [[Kian]]ene, who claim that its waters arise from nothing by the will of the [[Solitary God]]. Before the first Jihads, [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] cartographers made several attempts to locate its headwaters in the [[Great Salt]], none of them successful.
“Sweki” means “The Sacred” in Kianni.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Sweki River’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Rivers]]

The '''River Wernma''' is an extensive river system in east central [[Eärwa]], draining vast tracts of the [[Dameöri Wilderness]] and emptying into the [[Meneanor|Meneanor Sea]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Wernma River’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Rivers]]

[[Image:Three_Seas.png|thumb|400px|The Three Seas of Eärwa.]]The '''Sea of Meneanor''' is the northernmost of the [[Three Seas]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Meneanor, Sea of’</ref>
==Rivers Emptying into Meneanor== * [[River Jeshimal]] * [[River Phayus]] * [[River Sempis]] * [[River Shaul]] * [[River Swa]] * [[River Wernma]] * [[River Wutmouth]]
==Cities== * [[Anqui]] * [[Gerotha]] * [[Gielgath]] * [[Hinnereth]] * [[Joktha]] * [[Marsadda]] * [[Momemn]] * [[Shimeh]] * [[Sumna]]
==Structures== * [[Kijenicho]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Seas]]
[[Category:Geography]]

The '''Neleöst Sea''' is a large inland sea located in northwestern [[Eärwa]] that formed the traditional northern frontier for those nations arising from the [[River Aumris]] Valley.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Neleöst Sea’</ref> It is also known as the '''Misty Sea'''.<ref>''The Great Ordeal'' map</ref>
==Rivers Emptying into the Neleöst Sea== * [[River Aumris]] * [[River Sursa]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Seas]]
#redirect [[Neleöst]]

[[Image:Three_Seas.png|thumb|400px|The Three Seas of Eärwa.]]The '''Nyranisas Sea''' is the easternmost of the [[Three Seas]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Nyranisas Sea’</ref>
==Rivers Emptying into the Nyranisas== * [[River Sayut]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Seas]]

The '''River Phayus''' is the primary river system of the [[Kyranae Plains]], draining the south central [[Hethanta Mountains]] and emptying into the [[Meneanor|Meneanor Sea]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Phayus River’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Rivers]]

The '''Hethanta Mountains''' are a large mountain range located in central [[Eärwa]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Hethanta Mountains’</ref> They separate the [[Nansur Empire]] from the [[Jiünati Steppe]].
==Natural Features== * [[Attong Plateau]] * [[River Phayus]] * [[Sakthuta]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Mountains]]

The '''Indigo Plague,''' also known as the '''Great Pestilence,''' is the devastating pandemic that swept across [[Eärwa]] in 2157 following the death of the [[No-God]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Great Pestilence’</ref>
According to legend, the pestilence swept up from the No-God’s ashes after his destruction at the hands of [[Anaxophus V]] in 2155. [[Mandate]] scholars dispute this, claiming that the No-God’s body was recovered by the [[Consult]] and interred in [[Golgotterath]]. Whatever the cause, the Indigo Plague ranks as among the worst in recorded history.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Indigo Plague’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:War]] [[Category:First Apocalypse]]

'''Viramsata''', "many-breaths", is a game played in southern [[Nilnamesh]].
Viramsata is a game of truth. The players tell lies about who said what to whom, about who makes love to whomever, and so on. They do this continually, and what is more, they are at pains to act out the lies told by others, especially when they are elegant, so they might make them true. And so it goes from tongue to lip to tongue, until no distinction remains between what is a lie and what is true.
In the end, at a great ceremony, it is the most compelling tale that is declare ''Pirvirsut'', a word that means 'this breath is ground' in ancient Vaparsi. The weak, the inelegant, have died, while others grow strong, yielding only to the Pirvirsut, the Breath-that-is-Ground.
The viramsata become living things, and humans are their battleground.{{3|16}}
==References== <references /> [[Category:Culture]]

[[File:Shimeh.png|thumb|center|500px]] '''Shimeh''' is the second-holiest city of [[Inrithism]], located in [[Amoteu]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Shimeh’</ref> According to [[The Tractate|scripture]], its Sacred Heights, the [[Juterum]], were the site of [[Inri Sejenus]]’s [[Ascension]] to the [[Nail of Heaven]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Juterum, the’</ref>
Shimeh was sacked by the [[Fanimry|Fanim]] in 3845<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘College of Marucee’</ref><ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kian’</ref> and remained under their control until its conquest by [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]] and the [[Holy War]] in 4112.<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought,'' Chapter 16</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

The '''Nail of Heaven''' is the northern star that, aside from being the brightest in the night sky (it is sometimes visible in daylight), provides the axis from which all other stars revolve.{{EG|Nail of Heaven}} The [[Nonmen]] called it ‘''Imburil''’, meaning ‘the ''Newborn''’.[[The False Sun]] According to the tenets of [[Inrithism]], [[Inri Sejenus]] ascended to the Nail of Heaven after his death in 2202.{{EG|Inri Sejenus}} {{Blockquote|In the slot of a hanging ravine, the Nail of Heaven twinkled alone in the endless blue, a beacon of all things high and open…
A final call to those who would dare the nethers of the earth.{{4|11}}}} == Nature == One night the star suddenly blazed with a strange, sudden intensity. This waxing lasted a time and then abated. The Cûnuroi could not explain it, but then dismissed it as a curiosity and moved on with their lives. Three years after this curious event, the [[Incû-Holoinas]] fell down. This may mean that the Nail of Heaven is not an actual star but rather a wormhole Incû-Holoinas came through or even a mother-ship with Incû-Holoinas being a drop-ship. The fact that Nonmen call this star 'Newborn' support either of this. ==References== [[Category:Religion]] [[Category:Cosmos]]

'''Myclai''' was the ancient administrative and commercial capital of [[Akksersia]], destroyed in 2149 during the [[Apocalypse]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Myclai’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

'''Nagogris''' is a large New Dynasty [[Shigek]] city on the upper [[River Sempis]], famed for her red sandstone fortifications.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Nagogris’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

'''Iothiah''' is a great Old Dynasty [[Shigek]] city located on the [[River Sempis]] Delta.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Iothiah’</ref>
Iothiah is the location of the great [[Sareötic Library]], which in the time of the [[Ceneian Empire]] was one of the greatest libraries in the known world. The so-called “script law” of Iothiah forced, on punishment of death, all visitors bearing books to surrender them for copying and inclusion in the Library. Though the Sareöts were massacred when Shigek fell to the [[Fanimry|Fanim]] in 3933, Padirajah [[Fan’oukarji III]] spared the Library when he found it contained maps useful for his [[Dagger Jihad|Jihad]], thinking it the will of the [[Solitary God]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Sareotic Library’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

'''Girgilioth''' is a ruined city on the south bank of the [[River Sempis]], which was once the capital of [[Kyraneas]]-occupied [[Shigek]] but was destroyed following Kyraneas's demise in the [[Apocalypse]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 445, 'Girgilioth'</ref>.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Cities]]

'''Gesindal''' is a fiefdom of [[Galeoth]] located to the immediate northwest of [[Oswenta]]<ref name=":0" />.
A disproportionate number of Gesindalmen belong to the so-called Tattoo Cult of [[Gilgaöl]]—a subsect common among the Galeoth and [[Cepalor|Cepalorans]]—believing that skin tattooed with the sacred signs of War is immune to injury<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Gesindal’</ref>.
The Earl of Gesindal at the time of the [[Holy War|First Holy War]] was [[Thagawain Anfirig]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Anfirig, Thagawain’</ref>. This title was held by [[Linnû Arcastor]] by the time of the [[Great Ordeal]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Arcastor, Linnû'</ref>.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Fiefdoms]]

'''Oswenta''' is the administrative and commercial capital of [[Galeoth]], located on the north coast of [[Huösi|Lake Huösi]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Oswenta’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

'''Gielgath''' is an important [[Nansur]] city located on the [[Meneanor]] coast<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 444, 'Gielgath'</ref>.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Cities]]

'''Momemn''', "Praise Momas", is the administrative and commercial capital of the [[Nansur Empire]].
Heavily fortified, Momemn houses the residence of the Nansur Emperor, the [[Andiamine Heights]], as well as one of the busiest harbors on the [[Three Seas]]. Historians have oft noted how each of the three capitals ([[Mehtsonc]], [[Cenei]], and Momemn) of the three great empires to arise from the [[Kyranae Plains]] have stood along the [[River Phayus]], each closer than the last to the [[Meneanor]]. Some claim that Momemn, which stands at the mouth, will be the last, this leading to the common phrase "running out of river" to indicate changing fortunes.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 467, 'Momemn'</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

'''Usgald''' is a fiefdom in the [[Galeoth]] interior.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Usgald’</ref>
The Earl of Usgald is [[Raeharth Hagarond]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Hagarond, Raeharth’</ref>
==Trivia== * Usgald’s name is alternately spelled “Üsgald” in ''The Warrior-Prophet'' and “Usgald” in the Encyclopedic Glossary.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Fiefdoms]]

'''Cepalor''' is a region of temperate, semi-forested plains extending east of the [[Hethanta Mountains]] from the [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] frontier to the southwestern marches of [[Galeoth]].
Since the fall of [[Kyraneas]], Cepalor has been inhabited by [[Norsirai]] pastoralists known as the Cepalorae (Cepaloran), who have long been tributaries of the Nansurium.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Cepalor’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Plains]] [[Category:Nations]]

'''Eämnor''' is a lost White [[Norsirai]] nation of the [[Ancient North]].
The roots of Eämnor reach back to the days of [[Aulyanau]] the Conqueror and the Cond Yoke. In 927, Aulyana conquered the fortress of [[Ara-Etrith]] ("New Etrith") and, struck by the anarcane characteristics of [[Mount Ankulakai]], settled several [[Cond]] tribes in the vicinity. These tribes flourished, and under the influence of the nearby cities of the [[River Aumris]] they quickly abandoned their pastoral ways. In fact the Cond were so effectively assimilated into Aumris culture that their White Norsirai cousins, the [[Scintya]], took them for High Norsirai during the time of the Scintya Yoke (1228-1381).
Eämnor properly emerged from the Scintya Yoke as one of the pre-eminent nations of the Ancient North. Though laid waste in 2148, Eämnor could be considered the sole surviving nation of the [[Apocalypse]], insofar as [[Atrithau]] survived. Due to the concentrations of [[Sranc]], however, Atrithau has never been able to recover more than a fraction of the lands constituting historical Eämnor.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Eämnor'</ref>
==Cities and Provinces== * [[Atrithau]] * [[Sobel]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Nations]]

'''Mount Ankulakai''' is the mountain on the southern limit of the [[Demua Mountains]] that cradles the city of [[Atrithau]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ankulakai’</ref>
The foot of Mount Ankulakai is notable for being [[anarcane ground]]; which is to say, ground that renders [[sorcery]] impotent.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Atrithau’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Mountains]]

The '''Great Salt''' is a particularly harsh region of the [[Carathay Desert]] bordering traditional [[Chianadyni]].{{EG|Great Salt}}
==References== <references/> [[Category:Deserts]]

'''Nergaöta''' is a semi-mountainous fiefdom in northwestern [[Galeoth]], renowned for the quality of its wool.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Nergaöta’</ref>
The Earl of Nergaöta is [[Heänar Tharschilka]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Tharschilka, Heänar’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Fiefdoms]]

'''Gaenri''' is a fiefdom of [[Galeoth]], located to the northwest near the [[Hethanta Mountains]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Gaenri’</ref>.
The Earl of Gaenri at the time of the [[Holy War|First Holy War]] was [[Coithus Athjeäri]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Athjeäri, Coithus’</ref>. [[Sucoithus Hingeath]] eventually succeeded him, holding this title by the time of the [[Great Ordeal]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Hingeath, Sucoithus'</ref>.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Fiefdoms]]

The '''River Vindauga''' is the westernmost of the three major river systems draining into [[Huösi|Lake Huösi]], and the primary geographical boundary between [[Galeoth]] and [[Cepalor]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Vindauga River’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Rivers]]

'''Lake Huösi''' is a large freshwater lake draining the [[River Vindauga]] and [[River Sculpa]] systems, and emptying into the [[River Wutmouth]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Huösi, Lake’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Seas]]

The '''River Sculpa''' is the northernmost of the three major river systems draining into [[Huösi|Lake Huösi]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Sculpa River’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Rivers]]

'''Seleukara''' is a major port city on the south coast of [[Eumarna]]. It is the commercial capital of [[Kian]], and one of the great cities of the [[Three Seas]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Seleukara’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]
[[Category:Places]]

The '''Cerish Sea''' is the largest of [[Eärwa]]’s inland seas.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Cerish Sea’</ref>
==Rivers Emptying Into Cerish== * [[River Tywanrae]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Seas]]

The '''River Kiyuth''' is a tributary of the [[River Sempis]], running deep into the [[Jiünati Steppe]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kiyuth River’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Rivers]]

[[File:ScarletSchoolman sm.jpg|thumb|300px]] The '''Anagogis''' is a branch of [[sorcery]] that turns on the resonance between meanings and concrete things.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Anagogis’</ref> It uses creative metaphors to implement sorcery.
The Anagogis is generally considered inferior to the [[Gnosis]] because it works through Analogies as opposed to Abstractions: the Anagogic sorcerers can summon only an imitation of a dragon which spews out fire, while Gnostic sorcerers can summon heat itself.
==Anagogic Schools== * [[Imperial Saik]] * [[Mikka Council]] * [[Mysunsai]] * [[Nilitar Compact]] * [[Oaranat]] * [[Scarlet Spires]] * [[Vokalati]]
==Spells== * The Dragonhead * The Houlari Twin-Tempests * The Iswazi Cant * The Memkotic Furies * The Meppa Cataract * The Portcullis * The Ramparts of Ur * The Uruborian Circle
==Trivia== * The branches of sorcery all take their names from Greek words. “Anagogis” comes from the Greek word “Αναγωγής,” meaning “Comparison.”
==References== <references /> [[Category:Branches of Sorcery]]
#redirect [[Anagogis]]

[[File:Cishaurim_sm.jpg|thumb|300px]] [[File:Mallahet by spiralhorizon-d7xx9ba.jpg|thumb|300px|The notorious Cishaurim sorcerer-priest, Mallahet]] The '''Psûkhe''' is the arcane practice of the [[Cishaurim]], much like [[sorcery]], though cruder in its exercise, and distinguished by its invisibility to the [[The Few|Few]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Psûkhe’</ref>
While wielding [[Gnosis|Gnostic]] and [[Anagogis|Anagogic]] sorcery requires intellectual strength, one’s ability to wield the Psûkhe is relative to one’s passions. Practitioners of the Psûkhe blind themselves to the profane world as part of their studies.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Cishaurim’</ref>
Practitioners of the Psûkhe are called '''psûkari.'''<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘psûkari’</ref>
==Trivia== * The branches of sorcery all take their names from Greek words. “Psûkhe” comes from the Greek word “Ψυχή,” meaning “Soul”.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Branches of Sorcery]]

'''Mount Eshki,''' the “Mountain of Revelation,” is the legendary mountain where, according to ''[[The Chronicle of the Tusk]],'' the prophet [[Angeshraël]] received the call to lead the [[Five Tribes of Men]] into [[Eärwa]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Mount Eshki’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Mountains]] [[Category:Religion]]

The '''River Swa''' is the river that forms the northern frontier of [[Ce Tydonn]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Swa River’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Rivers]]

{{Character infobox | name = Cû’jara-Cinmoi | titles = High King | nicknames = The Copper Tree of [[Siöl]] | appearances = ''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Thousandfold Thought (Book)|The Thousandfold Thought]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Judging Eye (Book)|The Judging Eye]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The White-Luck Warrior]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Great Ordeal (Book)|The Great Ordeal]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Four Revelations of Cinial’jin|Four Revelations]]'' (flashbacks) | lived = ? - ? | race = [[Nonmen]] | ethnicity = | nationality = [[Siöl|Siölan]] | gender = Male | occupation = High King
King of [[Siöl]] | relatives =[[Cu'huriol]] (grandfather)
[[Morimhira]] (great-uncle)
[[Cet'moyol]] (father)
[[Linqirû]] (mother)
[[Cu'cûlol]] (kinsman)
[[Hanalinqû]] (wife) }} [[File:Cu’jara-Cinmoi.jpg|thumb|300px|Cû’jara-Cinmoi, greatest of the Nonman kings.]] [[File:Kings.jpg|thumb|300px|At the fields of Pir Pahal, Cû’jara-Cinmoi, greatest of the Nonman Kings, confronts the fierce Inchoroi King Sil, armored in festering bodies.]] '''Cû’jara-Cinmoi''' was the greatest of the [[Nonmen|Nonman]] Kings and the first great foe of the [[Inchoroi]]Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Cû’jara-Cinmoi’. ==Role in the Cûno-Inchoroi Wars== Cû’jara-Cinmoi was the King of [[Siöl]] when the [[Incû-Holoinas]] plunged to the earth in the land of [[Viri]]. [[Nin’janjin]], the Nonman King of Viri, sent a letter to Cû’jara-Cinmoi begging his aid; instead, Cû’jara-Cinmoi sent an army and invaded. Viri became a tributary of Siöl. Cû’jara-Cinmoi dispatched the hero [[Ingalira]] to investigate the Incû-Holoinas, and Ingalira returned with two Inchoroi captives. Repelled by the obscenities, Cû’jara-Cinmoi had them put to death and set a Watch upon the Incû-Holoinas. Cû’jara-Cinmoi proceeded to conquer the Mansions of [[Nihrimsul]] and [[Cil-Aujas]]. However, the Inchoroi sent a secret embassy to Nin’janjin, who allied with them against Cû’jara-Cinmoi. The Nonmen of Viri rose up in revolt against rule of Cû’jara-Cinmoi; at the same time, hordes of Inchoroi poured from the Incû-Holoinas. However, the Nonmen of Viri were appalled when they actually looked upon the Inchoroi, and turned on Nin’janjin, who attempted to flee. The Inchoroi then turned on the Nonmen, hoping to destroy them before Cû’jara-Cinmoi’s forces arrived. The first conflict of the [[Cûno-Inchoroi Wars]] occurred at [[Fields of Eleneöt|Fields of Pir Pahal]]. The [[Battle of Pir Pahal]] raged through the night and into the following morning, but the Nonmen eventually prevailed. Cû’jara-Cinmoi struck down the Inchoroi King, [[Sil]], and took his weapon, the [[Heron Spear]]. After the Battle of Pir Pahal, emboldened by Siöl’s distraction, Nihrimsul and Cil-Aujas had revolted. After years of hard campaigning, Cû’jara-Cinmoi finally brought the [[Ishroi]] of Cil-Aujas to heel, but King [[Sin’niroiha]] and the Ishroi of Nihrimsul continued to resist him. The ''[[Isûphiryas]]'' chronicles dozens of bloody yet indecisive confrontations between the two Kings: the Battle of Ciphara, the Battle of Hilcyri, the Siege of Asargoi. Proud beyond reason, Cû’jara-Cinmoi refused to relent, and put to death every embassy Sin’niroiha sent to him. Only when Sin’niroiha became King of [[Ishterebinth|Ishoriöl]] through marriage did the High King of Siöl concede. “A King of Three Mansions,” he is said to have declared, “may be Brother to a King of Two.” Many years later, when Cû’jara-Cinmoi began growing old and frail, Nin’janjin returned begging Mercy and Penance. Cû’jara-Cinmoi was shocked to see that Nin’janjin had not aged. Cû’jara-Cinmoi offered peace with the Inchoroi in exchange for their secrets of immortality. He allowed the Inchoroi to move freely among the Nonmen, distributing the remedies that would make them immortal and doom them all. The first victim of the Womb-Plague was Cû’jara-Cinmoi’s wife, [[Hanalinqû]]. As all the women of the Nonmen died, Cû’jara-Cinmoi realized the Inchoroi had betrayed him and called the Nonmen to war. The Nonmen and the Inchoroi met in battle on the [[Inniür-Shigogli]], the Black Furnace Plain. But the Inchoroi had learned much since the Battle of Pir Pahal; they now wielded [[Chorae]], [[Sranc]], [[Bashrag]]s, and [[Wracu]]. Though the Nonmen fought valiantly, Cû’jara-Cinmoi was slain, struck down by his old foe Nin’janjin. The remaining Nonmen went on to win the battle, then returned to their Mansions and awaited their inevitable doom.Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Cûno-Inchoroi Wars’ Cû’jara-Cinmoi was succeeded as High King by [[Nil’giccas]], who made [[qirri]] from his predecessor’s body.''The White-Luck Warrior,'' Chapter 9 ==References== [[Category:Kings]] [[Category:Cûnuroi]] [[Category:Characters from the Ancient North]]

The '''River Tywanrae''' is a major river system in north central [[Eärwa]], draining the [[Plains of Gâl|Gâl]] basin and emptying into the [[Cerish|Cerish Sea]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Tywanrae River’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Rivers]]

The '''Plains of Gâl''' are a great expanse of grasslands to the north of the [[Cerish|Cerish Sea]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Gâl, Plains of’</ref> In Far Antiquity, the Plains of Gâl were a part of the nation of [[Akksersia]].
The semi-nomadic [[Werigda]] people live here.
==Natural Features== * [[River Tywanrae]]
== See Also == Werigda
==References== <references /> [[Category:Plains]]

'''Khemema''' is a region of [[Kian]] and former province of the [[Nansur Empire]].
Located to the south of [[Shigek]], Khemema marks the point where the great [[Carathay Desert]] reaches the [[Meneanor|Meneanor Sea]]. Sparsely inhabited by [[Khirgwi]] desert tribesmen, Khemema’s only source of wealth derives from the regular trade caravans that travel between Shigek and [[Caraskand]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Khemema’</ref>
The Sapatishah-Governor of Khemema is [[Cuäxaji]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Cuäxaji’</ref>
==Natural Features== * [[Subis]] * [[Tamiznai]]
==Tribes== * [[Khirgwi]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Governorates]]

'''Nenciphon''' is the administrative capital of [[Kian]], and one of the great cities of the [[Three Seas]], founded by [[Fan'oukarji I]] in 3752.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Nenciphon’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

The '''River Naures''' is an important river system in eastern [[Nilnamesh]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Naures River’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Rivers]]

'''''The Annals of Cenei''''' is a classic treatise of [[Casidas]], covering the history of [[Cenei]] and the [[Ceneian Empire]] from the Imperial City’s legendary foundation in 809 to the time of Casidas’s death in 3142.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Annals of Cenei, The’</ref>
==Excerpts== “The difference between the strong emperor and the weak is simply this: the former makes the world his arena, while the latter makes it his harem.”<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before, Chapter 5</ref>
“That hope is little more than the premonition of regret. This is the first lesson of history.”<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 8</ref>
“Ever do [[Men]] use secrets to sort and measure those they love, which is why they are less honest with their brothers and more guarded with their friends.”<ref>''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 7</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Written works]]

'''Eshkalas''' is a palatinate of [[High Ainon]], famed for the quality of its cotton, located on the western edge of the [[Secharib Plains]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Eshkalas’</ref>
The Palatine of Eshkalas is [[Hirul Detnammi]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Detnammi, Hirul’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Palatinates]]

'''Eshganax''' is a palatinate of [[High Ainon]], located across the north [[Secharib Plains]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Eshganax’</ref>.
The Palatine of Eshganax at the time of the [[Holy War|First Holy War]] was [[Nisht Galgota]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Galgota, Nisht’</ref>. By the time of the [[Great Ordeal]], this title was held by [[Namogritti Chorgah]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Chorgah, Namogritti'</ref>.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Palatinates]]

{{Character infobox | name = Nincaerû-Telesser II | titles = God-King of the Ûmeri Empire | nicknames = | appearances = mentioned only | lived = 574 - 668 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Ûmeri Empire|Ûmeri]] | gender = Male | occupation = God-King of the Ûmeri Empire | relatives = [[Nincaerû-Telesser]] }}
'''Nincaerû-Telesser II''' was the fifth God-King of the [[Ûmeri Empire]], succeeding [[Nincaerû-Telesser]].
Among his notable achievements was turning the [[Library of Sauglish]] into the cultural heart of the [[Ancient North]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Great Library of Sauglish’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Characters from the Ûmeri Empire]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Kings]]

{{Character infobox | name = Diagol | titles = [[Shriah]] | nicknames = | appearances = mentioned only | lived = ? - 3383 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = | gender = Male | occupation = Shriah of the [[Thousand Temples]] | relatives = }}
'''Diagol''' was Shriah of the [[Thousand Temples]] from 3371 until his assassination in 3383.
Diagol was known for his cruel excesses, and his reign prompted the high clergy to issue the [[Writ of Psata-Antyu]] in 3386, limiting the power of future Shriahs.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Writ of Psata-Antyu’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Shriahs]] [[Category:Thousand Temples]] [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Characters from the Three Seas]]

'''Antanamera''' is a palatinate of [[High Ainon]], located on the highland frontier of [[Jekhia|Jekk]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Antanamera’</ref>.
Antanamera often proves itself the spine of High Ainon<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 23</ref>.
The Count-Palatine of Antanamera at the time of both the [[Holy War|First Holy War]] and the [[Great Ordeal]] was [[Musammu Chinjosa]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Chinjosa, Musammu’</ref><ref>''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 15</ref>.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Palatinates]]

'''Gekas''' is a palatinate of [[High Ainon]], located on the upper [[River Sayut]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Gekas’</ref>
The Count-Palatine of Gekas is [[Kusjeter]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kusjeter’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Palatinates]]

'''Gerotha''' is the administrative and commercial capital of [[Xerash]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Gerotha’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

'''Hinnant''' is a palatinate of [[High Ainon]], located in the heart of the [[Secharib Plains]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Hinnant’</ref>
The Count-Palatine of Hinnant is [[Sepherathindor]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Sepherathindor’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Palatinates]]

'''Koraphea''' is the most populous city of [[High Ainon]] after [[Carythusal]], located on the coast north of the [[River Sayut]] Delta.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Koraphea’</ref>
The Palatine-Governor of Koraphea is [[Sammu Zursodda]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Zursodda, Sammu’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

The '''''kipfa’aifan''''' (“Witness of Fane” in Kianni), is the holiest scripture of [[Fanimry]], chronicling the life and revelations of the Prophet [[Fane]] from his blinding and exile into the [[Great Salt]] in 3703 to his death in 3742.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ''‘kipfa’aifan’''</ref>
==Excerpts== 16:4:22: “… the ends of the earth shall be wracked by the howls of the wicked, and the idols shall be cast down and shattered, stone against stone. And the demons of the idolaters shall hold open their mouths, like starving lepers, for no man living will answer their outrageous hunger.”<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 12</ref>
8:9:4: “… for the sin of the idolater is not that he worships stone, but that he worships one stone over others.”<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 20</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Religious texts]]

'''''The Tractate''''' is the writings of [[Inri Sejenus]] and his disciples, forming the second part of the [[Inrithi]] scriptural canon.
The Inrithi believe ''The Tractate'' to be the prophesied culmination of ''[[The Chronicle of the Tusk]]'', an embodiment of the Covenant of [[Gods]] and [[Men]] for the realities of a new age. Among its seventeen books are various accounts of the life of the Latter Prophet, many parables for the purposes of moral instruction, and Inri Sejenus's own explanation of the "Intervention" he himself represents: that mankind, as it matures, will become more and more able to worship the God in His "singular multiplicity". Given that ''The Tractate'' was written more as a testament to the divinity of Inri Sejenus's vision than out of any real commitment to historical rigor, it is impossible to assess the veracity of the text. [[Zarathinius]] and, more recently, [[Fanim]] commentators have pointed out several glaring inconsistencies in the text, but nothing that Inrithi apologists have not been able to explain away<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 495, 'Tractate, The'</ref>.
==Excerpts== Scholars 36, 21: "...though he consorts with man, woman, and child, though he lays with beasts and makes a mockery of his seed, never shall he be as licentious as the philosopher, who lays with all things imaginable."<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 12, p. 334</ref>
Scholars 7:16: "For He sees gold in the wretched and excrement in the exalted. Nay, the world is not equal in the eyes of the God."<ref>''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 4, p. 85</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Religious texts]]
[[Category:In-universe]]
[[Category:People]]
[[Category:Metaphysics]]
[[Category:Culture]]
[[Category:Culture]]
[[Category:Culture]]
[[Category:Culture]]

page.title: A Defence of the Arcane Arts

revision.text:
'''''A Defence of the Arcane Arts''''' is the famed sorcerous apologia of [[Zarathinius]], which is as widely cited by philosophers as [[sorcerer]]s because of its pithy critiques not only of the [[Inrithism|Inrithi]] prohibition of [[sorcery]] but of Inrithism itself. The work has long been banned by the [[Thousand Temples]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ''‘Defence of the Arcane Arts, A’''</ref>
==Excerpts== “If the world is a game whose rules are written by [[God of Gods|God]], and sorcerers are those who cheat and cheat, then who has written the rules of sorcery?”<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before,'' Chapter 3</ref>
“If the Gods did not pretend to be human, [[Men]] would recoil from them as from spiders.”<ref>''The White-Luck Warrior,'' Chapter 10</ref>
“No two prophets agree. So to spare our prophets their feelings, we call the future a whore.”<ref>''The White-Luck Warrior,'' Chapter 11</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Written works]]

The '''Hinayati Mountains''' are a large system of mountain ranges located in southwestern [[Eärwa]], sometimes called “the spine of [[Nilnamesh]].”<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Hinayati Mountains’</ref> ==Features== * [[Ajowai]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Mountains]]

[[Image:Three_Seas.png|thumb|400px|The Three Seas of Eärwa.]]The '''Three Seas''' are, specifically, the Seas of [[Meneanor]], [[Nyranisas]], and [[Oncis]], located in south central [[Eärwa]].
More generally, the “Three Seas” refers to the (primarily [[Ketyai]]) civilization that has thrived in this region since the end of the [[Apocalypse]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Three Seas’</ref>
==The Three Seas== * [[Meneanor]] * [[Nyranisas]] * [[Oncis]]
==Ketyai Nations== * [[Cengemis]] * [[Cingulat]] * [[Cironj]] * [[Conriya]] * [[Girgash]] * [[High Ainon]] * [[Kian]] * [[Nansur Empire]] * [[Nilnamesh]] * [[Nron]] * [[Sansor]]
==Norsirai Nations== * [[Ce Tydonn]] * [[Cepalor]] * [[Galeoth]] * [[Thunyerus]]
==Xiuhianni Nations== * [[Jekhia]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Seas]] [[Category:Nations]]

[[Image:Three_Seas.png|thumb|400px|The Three Seas of Eärwa.]]The '''Oncis Sea''' is the westernmost of the [[Three Seas]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Oncis Sea’</ref>
==Rivers Emptying into the Oncis== * [[River Naures]] * [[River Saskri]] * [[River Sweki]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Seas]]

The '''River Jeshimal''' is the primary river system of [[Amoteu]], draining the [[Betmulla Mountains]] and emptying into the [[Meneanor|Meneanor Sea]] at [[Shimeh]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Jeshimal River’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Rivers]]

'''Sobel''' is an abandoned province north of [[Atrithau]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Sobel'</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Provinces]]

'''Plaideöl''' is a fiefdom of [[Ce Tydonn]], one of the Deep Marches above the eastern headwaters of the [[River Swa]]<ref name=":0" />.
Plaideölmen are famed for their ferocity in battle, and are easily distinguished by their great beards, which they never trim<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Plaideöl’</ref>.
The Earl of Plaideöl at the time of both the [[Holy War|First Holy War]] and the [[Great Ordeal]] was [[Rilding Werijen Greatheart]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Werijen Greatheart, Rilding’</ref><ref>''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 18</ref>.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Fiefdoms]]

'''Marsadda''' is the former capital of [[Cengemis]], located on the coast of [[Ce Tydonn]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Marsadda’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

'''Gaethuni''' is a fiefdom of [[Ce Tydonn]], located on the southwestern coasts.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Gaethuni’</ref>
The Earl of Gaethuni is [[Hargraum Kothwa]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kothwa, Hargraum’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Fiefdoms]]

'''Canute''' is a fiefdom of [[Ce Tydonn]], one of the so-called Deep Marches of the Upper [[River Swa]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Canute’</ref>.
The Earl of Canute at the time of the [[Holy War|First Holy War]] was [[Weofota Finaöl]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Finaöl, Weofota’</ref>. By the time of the [[Great Ordeal]], [[Hirengar]] held this title<ref>''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 7</ref>.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Fiefdoms]]
[[Category:Places]]

The '''Tertae Plains''' are the heavily cultured alluvial plains bordering northeast [[Caraskand]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 493, 'Tertae Plains'</ref>.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Plains]]

'''Ebara''' is a small fortress in the [[Gedea]]n interior, built by the [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] after the fall of [[Shigek]] to the [[Fanimry|Fanim]] in 3933.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ebara’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

{{Character infobox | name = Shikol | titles = King | nicknames = | appearances = mentioned only | lived = 2118 - 2202 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = [[Xerash]]i | gender = Male | occupation = King of Xerash | relatives = }}
'''Shikol''' was the King of ancient [[Xerash]], famed for sentencing [[Inri Sejenus]] to death in 2198, as recounted in ''[[The Tractate]]''.
For obvious reasons, Shikol's name has become synonymous with moral corruption among the [[Inrithi]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Shikol'</ref> His instrument of judgement, a gilded thighbone, is the most potent symbol of evil in Inrithism.<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 22</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Characters from Xerash]] [[Category:Kings]] [[Category:Men]]

The '''''Third Analytic of Men''''' is a work by [[Ajencis]], regarded by many to be his magnum opus.
The ''Third Analytic'' interrogates the aspects of human nature that make knowledge possible, as well as the human weaknesses that make knowledge so difficult to attain. As Ajencis notes, "if all [[Men]] disagree on all matters, then most Men confuse deception for truth". He investigates the reasons, not only for deception in general, but for the erroneous sense of conviction that sustains it, giving what has come to be called the "selfish knower" thesis, the idea that convenience, conditioning, and appeal (as opposed to evidence and rational argumentation) are the primary motivation for the beliefs of the vast majority<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 493, 'Third Analytic of Men, The'</ref>.
==Excerpts==
"If it is only after that we understand what has come before, then we understand nothing. Thus we shall define the soul as follows: that which precedes everything."<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Prologue, p. 1</ref>
"The world is a circle that possesses as many centers as it does men."<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 7, p. 194</ref>
"The proposition "I am the center" need never be uttered. It is the assumption upon which all certainty and all doubt turns."<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 3, p. 41</ref>
"One can look into the future, or one can look at the future. The latter is by far the more instructive."<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 9, p. 186</ref>
"Love is lust made meaningful. Hope is hunger made human."<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 10, p. 202</ref>
"What is the meaning of a deluded life?"<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 25, p. 588</ref>
"Death, in the strict sense, cannot be defined, for whatever predicate we, the living, attribute to it necessarily belongs to Life. This means that Death, as a category, behaves in a manner indistinguishable from the Infinite, and from [[God]]."<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 12, p. 240</ref>
"When a man possesses the innocence of a child, we call him a fool. When a child possesses the cunning of a man, we call him an abomination. As with love, knowledge has its season."<ref>''The Judging Eye'', Prologue, p. 3</ref>
"The world is only as deep as we can see. This is why fools think themselves profound. This is why terror is the passion of revelation."<ref>''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 14, p. 296</ref>
"It is not so much the wisdom of the wise that saves us from the foolishness of the fools as it is the latter's inability to agree."<ref>''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 2, p. 37</ref>
"Everything is concealed always. Nothing is more trite than a mask."<ref>''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 6, p. 152</ref>
"Complexity begets ambiguity, which yields in all ways to prejudice and avarice. Complication does not so much defeat Men as arm them with fancy."<ref>''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 8, p. 227</ref>
"Gods are epochal beings, not quite alive. Since the Now eludes them, they are forever divided. Sometimes nothing blinds souls more profoundly than the apprehension of the Whole. Men need recall this when they pray."<ref>''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 13, p. 443</ref>
"Any fool can see the limits of seeing, but not even the wisest know the limits of knowing. Thus is ignorance rendered invisible, and are all Men made fools."<ref>''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 14, p. 497</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Written works]]

'''''The Fourth Analytic of Men''''', also known as the ''Book of Maxims'', is one of the more famous works of [[Ajencis]].
The ''Fourth Analytic'' contains several hundred not-so-flattering "Observations of Men", and the corresponding maxim outlining the practical way to deal with each of the [[Men]] so observed.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Fourth Analytic of Men, The'</ref>
==Excerpts==
"Faith is the truth of passion. Since no passion is more true than another, faith is the truth of nothing."<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 15</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Written works]]

'''''The Epistemologies''''' is a work oft attributed to [[Ajencis]] but more likely a redacted compilation drawn from his other works.
Many consider ''The Epistemologies'' to be Ajencis's definitive philosophical statement on the nature of knowledge, but some argue that it distorts his position since it presents a unitary vision of views that actually evolved quite dramatically over the course of his life.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Epistemologies, The'</ref>
==Extracts==
"To be ignorant and to be deceived are two different things. To be ignorant is to be a slave of the world. To be deceived is to be the slave of another man. The question will always be: Why, when all men are ignorant, and therefore already slaves, does this latter slavery sting us so?"<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 4</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Written works]]

'''Warnute''' is a fiefdom of [[Ce Tydonn]], one of the so-called Deep Marches of the upper [[River Swa]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Warnute’</ref>
The Earl of Warnute is [[Sheorog Cerjulla]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Cerjulla, Sheorog’</ref>
