==References== <references /> [[Category:Fiefdoms]]

'''Dayrut''' is a small fortress in the [[Gedea]]n interior, built by the [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] after the fall of [[Shigek]] to the [[Fanimry|Fanim]] in 3933.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Dayrut’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

The '''Unaras Spur''' is a low mountain range that extends from the southern terminus of the [[Hethanta Mountains]] to the [[Meneanor|Meneanor Sea]] coast, marking the geographical frontier between the [[Kyranae Plains]] and [[Gedea]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Unaras Spur’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Mountains]]

The '''Great Ocean''' is the ocean to the west of [[Eärwa]], largely uncharted beyond the coastline, though some claim the [[Zeüm]]i have mapped its extent.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Great Ocean'</ref>
Given the lack of any other extant nation along the coast of the Great Ocean, maritime trade and travel along the far western coasts is not commonplace (aside from that within Zeüm itself). Zeüm trades with the nations of the [[Three Seas]] through its southern ports and the straits separating the Ocean from the [[Oncis|Sea of Oncis]]. The only major use of the Great Ocean for a military campaign was during the [[Cûno-Inchoroi Wars]], when the [[Nonman]] [[Mansion]] of [[Illisserû]] assaulted the [[Incû-Holoinas]] by sea. The attack was not successful, with most of the invading force destroyed in the [[Battle of Imogirion]]. The remnants of the fleet were sunk on the way back to the Three Seas by storms, demonstrating the dangers of entrusting any major military campaign to the vagaries of the weather.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Battle of Imogirion'</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Seas]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/2601:85:4401:2ED4:E11D:C2BB:BAD6:AD63|2601:85:4401:2ED4:E11D:C2BB:BAD6:AD63]] ([[User talk:2601:85:4401:2ED4:E11D:C2BB:BAD6:AD63|talk]]) to last version by Neorem
revision.text:
Jhunsae is a long-abandoned [[Ceneian]] fortress located on the [[Gedea]]n coast.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Gunsae'</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

The '''Osthwai Mountains''' are a major mountain range located in central [[Eärwa]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Osthwai Mountains’</ref>
==Natural Features== * [[Aenaratiol]]
==Structures== * [[Cil-Aujas]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Mountains]]

'''Hinnereth''' is the administrative and commercial capital of [[Gedea]], located on the [[Meneanor|Meneanor Sea]] coast.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Hinnereth’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

'''''The Sagas''''' is a collection of epic lays that recount the [[Apocalypse]]. It primarily consists of "The Kelmariad", the story of [[Anasûrimbor Celmomas II]] and his tragic Ordeal; "The Kayûtiad", the account of Celmomas's son, [[Anasûrimbor Nau-Cayûti]], and his heroic exploits; "The Book of Generals", the story of the deceptive events following Nau-Cayûti's murder; "The Trisiad", which recounts the great city of [[Trysë]]'s destruction; "The Eämnoriad", the story of ancient [[Atrithau]]'s expulsion of [[Seswatha]] and subsequent survival; "The Annals of Akksersa", which recounts the Fall of [[Akksersia]]; and lastly, "The Annal Sakarpa", or "The Refugee's Song" as it is sometimes called, the strange account of the city of [[Sakarpus]] during the Apocalypse. Despite the scorn of [[Mandate]] scholars (or perhaps because of it), ''The Sagas'' possess an almost scriptural reputation in the [[Three Seas]].{{EG|Sagas, The}} A number of different authors contributed to the ''Sagas'', but only two are named: [[Heyorthau]] and [[Nau-Ganor]].{{3|8}} ==Excerpts== On the [[Mengedda Plains]]: "The soul that encounters [[No-God|Him]] passes no further."{{EG|[The] soul that encounters Him passes no further}} A warring we have come
A reaving we shall work.
And when the day is done,
In our eyes the Gods shall lurk!{{2|6}} Rage -- Goddess! Sing of your flight
From our fathers and our sons.
Away, Goddess! Secret your divinity!
From the conceit that makes kings of fools,
From the scrutiny that makes corpses of souls.
Mouths open, arms thrown wide, we beseech thee:
Sing us the end of your song.{{3|8}} On the birth of Anasûrimbor Celmomas II: "His rosy wail could not stir [[Anasûrimbor Huörmomas|his brother]]'s blue slumber."{{3|8}} Grim kinsman, frosting the breath of his every counsel.
Dark reflection! Even the Knight-Chieftans bundle their cloaks
When they catch your glint in their Lord's eye.{{3|8}} The pyres gutted, the towers fallen and black,
The foeman glutted, our glory slung 'cross his back,
The world's keel broken, our blood thinner than our tears.
The story spoken, as though the dead possessed ears.{{3|8}} ==References== [[Category:Written works]]

[[File:Thunyerus.png|thumb|400px|Thunyerus in 4109.]]'''Thunyerus''' is a [[Norsirai]] nation of the [[Three Seas]] located on the northeastern coasts of the [[Meneanor|Meneanor Sea]].
According in Thunyeri legend, their peoples migrated down the length of the [[River Wernma]], continually pressured by the [[Sranc]] tribes that largely rule the great forests of the [[Dameöri Wilderness]]. For two hundred years the Thunyeri plied the Three Seas as pirates and raiders. Then, in 3987, after three generations of [[Inrithism|Inrithi]] missionaries had largely converted them from their traditional [[Kiünnat]] beliefs, the tribes elected their first King, [[Hringa Hurrausch]], and began adopting the institutions of their Three Seas neighbours.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Thunyerus’</ref>
Thunyeri are typically described as having long beards.
==Fiefdoms== * [[Ingraul]] * [[Skagwa]]
==Structures== * [[Cern Auglai]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Nations]]

{{Character infobox | name = Memgowa | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Thousandfold Thought]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Judging Eye]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The White-Luck Warrior]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Great Ordeal]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned) | lived = 2466 - 2506 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Satyothi]] | nationality = [[Zeüm]]i | gender = Male | occupation = Philosopher | relatives = }} '''Memgowa''' was a famed near antique [[Zeüm]]i sage and philosopher, primarily known in the [[Three Seas]] for his ''[[Celestial Aphorisms]]'' and ''[[The Book of Divine Acts]]''Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Memgowa’. ==References== [[Category:Writers]] [[Category:Philosophers]] [[Category:Characters from Zeüm]] [[Category:Satyothi]] [[Category:Men]]

The '''Araxes Mountains''' are a range forming the eastern frontiers of both [[Ce Tydonn]] and [[Conriya]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Araxes Mountains’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Mountains]]

'''Dakyas''' is a semi-mountainous district of [[Nilnamesh]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Dakyas’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Provinces]]

The '''River Wutmouth''' is the immense river joining [[Huösi|Lake Huösi]] to the [[Meneanor|Meneanor Sea]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Wutmouth River’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Rivers]]

page.title: The Book of Circles and Spirals

revision.text:
'''''The Book of Circles and Spirals''''' is the magnum opus of [[Sorainas]], providing an entertaining blend of philosophical commentary and religious aphorism.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Book of Circles and Spirals, The’</ref>
==Excerpts== “Sleep, when deep enough, is indistinguishable from vigilance.”<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 7</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Written works]]

'''''The Book of Divine Acts''''' is the magnum opus of [[Memgowa]], the famed [[Zeüm]]i sage and philosopher. Though not as commonly read or copied as his ''[[Celestial Aphorisms]],'' most scholars consider it a vastly superior work.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Book of Divine Acts, The’</ref>
==Excerpts== “If all human events possess purpose, then all human deeds possess purpose. And yet when men vie with men, the purpose of no man comes to fruition: the result always falls somewhere in between. The purpose of deeds, then, cannot derive from the purposes of men, because all men vie with all men. This means the deeds of men must be willed by something other than men. From this it follows that we are all slaves. Who then is our Master?”<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 11</ref>
“The vulgar think the [[God of Gods|God]] by analogy to man and so worship Him in the form of the [[Gods]]. The learned think the God by analogy to principles and so worshp Him in the form of Love or Truth. But the wise think the God not at all. They know that thought, which is finite, can only do violence to the God, who is infinite.”<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 20</ref>
“In life, your soul is but the extension of your body, which reaches inwards until it finds its centre in spirit. In death, your body is but the extension of your soul, which reaches outward until it finds its circumference in flesh. In both instances, all things appear the same. Thus are the dead and the living confused.”<ref>''The White-Luck Warrior,'' Chapter 15</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Written works]]

'''Anwurat''' is a large [[Kian]]ene fortress to the south of the [[River Sempis]] Delta, constructed in 3905.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Anwurat’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

'''Chianadyni''' is a governorate of [[Kian]] and one-time tributary of the [[Nansur Empire]].
Located to the west of [[Eumarna]] and east of [[Nilnamesh]] Chianadyni is the traditional homeland of the Kianene and, after Eumarna, the wealthiest and most populous governorate in Kian<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 426, 'Chianadyni'</ref>.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Governorates]]

'''Ankirioth''' is a palatinate of south central [[Conriya]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ankirioth’</ref>
The Palatine of Ankirioth is [[Amurrei Ganyatti]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ganyatti, Amurrei’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Palatinates]]

'''Sansor''' is a nation of the [[Three Seas]] tributary to [[High Ainon]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Sansor’</ref>
Sansor is one of the four successor nations to the [[Shiradi Empire]], the other three being [[Cengemis]], [[Conriya]], and High Ainon.<ref> Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Conriya’</ref>
The Tributary Prince of Sansor is [[Ram-Sassor Garsahadutha]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Garsahadutha, Ram-Sassor’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Nations]]

'''Anplei''' is the second-largest city in [[Conriya]] after [[Aöknyssus]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Anplei’</ref> located in homonymous palatinate [[Anplei]].
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

'''Kethantei''' is a palatinate located in south central [[Conriya]], noted for its wine and fruit production<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kethantei’</ref>.
The Palatine of Kethantei at the time of the [[Holy War|First Holy War]] was [[Sristai Ingiaban]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ingiaban, Sristai’</ref>. He was succeeded by his son, [[Sristai Croimas]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Croimas, Sristai'</ref>.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Palatinates]]

'''Kishyat''' is a palatinate of [[High Ainon]], located on the south bank of the [[River Sayut]] on the [[Sansor]]i frontier.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kishyat’</ref>
The Palatine of Kishyat is [[Nurbanu Soter]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Soter, Nurbanu’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Palatinates]]

The '''Kuöti''' are a [[Scylvendi]] tribe of the northwestern [[Jiünati Steppe]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kuöti’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Tribes]]

The '''Pulit''' are a tribe of [[Scylvendi]] from the southern desert fringes of the [[Jiünati Steppe]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Pulit’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Tribes]]

'''Kurrut''' is a small fortress in the [[Gedea]]n interior built by the [[Nansur]] after the fall of [[Shigek]] to the [[Fanim]] in 3933.{{EG|Kurrut}}
==References== <references/> [[Category:Structures]]

The '''Nymbricani''' are a tribe of [[Norsirai]] pastoralists who range southern [[Cepalor]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Nymbricani’</ref>
==Members of the Nymbricani== * [[Ingaera]] * [[Serwë]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Tribes]]

'''Kerioth''' is a major port city on the south coast of [[Eumarna]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kerioth’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

'''''Celestial Aphorisms''''' is one of the philosopher [[Memgowa]]'s most celebrated texts<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 423, 'Celestial Aphorisms'</ref>.
==Excerpts==
"Souls can no more see the origins of their thought than they can see the backs of their heads or the insides of their entrails. And since souls cannot differentiate what they cannot see, there is a peculiar sense in which the soul cannot self-differentiate. So it is always, in a peculiar sense, the same time when they think, the same place where they think, and the same individual who does the thinking. Like tipping a spiral on its side until only a circle can be seen, the passage of moments always remains now, the carnival of spaces always sojourns here, and the succession of people always becomes me. The truth is, if the soul could apprehend itself the way it apprehended the world -- if it could apprehend its origins -- it would see that there is no now, there is no here, and there is no me. In other words, it would realize that just as there is no circle, there is no soul."<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 10, p. 198</ref>
"If the immutable appears recast, then you yourself have been transformed."<ref>''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 15, p. 344</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Written works]]

'''Mongilea''' is a governorate of [[Kian]] and former province of the [[Nansur Empire]], located along the coasts adjacent to the [[River Sweki]].
Long a tributary land, Mongilea has exchanged masters many times. As the original conquest of [[Fan’oukarji I]] (3759), it has become the “Green Homeland” of the Kianene, and a famed producer of horses.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Mongilea’</ref>
The Prince of Mongilea is [[Hûkal]].<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought,'' Chapter 15</ref>
==Cities== * [[Mamot]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Governorates]]

'''Mohaïva''' is a district of [[Nilnamesh]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Mohaïva’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Provinces]]

'''Moraör''' (“Hall of Kings” in Old Meöric), is the famed palace complex of [[Galeoth]]’s rulers, located in [[Oswenta]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Moraör’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

revision.comment: Added Description, edited character info box and grammar.
revision.text:
{{Character infobox | name = Skuthula | titles = | nicknames = The Black, Scourge of Ages | appearances = [[The Unholy Consult]] | lived = ? - present | race = [[Wracu]] | ethnicity = | nationality = | gender = Male | occupation = | relatives = |image=|caption1=}} [[File:Skuthula & Mirshoa .png|thumb|220x220px]] '''Skuthula the Black''' is an ancient [[Wracu]] spawned during the [[Cûno-Inchoroi Wars]], one of the few Dragons known to have survived the [[Apocalypse|Apocalypse.]] He is described as "magnificent."''Encyclopaedic Glossary, 'Skuthula''' In ''[[The Unholy Consult]]'', he is found during the battle for [[Golgotterath]] guarding the [[Intrinsic Gate]] where he battles the [[Witch]] [[Anasûrimbor Serwa]]. Although he is buried under tons of rubble, his fate is ultimately uncertain.''The Unholy Consult, ''Chapter 18 == Description == The most serpentine of the Wracu, Skuthula's monstrous body consists mainly of spine and ribs with dozens of spindly legs along his underside. His legs move like that of a centipede. He is skinned in black scales that are about the size of Norsirai shields which reflect and shatter light like mirrors. Spear-long quills form a mane along the back of his neck, and a crest of white spines form a thicket about his crown.
==References== [[Category:Wracu]] [[Category:Characters from Golgotterath]]

{{Character infobox | name = Tanhafut | titles = | nicknames = The Red | appearances = mentioned only | lived = ? - 2137 | race = [[Wracu]] | ethnicity = | nationality = | gender = Male | occupation = | relatives = }}
'''Tanhafut the Red''' was an ancient [[Wracu]].
He was killed by [[Anasûrimbor Nau-Cayûti]] in 2137 at the [[Battle of Ossirish]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Apocalypse'</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Wracu]] [[Category:Characters from Golgotterath]]

The '''Writ of Psata-Antyu''' is a proclamation issued by the high clergy of the [[Thousand Temples]] at the Council of Antyu (3386) that limits the power of the Shriah.
The Writ was motivated by the cruel excesses of Shriah [[Diagol]], who held the Seat from 3371 until his assassination in 3383<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 500, 'Writ of Psata-Antyu'</ref>.
==Dictates==
The writ forbids laughing aloud as a carnal indulgence<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 9, p. 193</ref>.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Religious texts]] [[Category:Written works]]

'''Eänna''' (“[Land of the] Uplifted Sun” in Thoti-Eännorean), is the traditional name of all lands to the east of the [[Great Kayarsus]]. It is possible that it is a separate continent entirely to [[Earwa]], but this has never been specified.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Eänna’</ref>
==References== <references />[[Category:Continents]]
#redirect [[Eänna]]

The '''Ennutil''' are a [[Scylvendi]] tribe of the northwestern [[Jiünati Steppe]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ennutil’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Tribes]]

The '''Khirgwi''' are the tribesmen of the eastern [[Carathay Desert]], tributary to the [[Kian]]ene but ethnically distinct.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Khirgwi’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Tribes]]

'''''44 Epistles''''' is the magnum opus of [[Ekyannus I]], consisting of fourty-four “letters” written to the [[God of Gods|God]], including commentary and confession as well as philosophical inquiry and critique.Encyclopedic Glossary, ''‘44 Epistles’'' ==Excerpts== “Reason, [[Ajencis]] writes, is the capacity to overcome unprecedented obstacles in the gratification of desire. What distinguishes man from beasts is man’s capacity to overcome infinite obstacles through reason.
But Ajencis has confused the accidental for the essential. Prior to the capacity to ''overcome'' infinite obstacles is the capacity to ''confront'' them. What defines man is not that he reasons, but that he ''prays.''”''The Darkness That Comes Before,'' Chapter 11 “Duty measures the distance between the animal and the divine.”''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 2 “If soot stains your tunic, dye it black. This is vengeance.”''The Thousandfold Thought,'' Chapter 3 “Ask the dead and they will tell you.
All roads are not equal.
Verily, even maps can sin.”''The Judging Eye,'' Chapter 6 “There is morality and there is cowardice. The two are not to be confused, even though in appearance and effect they are so often the same.”''The White-Luck Warrior,'' Chapter 10 ==References== [[Category:Written works]]

'''''111 Aphorisms''''' is a minor work of [[Ekyannus VIII]], consisting of 111 aphorisms that primarily deal with matters of faith and integrity.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ''‘111 Aphorisms’''</ref>
==Excerpts== “Some say men continually war against circumstances, but I say they perpetually flee. What are the works of men if not a momentary respite, a hiding place soon to be discovered by catastrophe? Life is endless flight before the hunter we call the world.”<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before,'' Chapter 14</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Written works]]

'''''The Trucian Dramas''''' are the magnum opus of [[Xius]], a near antique poet and playwright<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 496, 'Trucian Dramas, The'</ref>
==Excerpts==
"No decision is so fine as to not bind us to its consequences. No consequence is so unexpected as to absolve us of our decisions. Not even death."<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 4, p. 73</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Written works]]

'''''Journals and Dialogues''''' is the collected writings of [[Triamis the Great]], greatest of the [[Ceneian]] Aspect-Emperors<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 456, 'Journals and Dialogues'</ref>.
==Excerpts==
"Why must I conquer, you ask? War makes clear. Life or Death. Freedom or Bondage. War strikes the sediment from the water of life."<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 5, p. 101</ref>
"What is practicality but one moment betrayed for the next?"<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 11, p. 228</ref>
"...and my soldiers, they say, make idols of their swords. But does not the sword make certain? Does not the sword make plain? Does not the sword compel kindness from those who kneel in its shadow? I need no other god."<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 19, p. 410</ref>
"I returned from that campaign a far different man, or so my mother continuously complained. "Now only the dead," she would tell me, "can hope to match your gaze.""<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought, Chapter 4, p. 69</ref>
"If war does not kill the woman in us, it kills the man."<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 15, p. 303</ref>
"...conquered peoples live and die with the knowledge that survival does not suffer honor. They have chosen shame over the pyre, the slow flame for the quick."<ref>''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 7, p. 162</ref>
"A beggar's mistake harms no one but the beggar. A king's mistake, however, harms everyone but the king. Too often, the measure of power lies not in the number who obey your will, but in the number who suffer your stupidity."<ref>''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 9, p. 208</ref>
"The bondage we are born into is the bondage we cannot see. Verily, freedom is little more than the ignorance of tyranny. Live long enough, and you will see: Men resent not the whip so much as the hand that wields it."<ref>''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 3, p. 56</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Written works]]

'''''The Psûkalogues''''' are the magnum opus of [[Imparrhas]], [[sorcerer]] of the [[Imperial Saik]] and esoteric metaphysician primarily interested in the [[Psûkhe]] of the [[Cishaurim]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Psûkalogues, The'</ref>
==Excerpts==
"Every monumental work of the State is measured by cubits. Every cubit is measured by the length of the Aspect-Emperor's arm. And the Aspect-Emperor's arm, they say, stands beyond measure. But I say the Aspect-Emperor's arm is measured by the length of a cubit, and that all cubits are measured by the works of the State. Not even the All stands beyond measure, for it is more than what lies within it, and "more" is a kind of measure. Even the [[God]] has His cubits."<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 8</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Written works]]

'''''The Imprompta''''' is an anonymously-written collection of [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]]'s earliest sermons and aphorisms during the [[Holy War]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 452, 'Impromta, The'</ref>
==Excerpts==
"How does one learn innocence? How does one teach ignorance? For to be them it to know them not. And yet they are the immovable point from which the compass of life swings, the measure of all crime and compassion, the rule of all wisdom and folly. They are the Absolute."<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 10, p. 202</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Written works]]

'''''The Goat's Heart''''' is a famed book of fables by [[Protathis]].Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Goat's Heart, The' ==Excerpts== "Where the holy take men for fools, the mad take the world."''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 15 "A soul too far wandered from the sun,
walking deeper ways,
into regions beneath map and nation,
breathing air drawn for the dead,
talking of lamentation."''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 16 ==References== [[Category:Written works]]

'''''On the Carnal''''' is the most famous of [[Opparitha]]'s exhortary works, popular among lay readers though widely derided by [[Three Seas]] intellectuals<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 475, 'On the Carnal'</ref>.
==Excerpts==
"Men never resemble one another so much as when asleep or dead."<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 16, p. 342</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Written works]]

'''''Triamis Imperator''''' is a famed drama by [[Throseanis]], based on events in the life of [[Triamis the Great]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 495</ref>.
==Excerpts==
"In terror, all men throw up their hands and turn aside their faces. Remember, Tratta, always preserve the face! For that is where you are."<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 17, p. 364</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Written works]]
#redirect [[Avowels]]
#redirect [[The Goat's Heart]]

'''''The City of Men''''' is a famous work by [[Teres Ansansius]], the most famous theologian of the early [[Thousand Temples]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 411, 'Ansansius, Teres'</ref>.
==Excerpts==
"The Poet will yield up his stylus only when the Geometer can explain how Life can at once be a point and a line. How can all time, all creation, come to the now? Make no mistake: this moment, the instant of this very breath, is the frail thread from which all creation hangs. That men dare to be thoughtless..."<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 17, p. 364</ref>.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Written works]]

'''''Tempiras the King''''' is a work widely thought to be the greatest of [[Hamishaza]]’s satiric tragedies.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ''‘Tempiras the King’''</ref>
==Excerpts== “What vengeance is this? That he should slumber while I endure? Blood douses no hatred, cleanses no sin. Like seed, it spills of its own volition, and leaves naught but sorrow in its wake.”<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 19</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Written works]]

'''''Ruminations''''' is the magnum opus of [[Stajanas II]], the so-called “Philosopher-Emperor” who ruled [[Cenei]] from 2412 to 2431 ([[Year-of-the-Tusk]]).{{EG|''Ruminations''}}There is a contradiction in the text: according to the entry 'Stajanas II', he lived from 2338 to 2395, whereas under ‘''Ruminations''’, he ruled from 2412 to 2431. ==Excerpt== {{Blockquote|Like many old tyrants, I dote upon my grandchildren. I delight in their tantrums, their squealing laughter, their peculiar fancies. I willfully spoil them with honey sticks. And I find myself wondering at their blessed ignorance of the world and its million grinning teeth. Should I, like my grandfather, knock such childishness from them? Or should I indulge their delusions? Even now, as death’s shadowy pickets gather about me, I ask, why should innocence answer to the world? Perhaps the world should answer to innocence...
Yes, I rather like that. I tire of bearing the blame.|Stajanas II, ''Ruminations''{{2|22}}}} ==Notes== ==References== [[Category:Written works]]

'''''Exhortations''''' is the sole surviving work of [[Hatatian]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Exhortations'</ref>
''Exhortations'' is a work that eschews traditional [[Inrithi]] values and espouses an ethos of unprincipled self-promotion. Though long censured by the [[Thousand Temples]], it remains popular among the [[caste]]-nobility of the [[Three Seas]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Hatatian'</ref>
==Excerpts==
"I tell you, guilt dwells nowhere but in the eyes of the accuser. This men know even as they deny it, which is why they so often make murder their absolution. The truth of crime lies not with the victim but with the witness."<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 2</ref>
"When others speak, I hear naught but the squawking of parrots. But when I speak, it always seems to be the first time. Each man is the rule of the other, no matter how mad or vain."<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 5</ref>
"One cannot assume the truth of what one declares without presuming the falsity of all incongruous declarations. Since all men assume the truth of their own declarations, this presumption becomes at best ironic and at worst outrageous. Given the infinity of possible claims, who could be so vain as to think their dismal claims true? The tragedy, of course, is that we cannot but make declarations. So it seems we must speak as [[God]]s to converse as [[Men]]."<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 12</ref>
"We belittle what we cannot bear. We make figments out of fundamentals, all in the name of preserving our own peculiar fancies. The best way to secure one's own deception is to accuse others of deceit."<ref>''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 2</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Written works]]

'''''Discourse on War''''' is a work by the famed philosopher [[Ajencis]].
==Excerpts== “Here we find further argument for [[Gotagga]]’s supposition that the world is round. How else could all men stand higher than their brothers?”<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 3</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Written works]]

'''''One Hundred Heavens''''' is a work by the near antique poet [[Protathis]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Protathis'</ref>
==Excerpts==
"Like a stern father, war shames men into hating their childhood games."<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 4</ref>
"A return to a place never seen. Always is it thus, when we understand what we cannot speak."<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 13</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Written works]]

'''''Theophysics''''' is a work by the famous philosopher [[Ajencis]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ajencis’</ref>
==Excerpts==
{{Blockquote|Where two reasons may deliver truth, a thousand lead to certain delusion. The more steps you take, the more likely you will wander astray.<ref>''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 11</ref>}}
==References== <references /> [[Category:Written works]]

{{Character infobox | name = Stajanas II | titles = Emperor of [[Cenei]] | nicknames = The Philsopher-Emperor<ref name="nm" group="Notes">His name is spelled 'Stajanas II' in the entry of the same name, and 'Stajanus II' in the entry ‘''Ruminations''’.</ref> | appearances = ''[[The Warrior Prophet]]'' (mentioned) | lived = 2338 - 2395<ref name="age" group="Notes">There is a contradiction in the text: according to the entry 'Stajanas II', he lived from 2338 to 2395, whereas under ‘''Ruminations''’, he ruled from 2412 to 2431.</ref> | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Ketyai]] | nationality = [[Ceneian]] | gender = Male | occupation = Emperor | relatives = }}
'''Stajanas II''' was the famed “Philospher-Emperor” of [[Cenei]], who ruled from 2412 to 2431 ([[Year-of-the-Tusk]]). His ''[[Ruminations]]'' has remained an important work in [[Three Seas]] literary canon.{{EG|Stajanas II}}{{EG|''Ruminations''}}<ref name="nm" group="Notes" /><ref name="age" group="Notes" />
==Notes== <references group="Notes" />
==References== <references/> [[Category:Characters from the Ceneian Empire]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Philosophers]] [[Category:Writers]] [[Category:Emperors]]

{{Character infobox | name = Gotagga | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = mentioned only | lived = 687 - 735 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Ûmeri Empire|Ûmeri]] | gender = Male | occupation = [[Sorcerer]] | relatives = }}
'''Gotagga''' was a great [[Ûmeri Empire|Ûmeri]] [[sorcerer]] credited with the birth of philosophy apart from what had been purely theological speculation. According to [[Ajencis]], [[Men]] explained the world with characters and stories before Gotagga and with principles and observations after.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Gotagga’</ref>
==Works== * ''[[Parapolis]]'' * ''[[The Prima Arcanata]]''
==References== <references /> [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Characters from the Ûmeri Empire]] [[Category:Sorcerers]]
#redirect [[Apocalypse]]

{{Character infobox | name = Zerxei Triamarius III | titles = Emperor of Nansur | nicknames = | appearances = mentioned only | lived = 3588 - 3619 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Ketyai]] | nationality = [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] | gender = Male | occupation = Emperor of Nansur | relatives = [[Zerxei Triamarius I]] }}
'''Zerxei Triamarius III''' was the last of the [[House Zerxei|Zerxei]] Emperors of [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]], murdered by palace eunuchs.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Triamarius III’</ref>
Triamarius is said to have been so fat that he needed slaves to brace his knees when he rode his horse.<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 9</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Characters from Nansur]] [[Category:Emperors]] [[Category:Ketyai]]

{{Character infobox | name = Sirwitta | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = mentioned only | lived = ? - ? | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Emwama]] | nationality = | gender = Male | occupation = Member of the Second Watch | relatives = [[Cimoira]] (daughter) }}
'''Sirwitta''' is a criminal mentioned in the ''[[Isûphiryas]]''.
Sirwitta seduced the wife of a high-ranking [[Ishroi]] and conceived by her a daughter named [[Cimoira]]. It was the first recorded instance of interbreeding between [[Men]] and [[Nonmen]]. The truth of Cimoira was suppressed, and despite her mannish blood she was accepted as Cûnuroi. Sirwitta himself was banished to the Second Watch, which stood guard over the [[Incû-Holoinas]].
Somehow (the ''Isûphiryas'' does not go into detail) Sirwitta managed to enter the Incû-Holoinas. A month passed, and all thought him lost. Then he reappeared, deranged, screeching claims so alarming that [[Oirinas]] and [[Oirûnas]] brought him directly to [[Cû’jara-Cinmoi]]. What was said between Sirwitta and the High King of [[Siöl]] is not recorded. The chroniclers say only that Cû’jara-Cinmoi, after hearing Sirwitta speak, ordered him put to death. A later entry, however, describes Sirwitta as "tongueless and imprisoned". It appears the High King, for some unknown reason, had rescinded his warrant.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Cûno-Inchoroi Wars'</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Characters from the Ancient North]] [[Category:Emwama]]

page.title: Compendium of the First Holy War

revision.text:
{{Character infobox | name = Skafra | titles = | nicknames = Tyrant of Cloud and Mountain | appearances = ''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]'' (flashbacks only) ''[[The Judging Eye]]'' (flashbacks only) | lived = ? - 2155 | race = [[Wracu]] | ethnicity = | nationality = | gender = Male | occupation = | relatives = }}
'''Skafra''' was one of the principle [[Wracu]], or Dragons, of the [[Apocalypse]], finally slain by [[Seswatha]] at [[Mengedda]] in 2155.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Skafra'</ref> He is described as "ancient."
==Appearance==
Skafra had iridescent black scales. His hide was scarred from a thousand battles.He wore a necklace of human heads.<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 1</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Wracu]] [[Category:Characters from Golgotterath]]

{{Character infobox | name = Surmante Xatantius I | titles = Emperor | nicknames = | appearances = mentioned only | lived = 3644 - 3693 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = [[Nansur]] | gender = Male | occupation = Emperor of Nansur | relatives = [[Surmante Skilura II]]
[[Surmante Caphrianus I]] }} '''Surmante Xatantius I''' was the most warlike of the Surmante Emperors of [[Nansur]]. Xatantius enlarged the Nansur Empire to its greatest extent, pacifying the [[Norsirai]] tribes of the [[Cepalor]] and for a time even managing to hold the far southern city of [[Invishi]] (though he failed to entirely subdue the [[Nilnamesh]]i countryside). Despite his military successes, his continual wars exhausted both the Nansur people and the Imperial Treasury, inadvertently laying the groundwork for the disastrous wars against the [[Kian]]ene following his death.Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Xatantius I' ==References== [[Category:Emperors]] [[Category:Characters from Nansur]] [[Category:Ketyai]]

'''Misarat''' is an immense [[Kian]]ene fortress located in [[Eshgarnea]] on the northwestern frontier of [[Eumarna]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Misarat’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

'''Moserothu''' is an [[High Ainon|Ainon]]i city located in the heart of the populous [[Secharib Plains]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Moserothu’</ref>.
The Palatine-Governor of Moserothu at the time of the [[Holy War|First Holy War]] was [[Sirpal Uranyanka]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Uranyanka, Sirpal’</ref>. He was suceeded by [[Sirpal Onyarapû]]<ref>''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 5</ref>.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

{{Battle infobox | name = Fourth Battle of Mengedda | partof = [[Holy War]] | date = 4110 | location = [[Mengedda]] | army1 = Vulgar Holy War | army2 = Kianene | army3 = | result = Victory for the Kianene | army1leader = [[Nersei Calmemunis]] | army1participants = [[Akori Kumrezzer]]
[[Heänar Tharschilka]] | army2leader = [[Skauras ab Nalajan]] | army2participants = | army3leader = | army3participants = }} The '''Fourth Battle of Mengedda''' is the battle where the so-called [[Vulgar Holy War]] under [[Nersei Calmemunis]] suffered utter destruction at the hands of the [[Kian]]ene under [[Skauras ab Nalajan]] in 4110.Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Battle of Mengedda, the Fourth' ==References== [[Category:War]] [[Category:First Holy War]]

{{Battle infobox | name = Fifth Battle of Mengedda | partof = [[Holy War]] | date = 4111 | location = [[Mengedda Plains]] | army1 = Holy War | army2 = [[Kian]]ene | army3 = | result = Victory for the Holy War | army1leader = [[Coithus Saubon]] | army1participants = [[Hoga Gothyelk]]
[[Braelwan Cynnea]]
[[Eorcu Othrain]]
[[Goken the Red]]
[[Hargraum Kothwa]]
[[Hringa Magga]]
[[Hringa Narradha]]
[[Hringa Skaiyelt]]
[[Incheiri Gotian]]
[[Kussalt]]
[[Raeharth Hagarond]]
[[Rilding Werijen Greatheart]]
[[Safirig Trondha]]
[[Swahon Wainhail]]
[[Thagawain Anfirig]]
[[Yalgrota Sranchammer]] | army2leader = [[Skauras ab Nalajan]] | army2participants = [[Fanayal ab Kascamandri]] | army3leader = | army3participants = }} The '''Fifth Battle of Mengedda''' was the first decisive battle fought between the [[Holy War|First Holy War]] and the [[Kian]]ene, in 4111. Plagued with organizational problems and dissension under its commanders, the First Holy War, under the nominal command of Prince [[Coithus Saubon]], was caught by [[Skauras ab Nalajan]] and his Kianene host on the [[Mengedda Plains]] with only half of its available strength. From morning to late afternoon, the [[Inrithi]] managed to beat back innumerable Kianene charges. When the remainder of the First Holy War arrived on the [[Fanim]] flank, the will of the Kianene broke and they were routed.Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Battle of Mengedda, the Fifth’ ==References== [[Category:War]] [[Category:First Holy War]]

'''Mysunsai''', "The Bond of Three", is a self-proclaimed "mercenary [[School]]", which sells its sorcerous services across the [[Three Seas]].
Perhaps the largest of the [[Anagogic]] Schools, though far from the most powerful, the Mysunsai are a commercial result of the 3804 defensive amalgamation of three minor Schools during the [[Scholastic Wars]]: the [[Mikka Council]] from [[Cironj]], the [[Oaranat]] from [[Nilnamesh]], and the ([[Cengemis|Cengemic]]) [[Nilitar Compact]] from [[Ce Tydonn]]. Under the terms of the infamous Psailian Concession during the Scholastic Wars, the Mysunsai assisted the [[Inrithi]] in their [[Ainon]]i campaigns, an act for which the School was never forgiven, though it did much to confirm the School's exclusive commercial interests to its customers<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 468, 'Mysunsai'</ref>.
Mysunsai Schoolmen have a reputation for being lesser sorcerers.
==Known Members== * [[Hagnar]] * [[Keles Musyerius]] * [[Obwë Gûswuran]] (Grandmaster at the time of the [[Great Ordeal]]) * [[Pafaras]] (cast away from his School, thus a [[Wizard]]) * [[Parsalates]] * [[Skalateas]] (Grandmaster at the time of the [[Holy War]])
==References== <references/> [[Category:Schools]]

'''Anserca''' is the southernmost province of the [[Nansur Empire]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Anserca’</ref>
The province’s primary commodity is wool.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Nabathra’</ref>
==Towns== * [[Nabathra]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Provinces]]

{{Character infobox | name = Cimoira | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Thousandfold Thought]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned) | lived = ? - ? | race = [[Men|Man]]-[[Cûnuroi|Nonman]] hybrid | ethnicity = (Half-)[[Emwama]] | nationality =[[Siöl|Siölan]] | gender = Female | occupation = | relatives = [[Sirwitta]] (father)
Unnamed mother }} '''Cimoira''' was the first known instance of a half-[[Men|Man]], half-[[Nonman]] child, as recorded in the ''[[Isûphiryas]]''. Cimoira was the daughter of the wife of a Nonman [[Ishroi]] by the [[Emwama]] man [[Sirwitta]]. After her birth, her father was banished to the Second Watch. Cimoira's true heritage was covered up and she was accepted and raised as a full CûnuroiEncyclopedic Glossary, 'Cûno-Inchoroi Wars'. ==References== [[Category:Cûnuroi]] [[Category:Emwama]] [[Category:Characters from the Ancient North]] [[Category:Hybrids]]

{{Character infobox | name = Surmante Caphrianus I | titles = Emperor | nicknames = The Younger | appearances = mentioned only | lived = 3722 - 3785 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = [[Nansur]] | gender = Male | occupation = Emperor of Nansur | relatives = [[Surmante Skilura II]] (ancestor)
[[Surmante Xatantius I]] (ancestor) }} '''Surmante Caphrianus I''', commonly called "the Younger" to distinguish him from his [[Ceneian]] namesake, was a [[Nansur]] Surmante emperor famed for his wily diplomacy and far-reaching reforms of the Nansur legal code.Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Caphrianus I' ==References== [[Category:Characters from Nansur]] [[Category:Emperors]] [[Category:Ketyai]]

The '''Imperial Saik''' is an [[Anagogic]] [[School]] based in [[Momemn]] and indentured to the [[Nansur]] Emperor<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 452, 'Imperial Saik'</ref>.
The Saik, or Imperial Saik as they are often called, are the institutional descendants of the [[Saka]], the notorious state-sanctioned School of Imperial [[Cenei]], who for a thousand years dominated the [[Three Seas]] under the aegis of the Aspect-Emperors. Though still considered a Major School, the Saik have dwindled in strength, their resources limited by Nansur's losses and their numbers diminished by continual skirmish with the [[Cishaurim]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 480, 'Saik'</ref>.
They are also known as "Sorcerers of the Sun"<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 489, 'Sorcerers of the Sun'</ref>.
They wear black and gold robes.
==Known Members== * [[Cememketri]] (Grandmaster at the time of the [[Holy War]]) * [[Darastius]] * [[Imparrhas]] * [[Ouras]] * [[Temus Enhorû]] (Grandmaster at the time of the [[Great Ordeal]]) * [[Thassius]] * [[Vem-Mithriti]]
==References== <references/> [[Category:Schools]]

'''Chanv''' is an addictive narcotic popular among the [[Ainon]]i aristocracy, although many eschew it because of its uncertain origins. Chanv reputedly sharpens the intellect, extends one lifespan, and drains the body of all its pigment.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘chanv’</ref>
Chanv is produced in the nation of [[Jekhia]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Jekhia’</ref>
==Trivia== * Chanv was inspired by Sappho Juice from Frank Herbert's ''Dune'' series of novels.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Artifacts]]

{{Character infobox | name = Charamemas | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = mentioned only | lived = 4036 - 4108 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = | gender = Male | occupation = Tutor | relatives = }}
'''Charamemas''' was a famed Shrial commentator and author of ''The Ten Holies''.
Charamemas replaced [[Drusas Achamian]] as [[Nersei Proyas]]'s tutor in exoterics in 4093.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Charamemas'</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Tutors]] [[Category:Characters from the Three Seas]]

'''Chargiddo''' is a large fortress located on the frontier of [[Xerash]] and [[Amoteu]] beneath the [[Betmulla Mountains]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Chargiddo’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

'''Chiama''' is a walled town on the [[River Sempis]], destroyed by the [[Holy War|First Holy War]] in 4111.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Chiama’</ref>
Fearing starvation because of a blight the previous year, the town elders demanded guarantees from the Holy War before throwing open their gates. Rather than negotiate, [[Sheorog Cerjulla]] had his men storm the walls and massacre everyone.<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 11</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

The '''Citadel of the Dog''' is the great redoubt of [[Caraskand]] as named by the Men of the [[Tusk]].
Raised by [[Surmante Xatantius I]] in 3684, it was originally called “Insarum,” until it fell to the [[Fanim]] in 3839, who called it Il’huda, “the Bulwark.”<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Citadel of the Dog’</ref>
The fortress has round towers, massive barbicans, and offset inner and outer gates. The defenses are tiered, so that each concentric ring overshadows the next. The outer walls are shelled in glossy black basalt. It gained the nickname “Citadel of the Dog” because the towering central keep vaguely resembles a dog curled about his master’s leg.<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 21</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

revision.comment: Redirected page to [[Citadel of the Dog]]
revision.text: #redirect [[Citadel of the Dog]]

revision.comment: Redirected page to [[Citadel of the Dog]]
revision.text: #redirect [[Citadel of the Dog]]

'''''The Commerce of Souls''''' is a classic treatise on politics by the famed philosopher [[Ajencis]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 429, 'Commerce of Souls, The'</ref>.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Written works]]

'''Cuärweth''' is a fiefdom of interior [[Ce Tydonn]], located to the north of [[Meigeiri]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Cuärweth’</ref>.
The Earl of Cuärweth at the time of the [[Holy War|First Holy War]] was [[Damergal]]<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought,'' Chapter 16</ref>. At the time of the [[Great Ordeal]], this fiefdom was ruled by [[Shilka Grimmel]]<ref>''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 5</ref>.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Fiefdoms]]

[[File:Akka v Zioz.jpg|thumb|300px|The Mandate sorcerer Drusas Achamian sings the Gnosis against the Ciphrang lord Zioz.]] The '''Daimos,''' also known as noömancy, is the sorcery of summoning and enslaving agencies from the [[Outside]], namely, [[Ciphrang]].
For both political and pragmatic reasons, many [[The Schools|Schools]] forbid its practice. Some esoteric scholars claim that Daimotic sorcerers condemn themselves to eternal torment at the hands of their erstwhile slaves when they die.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Daimos’</ref>
==Daimotic Summoners== * [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]] * [[Heramari Iyokus]]
==Trivia== * The branches of sorcery all take their names from Greek words. “Daimos” comes from the Greek word “Δαιμος,” meaning “Demons.”
==References== <references /> [[Category:Branches of Sorcery]]

[[File:Akka v Zioz.jpg|thumb|300px|The Mandate sorcerer Drusas Achamian sings the Gnosis against the Ciphrang lord Zioz.]] '''Ciphrang''' are incorporeal agencies from the [[Outside]], of lesser power than the [[Gods]], that can be summoned through [[Daimos|Daimotic]] [[sorcery]]. They are commonly known as demons.
As they are divine agencies, manifesting in the world and taking a physical shape is a deeply painful experience to them. When forcibly summoned into the physical realm by Daimotic sorcerers, they are bound by their summoner’s will until he chooses to release them back into the Outside.
Ciphrang are commonly divided into ranks based on their power. These include Debiles and Potents.<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought,'' Chapter 14</ref>
==Known Ciphrang== * [[Ankaryotis]] * [[Hagazioz]] * [[Hish]] * [[Kakaliol]] * [[Puskarat]] * [[Setmahaga]] * [[Sohorat]] * [[Urskrux]] * [[Zioz]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Races]]

page.title: The Fourth Dialogue of the Movements of the Planets as They Pertain to Astrology

revision.text:
'''''The Fourth Dialogue of the Movements of the Planets as They Pertain to Astrology''''' is one of the famed "lost works" of [[Ajencis]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Fourth Dialogue of the Movements of the Planets as They Pertain to Astrology, The'</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Written works]]

{{Character infobox | name = Ginsil | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Thousandfold Thought]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned) | lived = 2115 - ca. 2147 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity =[[Norsirai]] | nationality =[[Kûniüri|Kûniüric]] | gender = Female | occupation = | relatives =[[En-Kaujalau]] (husband) }} '''Ginsil''' was the wife of General [[En-Kaujalau]]. She is mentioned in ''[[The Sagas]] ''as having pretended to be her husband in order to to fool the assassins coming to kill himEncyclopedic Glossary, 'Ginsil'. ==References== [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Characters from the Ancient North]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Characters from Kûniüri]]

The '''Great Ziggurat of Xijoser''' is the largest of the [[Ziggurats of Shigek]], raised by the Old Dynasty [[Shigek]] God-King [[Xijoser]] c. 670.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Great Ziggurat of Xijoser’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

The '''Ziggurats of Shigek''' are immense stepped pyramids found to the north of the [[River Sempis]] Delta and raised by the ancient God-Kings of [[Shigek]] to serve as their mortuary tombs.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ziggurats of Shigek’</ref>
==Significant Ziggurats== * [[Great Ziggurat of Xijoser]] * [[Palpothis]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

'''Huterat''' is a [[Kian]]ene town on the [[River Sempis]] Delta, destroyed by the First [[Holy War]] in 4111.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Huterat’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

{{Character infobox | name = Ikurei Anphairas I | titles = Emperor | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Thousandfold Thought]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned) | lived = 4022 - 4081 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity =[[Ketyai]] | nationality = [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] | gender = Male | occupation = Emperor of [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] | relatives = [[Ikurei Sorius I|Sorius]] (ancestor)
[[Ikurei Xerius III's father|Unnamed son]]
[[Ikurei Xerius III|Xerius]] (grandson)
[[Ikurei Conphas' father|Unnamed grandson]]
[[Ikurei Conphas|Conphas]] (great-grandson) }} '''Ikurei Anphairas I''' was the Emperor of [[Nansur]] from 4066 to 4081, when he was assassinated by persons unknownEncyclopedic Glossary, 'Ikurei Anphairas I'. ==References== [[Category:Emperors]] [[Category:Characters from Nansur]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Men]]

{{Character infobox | name = Ikurei Sorius I | titles = Emperor | nicknames = | appearances = mentioned only | lived = ? - ? | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = [[Nansur]] | gender = Male | occupation = Emperor of Nansur | relatives = [[Ikurei Anphairas I]] (descendant)
[[Ikurei Xerius III]] (descendant)
[[Ikurei Conphas]] (descendant) }} '''Ikurei Sorius I''' was the first of the long line of shrewd yet defensive Ikurei emperors of [[Nansur]].Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Ikurei Dynasty' A former Exalt-General, Sorius came to power as the result of a coup brought about by the turmoil following the loss of [[Shigek]] to the [[Kian]]ene in 3933. He reorganized both the Imperial Army and the empire, changes that allowed him and his descendants to defeat no fewer than three full-scale [[Fanim]] invasions.Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Nansur Empire' ==References== [[Category:Characters from Nansur]] [[Category:Emperors]] [[Category:Ketyai]]

revision.comment: I added a lot of text from the books.
revision.text:
The '''Indara-Kishauri''' are the “tribe” of the [[Cishaurim]].
The “Indara” refer, in the [[Kian]]ene tradition, to the “tribe of water-bearers,” a legendary band that supposedly wandered the dunes dispensing water and mercy to the faithful. The designation is critical (according to the ''[[kipfa’aifan]],'' it saved [[Fane]]’s life), given the importance of tribal affiliation in desert Kianene society.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Indara-Kishauri’</ref>
The pastoralists of the Carathay desert are unique in possessing a grammatical distinction between us and them, self and other, one which can only be captured in Sheyic as “us-them.” The stories of the Indara-Kishauri ranging from their mythical home of Udavant hidden somewhere in the lifeless heart of the Great Salt personify this distinction for the Kianene in particular, who referred to their shamanistic Kiunnat priests as such. These formed the trans-tribal basis for the spread of Fanimry, as well as the sudden transformation of a fractious, internecine tribal people into a cohesive, empire-building nation. By characterizing his miraculous powers as “water” and himself as a divine “water-bearer,” Fane managed to seize high ground built into the very structure of Kianene language.
==Members of the Indara-Kishauri== * [[Anasûrimbor Moënghus]] * [[Fane]] * [[Fanfarokar]] * [[Hab’hara]] * [[Hahkti ab Sibban]] * [[Hifanat ab Tunukri]] * [[Inkorot]] * [[Kisma]] * [[Meppa]] * [[Sartmandri]] * [[Seökti]] * [[Tatokar I]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Tribes]]

'''Ingraul''' is a fiefdom of the [[Thunyerus|Thunyeri]] [[Sranc]] Marches.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ingraul’</ref>
The Earl of Ingraul is [[Murworg Ganbrota]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ganbrota, Murworg’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Fiefdoms]]
#redirect [[Thunyerus]]

The '''Jahan Plains''' are the large, arid tableland that makes up the western frontier of [[Eumarna]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Jahan Plains’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Plains]]

'''Jarutha''' is a small agricultural town some twenty miles southwest of [[Momemn]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Jarutha'</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Cities]]

'''Jekhia''' (also known as '''Jekk''') is a tributary nation of [[High Ainon]], located at the headwaters of the [[River Sayut]] in the [[Great Kayarsus]].
Jekhia is famed as the mysterious source of [[chanv]].
The [[Men]] of Jekhia are unique in that they exhibit [[Xiuhianni]] racial characteristics.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Jekhia’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Nations]]

'''Jirux''' is a great [[Kian]]ene fortress on the north bank of the [[River Sempis]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Jirux’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

'''Joktha''' is a port city on the [[Enathpaneah|Enathpanean]] coast.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Joktha’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

The '''Jorua Sea''' is a great inland sea located in mid-western [[Eärwa]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Jorua Sea’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Seas]]

'''Jurisada''' is a governorate of [[Kian]] and former province of the [[Nansur Empire]].
Located on the southeastern end of the [[Eumarna]]n Penninsula, Jurisada is an intensively agricultural region, densely populated, and though to be a land of “spiritual sloth” by many Kianene.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Jurisada’</ref>
The Sapatishah-Governor of Jurisada is [[Swarjuka]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Swarjuka’</ref>
==Cities== * [[Nerum]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Governorates]]

'''Kanampurea''' is a palatinate in the [[Conriya]]n interior, famed for its agricultural productivity, traditionally held by the brother of the Conriyan King.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kanampurea’</ref>
The Palatine of Kanampurea is [[Nersei Calmemunis]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Calmemunis, Nersei’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Palatinates]]

'''Kanshaïva''' is a district of [[Nilnamesh]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 457, 'Kanshaïva'</ref>.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Provinces]]

'''Karyot''' is a palatinate of [[High Ainon]], located on the upper [[River Sayut]] and forming the [[Jekhia|Jekhian]] frontier<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Karyot’</ref>.
The Palatine of Karyot at the time of the [[Great Ordeal]] was [[Matmuth Shorathises]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Shorathises, Matmuth'</ref>.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Palatinates]]

'''Kelmeöl''' was the ancient capital of the [[Meöri Empire]], destroyed in the [[Apocalypse]] in 2150.{{EG|Kelmeöl}}
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

'''Kurigald''' is a fiefdom of [[Galeoth]], located on the eastern shores of [[Huösi|Lake Huösi]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kurigald’</ref>
The Earl of Kurigald is [[Swahon Wainhail]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Wainhail, Swahon’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Fiefdoms]]

'''Kutapileth''' is a palatinate of eastern [[High Ainon]], noted for its iron and silver mines<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kutapileth’</ref>.
The Palatine of Kutapileth at the time of the [[Holy War|First Holy War]] was [[Akori Kumrezzer]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kumrezzar, Akori’</ref>. [[Urdrûsû Marsalees]] held this title at the time of the [[Great Ordeal]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Marsalees, Urdrûsû'</ref>.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Palatinates]]

'''Mamot''' is a ruined [[Ceneian Empire|Ceneian]] city in [[Mongilea]] located near the mouth of the [[River Sweki]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Mamot’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

'''Manghaput''' is a major port city in [[Nilnamesh]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 464, 'Manghaput'</ref>.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Cities]]

'''Massentia''' is a province of the central [[Nansur]]ium, called "the Golden" because of the bounty of her wheat fields<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Massentia'</ref>.
Giv­en the pro­found cul­tur­al im­pact of the [[Ceneian Empire]], the name has long been a by­word for bucolic pros­per­ity across the [[Three Seas]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Massentia'</ref>.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Provinces]]

{{Character infobox | name = Cet’ingira | image = [[Image:Cet'ingira.JPG|260px]] | caption = Cet’ingira by [http://francisbuck.deviantart.com/ Francis Buck] | titles =The Evil Siqû | nicknames = Mekeritrig
Mantraitor | lived = ? - 4132 | race = [[Cûnuroi]] | ethnicity = | nationality = | gender = Male | occupation = [[Siqû]]
[[Qûya]]
Member of the [[Consult]] | relatives = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]''
''[[The Thousandfold Thought (Book)|The Thousandfold Thought]]'' (flashbacks only)
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' |caption1=}} {{Blockquote|I am a warrior of ages, Anasurimbor ... ages. I have dipped my nimil in a thousand hearts. I have ridden both against and for the No-God in the great wars that authored this wilderness. I have scaled the ramparts of great Golgotterath, watched the hearts of High Kings break for fury.|Cet'ingira}} '''Cet’ingira''', also known as '''Mekeritrig''' (“Traitor of Men” in Kûniüric), is an Erratic [[Nonmen|Nonman]] [[Siqû]] and powerful [[Qûya]] who revealed the location of the [[Incû-Holoinas|Min-Uroikas]] to the [[the Schools|School]] of [[Mangaecca]] in 777, and who would become a ranking member of the [[Consult]] during the [[Apocalypse]].Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Mekeritrig’ == What Came Before == Cet’ingira was sent on an expedition together with two [[Ishroi]] into the depths of the Incû-Holoinas by [[Nil’giccas]] following the end of the [[Cûno-Inchoroi Wars]]. They beheld the Inverse Fire. The two Ishroi, [[Misariccas]] and [[Runidil]], were driven to madness by the sight of it, while Cet’ingira appeared able to keep his wits. Upon returning, Cet’ingira advised the King to have the other two killed. Unknown to the others, Cet'ingira had also been affected, and was now wholly convinced of Damnation and the Inchoroi's mission to close the world to the Outside.[[The False Sun]] Over the following centuries, Cet'ingira disguised his true intentions. It was he who advised Nil'giccas to begin the [[Nonman Tutelage]] of the Men - ostensibly to teach the Nonmen's knowledge to the younger race, but in reality so that he could secretly pass on the Inchoroi's revelation. == The Darkness That Comes Before == Anâsurimbor Kellhus meets Cet'ingira on his long way south in the ruins of a Nonman fortress after killing a pack of Sranc. Cet'ingira, amused, eyes the many dead Sranc around Kellhus and notes that among those killed by him, one was his Eljû, a Sranc he and other Nonmen used as a "book". He then attacks after Kellhus prods him with various questions, and he senses that Kellhus has the same blood as one of the many skinned faces he uses as a part of his cloak. To his surprise, Kellhus outmatches him in their sword fight, but Cet'ingira overpowers him by using sorcery and forces the Dûnyain to flee. == The Thousandfold Thought == Drusas Achamian sees Cet'ingira in a Seswatha's dream relieved by Nautzera. The Evil Siqû interrogates the ancient hero in the recently fallen Dagliash, but is broken himself and weeps at his own degradation and the pain he causes Seswatha, who he viewed, in a way, his child. Achamian sees that completely covering the walls of Dagliash are hundreds upon hundreds of twitching human forms, all held up by immense nails driven through their torsos and groins. == The Unholy Consult == At the battle of Golgotterath, Anâsurimbor Kellhus tears off his head. Thus died the Evil Siqû, and his soul was cast down to Hell, to suffer eternally. ==References== [[Category:Cûnuroi]] [[Category:Erratics]] [[Category:Qûya]] [[Category:Consult members]] [[Category:Siqû]] [[Category:Characters from the Ancient North]]

The '''Munuäti''' are a powerful [[Scylvendi]] tribe from the interior of the [[Jiünati Steppe]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Munuäti’</ref>
==Members of the Munuäti== * [[Oknai One-Eye]] * [[Panteruth urs Mutkius]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Tribes]]
[[Category:Places]]

'''The Flail''' is a constellation in the northern sky.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Flail, the’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cosmos]]

'''The Lance''' is a [[Scylvendi]] constellation in the northern sky.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Lance, the’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cosmos]]

{{Character infobox | name = Anasûrimbor Mygella | titles = High King of Aörsi | nicknames = Hero-King | appearances = mentioned only | lived = 2065 - 2111 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Aörsi]] | gender = Male | occupation = High King of Aörsi | relatives = [[Anasûrimbor Nanor-Ukkerja I]] (ancestor)
[[Anasûrimbor Nimeric]] (descendant) }} '''Anasûrimbor Mygella''' was the famed Hero-King of [[Aörsi]], whose deeds are recounted in ''[[The Sagas]].''Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Mygella, Anasûrimbor’ ==References== [[Category:Anasûrimbor]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Characters from Aörsi]] [[Category:Kings]]

{{Character infobox | name = Anasûrimbor Nimeric | titles = High King of Aörsi | nicknames = | appearances = mentioned only | lived = 2092 - 2135 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Aörsi]] | gender = Male | occupation = High King of Aörsi | relatives = [[Anasûrimbor Nanor-Ukkerja I]] (ancestor)
[[Anasûrimbor Mygella]] (ancestor) }} '''Anasûrimbor Nimeric''' was the High King of ancient [[Aörsi]] before its destruction in the [[Apocalypse]].Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Nimeric, Anasûrimbor’ ==References== [[Category:Anasûrimbor]] [[Category:Characters from Aörsi]] [[Category:Kings]] [[Category:Norsirai]]

'''Nangael''' is a fiefdom of [[Ce Tydonn]], located along the [[River Swa]] Marches<ref name=":0" />.
Nangael warriors can be readily identified by their tattooed cheeks<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Nangael’</ref>.
The Earl of Nangael at the time of the [[Holy War|First Holy War]] was [[Nûkulk Iyengar]]<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought,'' Chapter 4</ref><ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Iyengar, Nûkulk'</ref>. He was eventually succeeded by [[Nûkulk Osfringa]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Osfringa, Nûkulk'</ref>, and Osfringa by [[Woyengar]] (who held the title by the time of the [[Great Ordeal]])<ref>''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 18</ref>.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Fiefdoms]]

{{Character infobox | name = Anasûrimbor Nau-Cayûti | titles = Prince | nicknames = Blessed Son
Scourge of Golgotterath
Murswagga
Dragonslayer
Cayû | appearances = ''[[The Thousandfold Thought (Book)|The Thousandfold Thought]]'' (flashbacks only)
''[[The Judging Eye (Book)|The Judging Eye]]'' (flashbacks only)
''[[The White-Luck Warrior (Book)|The White-Luck Warrior]]'' (flashbacks only)
''[[The Great Ordeal (Book)|The Great Ordeal]]'' (flashbacks only)
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned) | lived = 2119 - 2140(?) | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Kûniüri]] | gender = Male | occupation = Prince of [[Kûniüri]] | relatives = [[Anasûrimbor Celmomas II|Celmomas II]] (supposed father)
[[Suriala]] (mother)
[[Seswatha]] (possible father)
[[Anasûrimbor Ganrelka II|Ganrelka II]] (relative, possibly brother)
[[Iëva]] (wife)
[[Aulisi]] (concubine) }} '''Anasûrimbor''' '''Nau-Cayûti''' (“Blessed Son” in Ûmeritic) officially was the youngest son of [[Anasûrimbor Celmomas II]] and his wife [[Suriala]]. But perhaps he was a bastard child of [[Seswatha]] and the Queen. Nau-Cayûti was famed for his heroism and martial brilliance during the dark days after the fall of [[Aörsi]] (2136), when the nation of [[Kûniüri]] stood alone against the menace of the [[Consult]]. He rose to fame in the [[Battle of Ossirish]], where he routed the Consult forces and personally killed the dragon [[Tanhafut|Tanhafut the Red]]. After this, he became popularly known as ''Murswagga,'' the Dragonslayer. Many of his exploits are recounted in ''[[The Sagas]].''Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Nau-Cayûti’ His last great deed was infiltrating [[Golgotterath]] itself, together with his mentor and possible father Seswatha, where they stole the mysterious [[Heron Spear]]. This daring exploit was motivated by Nau-Cayûti’s desperate desire to rescue his favorite concubine, [[Aulisi]]. [[Mandate]] commentators dispute the account found in ''The Sagas,'' where they successfully return with both Aulisi and the Heron Spear, claiming that Aulisi was never found. Nau-Cayûti died shortly after the theft of the Heron Spear. According to ''The Sagas,'' he was murdered with poison by his wife, [[Iëva]].Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Apocalypse’ However, visions into the past, received by [[Drusas Achamian]] through [[Seswatha’s Dreams]], suggested that the poison merely paralyzed him. Iëva was in reality working for the Consult, and made sure to bury her husband alive rather than burning him.''The White-Luck Warrior,'' Chapter 12 Nau-Cayûti was then exhumed from his grave by [[Aurang]] and taken as a prisoner to Golgotterath. Nau-Cayuti later embraced the Consult's vision after viewing the Inverse Fire; nonetheless the Consult used his soul to create the No-God by placing him in the Carapace. ''The White-Luck Warrior,'' Chapter 15 ==References== [[Category:Anasûrimbor]] [[Category:Characters from Kûniüri]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Men]]

'''Nerum''' is a minor port city and the administrative capital of [[Jurisada]], located on the coast just south of [[Amoteu]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Nerum’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

{{Character infobox | name = Nersei Onoyas II | titles = King | nicknames = | appearances = mentioned only | lived = 3823 - 3878 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Ketyai]] | nationality = [[Conriya]]n | gender = Male | occupation = King of Conriya | relatives = [[Nersei Calmemunis]] (descendant)
[[Nersei Tirummas]] (descendant)
[[Nersei Proyas]] (descendant) }} '''Nersei Onoyas II''' is the King of [[Conriya]] who first forged the alliance between the [[School]] of [[Mandate]] and House Nersei.Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Onoyas II, Nersei' ==References== [[Category:Characters from Conriya]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Kings]]

'''Palpothis''' is one of the famed [[Ziggurats of Shigek]], named after [[Palpothis III]], the Old Dynasty [[Shigek]] God-King who raised her.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Palpothis’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

The '''Parrhae Plains''' are a region of fertile tablelands located in northwestern [[Galeoth]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Parrhae Plains’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Plains]]

'''Pasna''' is a town on the [[River Phayus]], known for the quality of its olive oil.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Pasna’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

'''Pharixas''' is a disputed island stronghold in the [[Meneanor]] Sea<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 477, 'Pharixas'</ref>.
It was long used as a pirate stronghold by King [[Hringa Rauschang]] of [[Thunyerus]], but in 4110 was stormed by several thousand [[Tydonni]] rendering service as mercenaries to [[Nrezza Barisullas]] in lieu of payment for a number of ships they'd contracted and defaulted on. Thousands of innocents perished in the raid<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 8, p. 229</ref>.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Structures]]

'''Sakthuta''' is a mountain in the [[Hethanta Mountains]] overlooking the [[River Kiyuth]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Sakthuta’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Mountains]]

'''Sappathurai''' is a powerful mercantile city in [[Nilnamesh]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Sappathurai’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

The '''Sareötic Library''' was one of the greatest libraries in the known world in the time of the [[Ceneian Empire]].
The so-called “script law” of [[Iothiah]] forced, on punishment of death, all visitors bearing books to surrender them for copying and inclusion in the Library. Though the Sareöts were massacred when [[Shigek]] fell to the [[Fanimry|Fanim]] in 3933, Padirajah [[Fan’oukarji III]] spared the Library when he found it contained maps useful for his [[Dagger Jihad|Jihad]], thinking it the will of the [[Solitary God]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Sareotic Library’</ref>
The Sareötic Library is destroyed in 4111 during a battle between [[Drusas Achamian]] and [[sorcerer]]s of the [[Scarlet Spires]].<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 13</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

{{Character infobox | name = Sasheoka | titles = Grandmaster | nicknames = | appearances = mentioned only | lived = 4049 - 4100 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = | gender = Male | occupation = Grandmaster of the [[Scarlet Spires]] | relatives = }}
'''Sasheoka''' was the Grandmaster of the [[Scarlet Spires]], assassinated in 4100 by the [[Cishaurim]] and succeeded by [[Hanamanu Eleäzaras]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Sasheoka'</ref>
Sasheoka was assassinated by the Cishaurim because they incorrectly believed the Scarlet Spires to be responsible for the creation of [[skin-spies]], which [[Anasûrimbor Moënghus]] discovered in [[Shimeh]].<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 16</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Scarlet Spires]] [[Category:Grandmasters]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Characters from Conriya]]

The '''River Saskri''' is a major river system in [[Eumarna]], with headwaters in [[Eshgarnea]] and draining the [[Jahan Plains]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Saskri River’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Rivers]]

'''Scindia''' is the [[Scylvendi]]-dominated land to the immediate west of the [[Hethanta Mountains]].{{EG|Scindia}}
==References== <references /> [[Category:Plains]]

The '''River Shaul''' is the second most important river system in the [[Nansur Empire]], after the [[River Phayus]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Shaul River’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Rivers]]

Generally, '''Siqû''' are [[Nonmen]] who find themselves in the service of [[Men]], usually as mercenaries or in some advisory capacity. Specifically, those Nonmen who participated in the so-called [[Nonman Tutelage]] from 555 to 825.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Siqu’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Occupations]]

{{Character infobox | name = Surmante Skilura II | titles = Emperor | nicknames = The Mad | appearances = mentioned only | lived = 3619 - 3668 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = [[Nansur]] | gender = Male | occupation = Emperor of Nansur | relatives = [[Surmante Xatantius I]]
[[Surmante Caphrianus I]] }} '''Surmante Skilura II''', also called "the Mad", was the most cruel of the Surmante Emperors of [[Nansur]], whose deranged antics led to the Granary Revolts of 3668 and the accension of [[Surmante Xatantius I]] to the Mantle.Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Skilura II' Skilura is said to have kept a bowl of molten gold at his side, to fling into the faces of those who displeased him.''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 9 ==References== [[Category:Characters from Nansur]] [[Category:Emperors]] [[Category:Ketyai]]

'''Suskara''' is a vast region of broken plains and highlands between [[Atrithau]] and the [[Jiünati Steppe]], inhabited by numerous tribes of [[Sranc]], some of which are tributary to the so-called Sranc King of [[Urskugog]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Suskara’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Plains]]

'''Tamiznai''' is a fortified oasis two days south of the [[River Sempis]], frequented by caravans.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Tamiznai’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Seas]]

'''Tendant'heras''' is an extensive fortress located on [[Nilnamesh]]'s frontier with [[Girgash]] and [[Kian]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 493, 'Tendant'heras'</ref>.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Structures]]

{{Character infobox | name = Nersei Tirummas | titles = Crown Prince | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Thousandfold Thought]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Great Ordeal]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned) | lived = 4075 - 4100 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Ketyai]] | nationality = [[Conriya]]n | gender = Male | occupation = Crown Prince of [[Conriya]] | relatives = [[Nersei Eukernas II|Eukernas II]] (father)
