[[Nersei Thaila (younger)|Thaila]] (niece) }} '''Nersei Tirummas''' was the eldest brother of [[Nersei Proyas]], and Crown Prince of [[Conriya]] until his death at sea.Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Tirummas, Nersei' ==References== [[Category:Characters from Conriya]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Men]]

'''Tusam''' was a village in the [[Inûnara Highlands]] destroyed by [[Fanim]] raiders in 4111<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 496, 'Tusam'</ref>.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Cities]]

The '''Inûnara Highlands''' are a region of foothills to the northeast of the [[Unaras Spur]] of the [[Hethanta Mountains]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Inûnara Highlands'</ref>
==Towns== * [[Tusam]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Plains]]

'''Uroris''' is a constellation in the northern sky.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Uroris’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cosmos]]

The '''Werigda''' are a semi-nomadic [[Norsirai]] tribe from the [[Plains of Gâl]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Werigda’</ref>
<nowiki> </nowiki>In the early spring of 4112, the women and children of a Werigda tribe were kidnapped and interrogated by the [[Consult]] for information about the [[Dûnyain]].
==Members of the Werigda== * [[Aëngelas]] * [[Bengulla]] * [[Valrissa]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Tribes]]

{{Character infobox | name = Ysilka | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Thousandfold Thought]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned) | lived = ? - ? | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity =[[Norsirai]] | nationality =[[Kûniüri|Kûniüric]] | gender = Female | occupation = | relatives =[[Sag-Marmau]] (husband) }} '''Ysilka''' was the wife of General [[Sag-Marmau]]. She was mentioned in ''[[The Sagas]]'', being referred to as "legendary"Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Sag-Marmau'''. ''Her name is often used as an euphemism for "adulteress" in the [[Three Seas]]Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Ysilka'. ==References== [[Category:Characters from the Ancient North]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Characters from Kûniüri]]

{{Character infobox | name = Leweth | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]'' | lived = 4061 - 4109 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Atrithau|Atrithan]] | gender = Male | occupation = Trapper | relatives = }}
'''Leweth''' is a trapper in the abandoned [[Atrithau|Atrithan]] province of [[Sobel]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Leweth’</ref>
==Appearance==
Leweth has fine, cropped hair of silver with a hint of bronze.<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Prologue</ref>
==Personality==
Leweth is an alcoholic. He is bitter at the world for the death of his wife, and unwilling to move on.
==Story==
===What Came Before===
Leweth originally lived in Atrithau, but left the city after the death of his wife, choosing instead to live alone in the abandoned province of [[Sobel]].
===''The Darkness That Comes Before''===
He is the first world-born [[Man]] encountered by [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]] after leaving [[Ishuäl]]. Kellhus learns to read Leweth's emotions and manipulate him, and eventually abandons him to his death at the hands of [[Sranc]].
==References== <references/> [[Category:POV characters]] [[Category:Characters from Atrithau]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Trappers]]

'''''Nimil''''' is a rare metal used in by [[Nonmen]] in their weapons and armor, also known as "Nonman steel". It is forged in the [[sorcery|sorcerous]] furnaces of [[Ishterebinth]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 471, 'nimil'</ref>. In ancient times, ''nimil'' was mined in the lowest depths of [[Cil-Aujas]], where the Nonmen used up the lives of several thousand slaves in their efforts to find the metal.
Weapons of ''nimil ''are sharper and stronger than any steel blades forged by Men.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Artifacts]]
#redirect [[Men]]

{{Character infobox | name = Geshrunni | titles = Shield-Captain | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]'' | lived = 4069 - 4110 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Ketyai]] | nationality = [[Ainon]]i | gender = Male | occupation = Shield-Captain of the [[Javreh]] | relatives = }}
'''Geshrunni''' is a Shield-Captain of the [[Javreh]], slain in [[carythusal]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Geshrunni'</ref>
==Appearance==
Geshrunni has a hawkish soldier's face, a beared pleated into what look like black leather straps, and tanned arms. He has a line of Ainoni pictograms tattooed from his shoulder to his wrist.<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 1</ref>
==Story==
===''The Darkness That Comes Before''===
[[Drusas Achamian]] befriends Geshrunni in an attempt to use him as an informant to learn about the [[Scarlet Spires]]. Geshrunni quickly identifies him as a [[Mandate]] Schoolman, and uses a [[Chorae]] to force Achamian to confess to being a spy. However, he does not kill Achamian, instead taking a small measure of vengeance against his cruel Scarlet Spire masters by giving away valuable information regarding the assassination of [[Sasheoka]] ten years previously.
Shortly after the meeting, Geshrunni is killed by a [[skin-spy]] that had been observing Achamian.
==References== <references/> [[Category:POV characters]] [[Category:Members of the Javreh]] [[Category:Slaves]] [[Category:Characters from High Ainon]] [[Category:Ketyai]]

{{Character infobox | name = Seidru Nautzera | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]''
''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]''
''[[The Thousandfold Thought (Book) | The Thousandfold Thought]]'' | lived = 4038 - ? | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Ketyai]] | nationality = | gender = Male | occupation = [[Mandate]] [[sorcerer]] | relatives = }} {{stub}} '''Seidru Nautzera''' is a senior member of the [[Mandate]] Quorum.{{EG|Nautzera, Seidru}} ==Appearance== Nautzera is tall in stature and extremely aged. He has a beard; dyed dark, cut square, and intricately braided in the fasion of the eastern [[Ketyai]].{{1|2}} ==Story== ===The Darkness That Comes Before=== Nautzera leads the Quorum meeting that sends Achamian to Sumna to recruit Inrau and spy on the Thousand Temples in the wake of the Holy War. He tells Achamian to discover whether the Holy War will be waged against the Schools or against the Fanim. After the meeting, he meets with Polchias Simas and reveals that they had already known that the Fanim will be the targets of the Holy War and expresses some regret for lying to Achamian. Simas assures him that lying was necessary to motivate Achamian, as they both find him to be weak. During the meeting, Nautzera is annoyed by Simas's friendly persona, believing it to be false. ===The Warrior Prophet=== ===The Thousandfold Thought=== ==References== [[Category:POV characters]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Mandate]] [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Characters from the Three Seas]] [[Category:Gnostic sorcerers]]

{{Character infobox | name = Polchias Simas | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]''
''[[The Thousandfold Thought (Book) | The Thousandfold Thought]]'' | lived = 4052 - ? | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = | gender = Male | occupation = [[Mandate]] [[sorcerer]] | relatives = }} '''Polchias Simas''' is [[Drusas Achamian]]'s old teacher and a member of the Quorum, the ruling council of the [[School]] of [[Mandate]].Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Simas, Polchias' ==Appearance== Simas has white hair and a snow-white beard.''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 2 ==Story== With his mild personality, Simas is described as "water to [[Seidru Nautzera|Nautzera's]] fire." During the Quorum meeting at which Achamian is sent on his mission to discover the target of Maithanet's Holy War, Simas reveals that he has told the Quorum about Achamian's former student [[Paro Inrau]], which Achamian feels is a great betrayal. After the Quorum meeting, Simas meets with Nautzera and discusses how they already know that the Fanim will be the true targets the Holy War. They lied to Achamian because they feel that he is weak and needed the motivation. During a private conversation, Nautzera expresses doubts about the strategy, but Simas assures him that it was necessary. Nautzera becomes annoyed by Simas's mild personalty, believing that it is an act. At some unknown point, Simas is killed and replaced by a [[skin-spy]]. Its identity is exposed by [[Maithanet]] during a visit to [[Atyersus]]. The skin-spy who impersonates him is the only skin-spy ever known to be capable of [[sorcery]].''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 13 ==References== [[Category:Mandate]] [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Characters from the Three Seas]] [[Category:Gnostic sorcerers]]

{{Character infobox | name = Chiki | titles = | nicknames = Pomegranate | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]'' | lived = ? - present | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Ketyai]] | nationality = [[Ainon]]i | gender = Male | occupation = Child prostitute
Runner | relatives = }} '''Chiki''' is an orphan employed as a runner by [[Drusas Achamian]] during his time in [[High Ainon]]. When not working for Achamian, Chiki makes a living as a prostitute. ==Appearance== Chiki has smooth skin and fine features, save for a pomegranate-shaped birthmark on his face.''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 1 ==References== [[Category:Prostitutes]] [[Category:Characters from High Ainon]] [[Category:Ketyai]]

[[The Boy]] (great-nephew)}}[[File:Maithinet.png|thumb|300px]] {{stub}} '''Maithanet''' is the Shriah of the [[Thousand Temples]], and primary instigator of the [[Holy War|First Holy War]].Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Maithanet' His name means "instruction".''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 3 ==Appearance== Maithanet has blue eyes and blonde hair, though he dyed it black when he first took the office of Shriah. ==Skills== Maithanet recieved [[Dûnyain]] training allowing him to effortlessly read peoples' emotions and manipulate them. His training allows him to identify [[skin-spies]] by sight. He is one of the [[the Few|Few]], but never studied [[sorcery]]. ==Story== ===What Came Before=== Maithanet is a son of [[Anasûrimbor Moënghus]], making him [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Kellhus]]'s half-brother. According to the Mandate, Maithanet seemed to seize the position of Shriah almost out of nowhere. He quickly thwarted three separate plans to assassinate him. He also identified and purged a number of spies from rival factions. ===''The Darkness That Comes Before''=== Maithanet's plan to call a Holy War becomes known to the other factions, including the Mandate, who are not sure whether the target will be Sorcerers or the Fanim. They send Achamian to Sumna to learn the truth. Maithanet ultimately declares his Holy War against the [[Fanim]], calling upon all Inrithi to join in a massive invasion of [[Kian]] to retake the holy city of [[Shimeh]]. ===''The Warrior-Prophet''=== ===''The Thousandfold Thought''=== ===''The Judging Eye''=== ===''The White Luck Warrior''=== ==Notes== ==References== [[Category:Shriahs]] [[Category:Dûnyain]] [[Category:Anasûrimbor]] [[Category:Characters from Kian]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Thousand Temples]] [[Category:Mixed ethnicity]]

{{Character infobox | name = Incheiri Gotian | titles = Grandmaster | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]''
''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]''
''[[The Thousandfold Thought (Book) | The Thousandfold Thought]]'' | lived = 4065 - 4112 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = | gender = Male | occupation = Grandmaster of the Shrial Knights | relatives = }} '''Incheiri Gotian''' is the Grandmaster of the Shrial Knights and [[Maithanet]]'s representative in the [[Holy War]].Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Gotian, Incheiri' ==Appearance== Gotian has silver hair.''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 3 ==Story== ===''The Darkness That Comes Before''=== Gotian is sent by Maithanet to stop the [[Vulgar Holy War]], but [[Nersei Calmemunis]] ignores his orders. ===''The Warrior-Prophet''=== ===''The Thousandfold-Thought''=== Gotian is killed during the battle for [[Shimeh]], struck in the armpit by an arrow while raising his sword.''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 16 ==References== [[Category:Shrial Knights]] [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Characters from the Three Seas]]

The '''Agonies''' are the [[Gnosis|Gnostic]] Cants of Torment, a reputed specialty of the [[Mangaecca]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Agonies’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Magic]]

The '''Uroborian Circle''' is a so-called “artifactual Cant” used to prevent the utterance of [[sorcery]] and thought to turn on the same [[Aporos|aporetic]] principles that make [[Chorae]] possible.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Uroborian Circle’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Sorcerous artifacts]]

The '''Aporos''' is a branch of [[sorcery]] once studied by [[Nonmen]] [[Qûya]]. [[File:Chorae by spiralhorizon-d6ps51q.png|thumb|300px]] Forbidden from practicing their art under [[Cû’jara-Cinmoi]], they were seduced by the [[Inchoroi]], whose loss of the [[Battle of Pir Pahal]] had been largely due to the power of Qûya. The practicioners of the Aporos created for their masters the first [[Chorae]], which rendered their bearers immune to magic and killed Qûya on touch.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Cûno-Inchoroi Wars’</ref>
The [[Uroborian Circle]] is thought to also function on aporetic principles.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Uroborian Circle’</ref>
==Trivia== * The branches of sorcery all take their names from Greek words. “Aporos” comes from the Greek word “Άπορος,” meaning “Destitute.”
==References== <references /> [[Category:Branches of Sorcery]]

{{Character infobox | name = Nersei Calmemunis | titles = Palatine | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]'' | lived = 4069 - 4110 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Ketyai]] | nationality = [[Conriya]]n | gender = Male | occupation = Palatine of [[Kanampurea]] | relatives = [[Nersei Tirummas]] (cousin)
[[Nersei Proyas]] (cousin) }} '''Nersei Calmemunis''' is the Palatine of the [[Conriya]]n province of [[Kanampurea]], and nominal leader of the [[Vulgar Holy War]].Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Calmemunis, Nersei' ==Appearance== Calmemunis is tall and broad of shoulder. His mouth is somewhat small. He wears a beard.''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 5 ==Personality== Calmemunis is arrogant, headstrong, and stupid.''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 10 ==Story== ===What Came Before=== Calmemunis fought in the [[Battle of Paremti]] under his cousin [[Nersei Proyas]], who had him whipped for impiety. Calmemunis and his men brought charges against him, both to the ecclesiastical courts and to the King. Proyas, humbled after a severe chatising from [[Krijates Xinemus]], offered to compensate Calmemunis lash for lash. Calmemunis accepted, whipping Proyas before the eyes of the King and court, not realizing until afterwards that in doing so he lost the high ground and gained the appearance of a petty, resentful oaf. Calmemunis claimed that Proyas had tricked him, and never forgave his cousin for this loss of honor. ===''The Darkness That Comes Before''=== Calmemunis is the first of the great [[Inrithi]] nobles to reach the [[Nansur Empire]] and join the [[Holy War]]. Believing the threat of the [[Fanim]] to be overstated, and worried that the glory of presiding over the Holy War's victory over them will be taken from him if he waits for more high-ranking nobles to arrive, Calmemunis leads the Vulgar Holy War to battle without waiting for reinforcements. He, and all who follow him, are subsequently massacred at the [[Fourth Battle of Mengedda]]. ==References== [[Category:Palatines]] [[Category:Characters from Conriya]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Vulgar Holy War]]

{{Character infobox | name = Arithmeas | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]'' | lived = ? - present | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = [[Nansur]] | gender = Male | occupation = Augur | relatives = }}
'''Arithmeas''' is the Prime Augur to [[Ikurei Xerius III]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Arithmeas'</ref>
Arithmeas is Xerius's favorite augur and astrologer. His appearance is described as portly and corpulent.<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 5</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Characters from Nansur]] [[Category:Augurs]]

{{stub}} {{Character infobox | name = Ikurei Istriya | titles = Empress | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]''
''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]''
''[[The Thousandfold Thought (Book)|The Thousandfold Thought]]''
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned) | lived = 4045 - c. 4112 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Ketyai]] | nationality = [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] | gender = Female | occupation = Empress of [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] | relatives = [[Ikurei Xerius III's father|Unnamed husband]]
[[Ikurei Xerius III|Xerius]] (son)
[[Ikurei Conphas' father|Unnamed son]]
[[Ikurei Conphas' half-sister|Unnamed daughter-in-law]] (possibly also granddaughter)
[[Ikurei Conphas|Conphas]] (grandson) }} '''Ikurei Istriya''' is the mother of Emperor [[Ikurei Xerius III]], once famed for her legendary beauty.Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Istriya, Ikurei’ At some point, Istriya is killed and replaced by a [[skin-spies|skin-spy]]. ==Appearance== Istriya once possessed a legendary beauty, but has grown wrinkled in her old age. ==Story== ===''What Came Before''=== The dowry of Istriya’s marriage to the Emperor of Nansur was the burning of the Imperial Harem.''The Darkness That Comes Before,'' Chapter 5 After the death of Xerius’s father, Istriya entered an incestuous relationship with him. More recently, she has turned her affections toward her grandson Conphas. ===''The Darkness That Comes Before''=== Istriya confronts Xerius about his plans to indenture the Holy War to return all former provinces of the [[Nansur Empire]]. As he tells her his full designs, she becomes increasingly alarmed at the risks involved, but he dismisses her warnings. ===''The Warrior-Prophet''=== ===''The Thousandfold Thought''=== ==References== [[Category:Characters from Nansur]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Empresses]] [[Category:Men]]

{{stub}} {{Character infobox | name = Cememketri | titles = Grandmaster | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]''
''[[The Thousandfold Thought (Book) | The Thousandfold Thought]]'' | lived = 4046 - 4112 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = [[Shiropti]] | gender = Male | occupation = Grandmaster of the [[Imperial Saik]] | relatives = }} '''Cememketri''' is the Grandmaster of the [[Imperial Saik]]Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Cememketri' ==Story== ===''The Thousandfold Thought''=== Cememketri is slain by [[Drusas Achamian]] during the battle for [[Shimeh]].''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 16 ==References== [[Category:Characters from Nansur]] [[Category:Imperial Saik]] [[Category:Grandmasters]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Anagogic sorcerers]]

{{Character infobox | name = Gaenkelti | titles = Exalt-Captain of the Eöthic Guard | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]'' | lived = 4068 - 4111 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Cepalor]]an | gender = Male | occupation = Exalt-Captain of the [[Eöthic Guard]] | relatives = }}
'''Gaenkelti''' is the Exalt-Captain of the Palatial [[Eöthic Guard]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Gaenkelti’</ref>
He is killed by the [[Skin-spies|skin-spy]] posing as [[Skeaös]].
==References== <references /> [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Characters from Cepalor]] [[Category:Members of the Eöthic Guard]]

The '''Eöthic Guard''' is the personal heavy infantry guard of the [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] Emperors, consisting primarily of [[Norsirai]] mercenaries from [[Cepalor]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Eöthic Guard’</ref>
==Known Members of the Eöthic Guard== * [[Gaenkelti]] * [[Skala]] * [[Imhailas]]

{{Character infobox | name = Pisathulas | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]''
''[[The Thousandfold Thought (Book) | The Thousandfold Thought]]'' | lived = ? - 4112 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = [[Nansur]] | gender = Male | occupation = Eunuch attendant to [[Ikurei Istriya]] | relatives = }} '''Pisathulas''' is the personal eunuch attendant of [[Ikurei Istriya]].Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Pisathulas’ He is killed by a [[skin-spy]] impersonating Istriya. ==References== [[Category:Characters from Nansur]] [[Category:Men]]

{{Character infobox | name = Ngarau | titles = Grand Seneschal | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]''
''[[The Thousandfold Thought (Book) | The Thousandfold Thought]]''
''[[The Judging Eye (Book) | The Judging Eye]]'' | lived = 4062 - | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = [[Nansur]] | gender = Male | occupation = Grand Seneschal | relatives = }} '''Ngarau''' is the Grand Seneschal to [[Ikurei Xerius III]].Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Ngarau' He continues to serve under Aspect-Emperor [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]].''The Judging Eye'', Prologue ==Story== ===''The Thousandfold Thought''=== After the death of Xerius, Ngarau temporarily handles matters in the [[Nansur Empire]] in the name of [[Ikurei Conphas]], hoping to curry favor in advance of his return from [[Kian]].''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 5 ==References== [[Category:Characters from Nansur]] [[Category:Men]]

{{Character infobox | name = Skeaös | titles = Prime Counsel | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]'' | lived = ? - ? | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = [[Nansur]] | gender = Male | occupation = Prime Counsel | relatives = }}
'''Skeaös''' is the Prime Counsel to [[Ikurei Xerius III]], having served in that capacity for thirty years.{{1|18}}
At some point, Skeaös was killed and replaced by a [[skin-spy]].
== Appearance and Personality == Skeaös is extremely old, with a shriveled and prune-like appearance, sunken cheeks and white hair. He has a cringing, obsequious manner around his superiors in contrast to his bold administrative tactics.
==Story==
===''The Darkness That Comes Before''===
Skeaös counsels Xerius's plans to seize control of the Holy War, and several others suspect that much of Xerius's daring plan was authored by Skeaös. During Xerius's meeting with Skauras, old rivals Skeaös and [[Cememketri]] get into an argument, which Xerius sees as a colossal embarrassment.
While walking up to the Andiamine Heights, Conphas notes that Skeaös has the endurance of a monkey for all his age. During their conversation, Skeaös claims that Xerius wanted to exclude Conphas from a meeting with the Scarlet Spires, which Conphas identifies as a lie. After some pressing, Skeaös admits that he sees the extermination of the [[Vulgar Holy War]] as a sin and fears for his soul. Conphas suspects that the lie was meant to put Conphas at odds with Xerius and rein the emperor in.
When [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]] comes for an audience with Xerius, he notices that Skeaös's face is false. Xerius, who is intensely paranoid, notices Kellhus's scrutiny of Skeaös and has him detained as a possible spy. Skeaös demonstrates superhuman ability in killing several of the men who attempt to apprehend him.
Xerius has [[Cememketri]] of the Imperial Saik and Skalateas of the Mysunsai to check Skeaös for the Mark of sorcery. Although Skeaös demonstrates superhuman immunity to pain under torture, the two grandmasters insist that they see no mark. Distrusting the Imperial Saik and doubting the Mysunsai's skill, Xerius asks [[Drusas Achamian]] for his opinion.
Upon seeing the [[Mandate]] Schoolman, Skeaös taunts him about the [[Consult]], referring to him as "[[Seswatha|Chigra]]." With superhuman strength, he breaks free, kills several people in the attendance and reveals himself to be a [[skin-spy]]. The Imperial Saik sorcerer blasts him, over Achamian's protests, but the skin-spy is still alive. He attempts to crush the skull of Achamian with his face limbs, but Conphas chops his head off.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Characters from Nansur]] [[Category:Men]]

{{Character infobox | name = Xunnurit | titles = Chieftain
King-of-Tribes | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]'' | lived = 4068 - present | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Scylvendi]] | nationality = [[Akkunihor]] | gender = Male | occupation = Chieftain of the Akkunihor
King-of-Tribes for the [[Battle of Kiyuth]] | relatives = [[Omiri urs Xunnurit]] (daughter) }} '''Xunnurit''' is the [[Scylvendi]] chieftain of the [[Akkunihor]] tribe, infamous for leading the Scylvendi to defeat at the [[Battle of Kiyuth]].Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Xunnurit' ==Appearance== Xunnurit is missing two fingers on his left hand.''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 6 ==Story== ===''The Darkness That Comes Before''=== Xunnurit is elected King-of-Tribes for the Battle of Kiyuth. He engages in a verbal battle with [[Cnaiür urs Skiötha]] over the host's tactics. Cnaiur urges that the host practice caution and bide its time to attack at a moment and place of their choosing. Xunnurit counters that they should strike quickly and decisively so that they can return home to bring their herds to summer pasture before the droughts begin. Xunnurit's skillful rhetoric and sly mockery of Cnaiur's past wins the support of the other chieftains, and he leads the Scylvendi in an immediate and all-out attack. The battle results in a disastrous defeat for the Scylvendi. After the battle, he is taken prisoner by [[Ikurei Conphas]] and brought back to [[Momemn]] in chains. There, he is tortured, mutilated and displayed as a symbol of Nansur triumph. ==References== [[Category:Characters from the Steppe]] [[Category:Scylvendi]] [[Category:Kings]]

'''Oknai One-Eye''' is the inveterate chieftain of the [[Munuäti]], a powerful federation of [[Scylvendi]] tribes.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Oknai One-Eye'</ref>
He is killed by [[sorcerer]]s of the [[Imperial Saik]] at the [[Battle of Kiyuth]].

[[Ikurei Conphas' half-sister|Unnamed half-sister]] }} '''Ikurei Conphas''' is the nephew of Emperor [[Ikurei Xerius III]] and heir apparent to the Imperial Mantle.Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Conphas, Ikurei’ ==Personality== Conphas is exceptionally conceited, to the point he becomes convinced of his own divinity. ==Story== ===''The Darkness That Comes Before''=== Conphas is charged with attacking the [[Scylvendi]] to ensure that the Nansur-Scylvendi border is safe during the [[Holy War]]. Conphas studies military history and realizes that their tactics can be predicted. Through a number of cunning maneuvers, he baits the Scylvendi horde into attacking and annihilates their [[Chorae]]-archers, allowing the [[Imperial Saik]] to emerge and obliterate the Scylvendi host. Upon arriving back at the [[Andiamine Heights]] for his triumph, he impulsively ponders assassinating his uncle Xerius, but backs down when he learns that the soldiers lining the parade ground are Xerius's men, not his own. When Xerius's plans to bend the [[Great Names]] into signing his [[indenture]] hit a rough patch, he adds Conphas's proven military genius as an incentive to sign. In the camps of the arriving Holy War at [[Momemn]], Conphas meets with [[Nersei Proyas]] and humiliates the prince in their verbal jousting. ===''The Warrior-Prophet''=== ===''The Thousandfold Thought''=== [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]] expels Conphas from [[Caraskand]], ordering him to return to [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] and sending [[Cnaiür urs Skiötha]] to watch over him. Cnaiür, who has been secret orders to assassinate Conphas, rapes him but does not kill him. Conphas subsequently escapes [[Joktha]], joins with reinforcements from Nansur, and attacks the city from without, killing all those loyal to Kellhus save for Cnaiür. Cnaiür is imprisoned, but promptly escapes with the aid of a [[skin-spies|skin-spy]] impersonating [[Biaxi Sompas]]. Upon receiving news of the death of Xerius, Conphas proclaims himself Emperor of Nansur. Conphas joins the battle in defense of [[Shimeh]], but his forces are decimated by [[Drusas Achamian]], and he is subsequently slain by [[Coithus Saubon]] as his Galeoth forces arrive. ==References== [[Category:POV characters]] [[Category:Characters from Nansur]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Members of the Imperial Army]] [[Category:Men]]

God-of-Men | nicknames = | lived = 4059 - 4112 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Ketyai]] | nationality = [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] | gender = Male | occupation = Emperor of [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] | relatives = [[Ikurei Anphairas I|Anphairas]] (grandfather)
[[Ikurei Xerius III's father|Unnamed father]]

[[Ikurei Conphas|Conphas]] (nephew) | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]''
''[[The Warrior Prophet]]''
''[[The Thousandfold Thought]]''
''[[The Judging Eye]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The White-Luck Warrior]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Great Ordeal]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned) }} '''Ikurei Xerius III''' was the Emperor of [[Nansur]] from 4081 until his assassination in 4112 ([[Year-of-the-Tusk]]). He is infamous for attempting to usurp the [[Holy War]] to his own ends using his Imperial [[Indenture]]. ==Appearance and personality== Xerius is paranoid, superstitious and excessively proud of himself—arrogant to the point of thinking himself divine.{{1|5}}{{1|8}} ==Story== ==='''''The Darkness That Comes Before'''''=== Ikurei Xerius III hatches an intricate plot to secure any lands conquered by the Holy War for the Nansur Empire. Much of what was then called heathen [[Kian]] once belonged to the Nansur, and recovering the Empire’s lost provinces is Xerius’s most fervent desire. Since the Holy War gathers in the Nansur Empire, it can march only if provisioned by the Emperor, something he refuses to do until every leader of the Holy War signs his Indenture, a written oath to cede all lands conquered to him. The first caste-nobles to arrive repudiate the Indenture, and a stalemate ensues. As the Holy War’s numbers swell into the hundreds of thousands, however, the titular leaders of the host begin to grow restless. Since they war in the God’s name, they think themselves invincible, and as a result see little reason to share the glory with those yet to arrive. A [[Conriya]]n noble named [[Nersei Calmemunis]] comes to an accommodation with the Emperor, and convinces his fellows to sign the Imperial Indenture. Once provisioned, most of those gathered march, even though their lords and a greater part of the Holy War have yet to arrive. Because the host consists primarily of lordless rabble, it comes to be called the [[Vulgar Holy War]]. Despite [[Maithanet]]’s attempts to bring the makeshift host to heel, it continues marching southward, and passes into heathen lands, where—precisely as the Emperor had planned—the [[Fanimry|Fanim]] destroy it utterly. Xerius knows that in military terms the loss of the Vulgar Holy War is insignificant, since the rabble that largely constituted it would have proven more a liability than an advantage in battle. In political terms, however, the Vulgar Holy War’s destruction is invaluable, because it has shown Maithanet and the [[Men of the Tusk]] the true mettle of their adversary. The Fanim, as the Nansur well know, are not to be trifled with, even with the God’s favour. Only an outstanding general, Xerius claims, can assure the Holy War’s victory—a man like his nephew, [[Ikurei Conphas]], who after his recent victory over the dread [[Scylvendi]] at the [[Battle of Kiyuth]] has been hailed as the greatest tactician of his age. The leaders of the Holy War need only sign the Imperial Indenture and Conphas’s preternatural skill and insight will be theirs. In an effort to forestall disaster Maithanet calls a Council of Great and Lesser Names, and all the leaders of the Holy War gather in the Emperor’s palace, the [[Andiamine Heights]], to make their arguments. There [[Nersei Proyas]] shocks the assembly by offering a many-scarred Scylvendi Chieftain, a veteran of past wars against the Fanim, as a surrogate for the famed Ikurei Conphas. The Scylvendi, [[Cnaiür urs Skiötha]], shares hard words with both the Emperor and his nephew, and the leaders of the Holy War are impressed. The Shriah’s Envoy, however, remains undecided: the Scylvendi are as apostate as the Fanim, after all. Only the wise words of Prince Anasûrimbor Kellhus of Atrithau settle the matter. The Envoy reads the decree demanding that the Emperor, under pain of Shrial Censure, provision the Men of the Tusk. And the Holy War marches. ==='''''The Warrior Prophet'''''=== Maithanet, the Shriah of the [[Thousand Temples]] summons Xerius to the temple of [[Xothei]] in [[Momemn]]. Maithanet asks Xerius if he has sealed a pact with the Fanim to betray the Holy War before it reaches [[Shimeh]], Xerius lies and denies the accusation.{{2|9}} ==='''''The Thousandfold Thought'''''=== Xerius is killed by a [[skin-spy]] impersonating his mother, [[Ikurei Istriya]], after the two attempt to copulate. He is succeeded by his nephew Ikurei Conphas.{{3|4}} ==References== [[Category:POV characters]] [[Category:Emperors]] [[Category:Characters from Nansur]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Men]]

{{Character infobox | name = Heänar Tharschilka | titles = Earl of Nergaöta | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]'' | lived = 4068 - 4110 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Galeoth]] | gender = Male | occupation = Earl of [[Nergaöta]] | relatives = }}
'''Heänar Tharschilka''' is the [[Galeoth]] Earl of [[Nergaöta]], and one of the three leaders of the [[Vulgar Holy War]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Tharschilka, Heänar’</ref>
==Story== ===''The Darkness That Comes Before''=== Along with [[Nersei Calmemunis]] and [[Akori Kumrezzer]], Tharschilka agrees to the [[Indenture]] so that he can be one of the leaders of the Vulgar Holy War, expecting to achieve glory with a quick victory over the [[Fanimry|Fanim]]. He is killed in the [[Fourth Battle of Mengedda]].
==References== <references /> [[Category:Characters from Galeoth]] [[Category:Earls]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Vulgar Holy War]]

{{Character infobox | name = Anissi | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]''
''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Thousandfold Thought]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned) | lived = ca. 4089 - 4113 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = Half-[[Scylvendi]], half-[[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Utemot]] | gender = Female | occupation = Wife of [[Cnaiür urs Skiötha]] | relatives = [[Cnaiür urs Skiötha|Cnaiür]] (husband)
[[Sanathi]] (daughter) }} '''Anissi''' was the favourite wife of [[Cnaiür urs Skiötha]]Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Anissi'. She was half-[[Norsirai]]''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 8. == Story == === What Came Before === Anissi married Cnaiür at an unknown date. They had at least one child together, a daughter named Sanathi. === ''The Darkness That Comes Before'' === Anissi is present when Cnaiür returns to the [[Utemot]] camp and kills [[Yursalka]] and his kin. She expresses relief at the fact he survived [[Battle of Kiyuth|Kiyuth]]. After Cnaiür finds [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Kellhus]], Anissi talks to her husband about him''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 12. She tells him Kellhus claimed the dead men found with him were from [[Atrithau]] and his followers. Anissi also confesses that she is as frightened of Kellhus as she is of Cnaiür himself. Later, Cnaiür strikes Anissi after he sees her weeping during his torture of Kellhus. She is also present (along with Cnaiür's other wives) when the two men depart. According to Kellhus, Cnaiür prizes Anissi above his other wives because she is the only one to weather his torment and still love him. He also believes Cnaiür's interest in [[Serwë]] is due to the fact that she reminds him of Anissi''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 13. === ''The Warrior-Prophet'' === As he thinks about Serwë, Cnaiür also imagines Anissi sleeping far away, holding their daughter [[Sanathi]] close''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 13. === ''The Thousandfold Thought'' === Anissi appears in one of Cnaiür's nightmares''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 5. === Later Events === Anissi died of unknown causes in 4113Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Anissi'. ==References== [[Category:Characters from the Steppe]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Scylvendi]] [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Mixed ethnicity]]

[[Cnaiür urs Skiötha]] kills her as revenge for his betrayal by Xunnurit and Yursalka at the [[Battle of Kiyuth]].<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before,'' Chapter 8</ref>

'''Nrezza Barisullas''' is the King of [[Cironj]], at once admired and maligned throughout the [[Three Seas]] for his mercantile ingenuity.
Nrezza is perhaps the wealthiest man in the Three Seas.<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 8</ref> He is notorious for surviving and managing to reverse Shrial Censure not once but three times.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Barisullas, Nrezza'</ref>

Aide to [[Ikurei Conphas]] | relatives = }} '''Martemus''' is a [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] General, and aide to [[Ikurei Conphas]].Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Martemus’ ==Appearance== Martemus has a broken nose. ==Personality== Martemus is extremely plainspoken, and only tells the truth. ==Story== ===''The Darkness That Comes Before''=== Martemus is present at the [[Battle of Kiyuth]]. ===''The Warrior-Prophet''=== Conphas instructs Martemus to spy on [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]], who he regards as a false prophet. He gives Martemus orders to kill Conphas; however, [[Cnaiür urs Skiötha]] kills him before he can perform the deed. ==References== [[Category:POV characters]] [[Category:Characters from Nansur]] [[Category:Members of the Imperial Army]] [[Category:Ketyai]]

[[Hoga Hogrim]] (nephew) }} '''Hoga Gothyelk''' is the Earl of [[Agansanor]], and leader of the [[Ce Tydonn|Tydonni]] contingent of the [[Holy War]].Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Gothyelk, Hoga’ ==Appearance== Gothyelk has a thick waist, long, iron-grey beard, a broad nose and overgrown brows.''The Darkness That Comes Before,'' Chapter 17 ==Story== === ''The Darkness That Comes Before'' === Gothyelk attends the meeting of the [[Great Names]] at [[Momemn]] at the start of the [[Holy War]]. He is loudly chastising his three sons also in attendance. [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]] sees the love he harbors for his sons beneath the father's stern expression. === ''The Warrior-Prophet'' === Gothyelk and his Tydonni host joins Coithus Saubon's Galeoth and the Thunyeri contingent to separate from the Holy War and attack [[Gedea]]. Along the way, Gothyelk's reckless intentions infuriate the more cautious Saubon. The two men nearly come to blows, and Gothyelk detaches from Saubon's host to go his own way, with the Thunyeri following. When Saubon arrives on the Battleplain, he eventually realizes that Gothyelk's host has been marching parallel with his own. The forces reunite and attack the Kianene together. Gothyelk is felled from his horse during the battle, but rescued by his sons. ===''The Thousandfold Thought''=== Gothyelk is slain by [[Fanayal ab Kascamandri]] during the battle of [[Shimeh]].''The Thousandfold Thought,'' Chapter 16 ===''The Judging Eye''=== In the twenty years since the end of the Holy War, Gothyelk has come to be known as “the Martyr of Shimeh.”''The Judging Eye,'' Chapter 10 ==References== [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Characters from Ce Tydonn]] [[Category:Earls]]

'''Agansanor''' is a fiefdom of south central [[Ce Tydonn]], noted for the martial zeal of its sons<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Agansanor’</ref>.
At the time of the [[Holy War|First Holy War]], it was ruled by Earl [[Hoga Gothyelk]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Gothyelk, Hoga’</ref>. Gothyelk was apparently eventually succeeded by [[Gaes Siklar]]<ref>''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 7</ref>.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Fiefdoms]]

{{Character infobox | name = Hringa Skaiyelt | titles = Prince of Thunyerus | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]''
''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]'' | lived = 4073 - 4111 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Thunyerus|Thunyeri]] | gender = Male | occupation = Prince of Thunyerus | relatives = [[Hringa Rauschang]] (father)
[[Hringa Hulwarga]] (brother)
[[Hringa Narradha]] (brother) }} '''Hringa Skaiyelt''' is the eldest son of King [[Hringa Rauschang]] of [[Thunyerus]] and leader of the Thunyeri contingent of the [[Holy War]]. He is claimed by disease at [[Caraskand]].Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Skaiyelt, Hringa’ ==Appearance== Skaiyelt has a wiry beard and long corn-silk hair. His face is uniformly scarred, as though by pox.''The Darkness That Comes Before,'' Chapter 17 ==References== [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Characters from Thunyerus]]

{{Character infobox | name = Hringa Hulwarga | titles = Prince of Thunyerus | nicknames = The Limper | appearances = ''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]''
''[[The Thousandfold Thought (Book)|The Thousandfold Thought]]'' | lived = 4086 - | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Thunyerus|Thunyeri]] | gender = Male | occupation = Prince of Thunyerus | relatives = [[Hringa Rauschang]] (father)
[[Hringa Skaiyelt]] (brother)
[[Hringa Narradha]] (brother) }} '''Hringa Hulwarga''' is the second son of King [[Hringa Rauschang]] of [[Thunyerus]], and leader of the Thunyeri contingent of the [[Holy War|First Holy War]] after the death of his older brother, Prince [[Hringa Skaiyelt]], in [[Caraskand]]. Called the Limper because of his uneven gait.Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Hulwarga, Hringa’ ==References== [[Category:Characters from Thunyerus]] [[Category:Norsirai]]

{{Character infobox | name = Imbeyan ab Imbaran | titles = Sapatishah-Governor | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]'' | lived = 4067 - 4111 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = [[Kian]]ene | gender = Male | occupation = Sapatishah-Governor | relatives = }}
'''Imbeyan ab Imbaran''' is the Sapatishah-Governor of [[Enathpaneah]] and son-in-law of Padirajah [[Kascamandri ab Tepherokar]], slain at [[Caraskand]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Imbeyan ab Imbaran'</ref>
==Story==
===''The Warrior-Prophet''===
Imbeyan and his retenue attempt to sneak out of Caraskand after it falls to the [[Holy War]], but are captured by a group of Shrial Knights. [[Incheiri Gotian]] has each of the Great Names of the Holy War place their boot on Imbeyan's face, an ancient ritual from the days of the [[Tusk]]. Imbeyan is then hung from a tree.<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 21</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Sapatishahs]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Characters from Kian]]

{{stub}} {{Character infobox | name = Kascamandri ab Tepherokar | titles = Padirajah of Kian | nicknames = | appearances = | lived = 4062 - 4112 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Ketyai]] | nationality = [[Kian]]ene | gender = Male | occupation = [[Padirajah]] of Kian | relatives = [[Fanayal ab Kascamandri]] (son)
[[Sirol ab Kascamandri]] (daughter) }} '''Kascamandri ab Tepherokar''' is the [[Padirajah]] of [[Kian]], slain by the Warrior-Prophet [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]] at the [[Battle of Caraskand|Battle of Tertae Fields]].Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kascamandri ab Tepherokar’ ==References== [[Category:POV characters]] [[Category:Characters from Kian]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Padirajahs]]

{{Character infobox | name = Kepfet ab Tanaj | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]'' | lived = 4061 - 4112 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = [[Kian]]ene | gender = Male | occupation = Soldier | relatives = }}
'''Kepfet ab Tanaj''' is the [[Kian]]ene officer who betrayed [[Caraskand]] to [[Coithus Saubon]] and the [[Holy War|First Holy War]] in 4111.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Kepfet ab Tanaj'</ref>
==Story==
===''The Warrior-Prophet''===
Kepfet exchanges missives and hostages with Saubon during the Holy War's siege of Caraskand. He and his compatriots' hatred for [[Imbeyan ab Imbaran]] is so great that they are willing to sacrifice Caraskand to see the Sapatishah-Governor dead. He opens one of the gates of Caraskand, allowing a group of raiders including Saubon and [[Cnaiür urs Skiötha]] to enter and open the Gate of Horns for the Holy War.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Characters from Kian]] [[Category:Ketyai]]

{{Character infobox | name = Aëngelas | titles = | nicknames = Aënga | appearances = ''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]'' | lived = 4087 - 4112 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Werigda]]n | gender = Male | occupation = Warrior | relatives = [[Bengulla]] (son)
[[Valrissa]] (wife) }} '''Aëngelas''' is a [[Werigda]]n warrior, and husband of the missing [[Valrissa]].Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Aëngelas’ He, his wife, and his son are raped and killed during an interrogation by [[Aurax]] seeking information about the [[Dûnyain]].''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 25 ==References== [[Category:POV characters]] [[Category:Characters from Akksersia]] [[Category:Werigda]]

{{Character infobox | name = Valrissa | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]'' | lived = 4086 - 4112 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Werigda]]n | gender = Female | occupation = Wife of [[Aëngelas]] | relatives = [[Bengulla]] (son)
[[Aëngelas]] (husband) }} '''Valrissa''' is a daughter of the [[Werigda]] and wife of [[Aëngelas]].Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Valrissa’ She, her husband, and her son are raped and killed during an interrogation by [[Aurax]] seeking information about the [[Dûnyain]].''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 25 ==References== [[Category:Characters from Akksersia]] [[Category:Werigda]] [[Category:Norsirai]]

{{Character infobox | name = Bengulla | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]'' | lived = 4103 - 4112 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Werigda]]n | gender = Male | occupation = | relatives = [[Aëngelas]] (father)
[[Valrissa]] (mother) }} '''Bengulla''' is the son of [[Aëngelas]] and [[Valrissa]].Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Bengulla’ He is raped and killed along with his parents during an interrogation by [[Aurax]] seeking information about the [[Dûnyain]].''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 25 ==References== [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Werigda]] [[Category:Characters from Akksersia]]

The '''Cants of Calling''' are the family of [[sorcery|sorcerous]] incantations that enable communications over distance. Though the metaphysics of these Cants is only loosely understood, all long-distance Cants of Calling seem to turn on the so-called Here Hypothesis. One can call only to slumbering souls (because they remain open to the [[Outside]]) and only to those residing someplace where the Caller has physically been. The idea is that the "Here" of the Caller can only reach a "There", or other location, that has been a "Here" sometime in the past. The degree of similarity between [[Anagogic]] and [[Gnostic]] Cants of Calling has led many to suspect that they hold the key to unravelling the GnosisEncyclopedic Glossary, p. 422, 'Cants of Calling'. ==Known Cants== ===Ishra Discursia=== The Ishra Discursia is the most ancient and most simple of the [[Gnostic]] Cants of Calling''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 6, p. 140. It consists of two strings in the Gilcûnya tongue, one utteral and the other inutteral, which must be spoken and thought simultaneously. The utteral is, ''"Iratisrineis lo ocoimenein loroi hapara..."''
The inutteral is, ''"Li lijineriera cui ashiritein hejaroit..."'' ==References== [[Category:Magic]]

revision.comment: Created page with "The '''Cants of Compulsion''' are the family of incantations that control the movements of an individual's soul. Typically these include the so-called Cants of Torment (the [[A..."
revision.text:
The '''Cants of Compulsion''' are the family of incantations that control the movements of an individual's soul.
Typically these include the so-called Cants of Torment (the [[Agonies]]), though not always. An insidious aspect of these Cants is that their subject often has no way of distinguishing [[sorcery|sorcerously]] compelled thoughts from his own thoughts. This has spawned a whole literature on the very notion of "will". If the compelled soul feels every bit as uncompelled as the free soul, then how can anyone truly know himself to be free?<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 422, 'Cants of Compulsion'</ref>.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Magic]]

'''Castes''' are inherited social statuses.
Though weaker in the so-called Middle North, the [[Inrithi]] caste system is one of the central institutions of [[Three Seas]] society. In a technical sense, there almost as many castes as there are occupations, but in practice they fall into roughly four different groups: the suthenti or laboring castes (caste-menial); the momurai or transactional castes (caste-apparati); the nahat or priestly castes (caste-priest); and the kijneta or warrior castes (caste-noble).
Elaborate [[jnan]]ic protocols supposedly govern all interactions within and between castes to ensure the observances of various privileges and obligations, as well as to minimize ritual pollution, but in practical terms they are rarely adhered to unless in the pursuit of advantage<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 423, 'castes'</ref>.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Culture]]

'''Jnan''' is an informal code of manner and speech understood by many to be a "war of word and sentiment".
Adeptness at jnan is understood, particularly by the more refined subcultures of the [[Three Seas]], to be the key determinant of status among individuals who are otherwise of equal caste of station. Given that the [[God]] is believed to be manifested in the movement of history, and history is determined primarily by the disparate statuses of men, for many jnan is understood as a sacred and not simply an instrumental enterprise. Many others, however, especially the [[Norsirai]] of the Three Seas, regard jnan with contempt, as a "mere game". Jnanic exchanges are typically characterized by concealed antagonism, the appreciation of irony and intellect, and the semblance of detached interest<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 456, 'jnan'</ref>.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Culture]]

{{Character infobox | name = Sheorog Cerjulla | titles = Earl of Warnute | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]'' | lived = 4069 - 4111 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Ce Tydonn|Tydonni]] | gender = Male | occupation = Earl of [[Warnute]] | relatives = [[Sheorog Gauslas]] (son) }}
'''Sheorog Cerjulla''' is the [[Ce Tydonn|Tydonni]] Earl of [[Warnute]].
==Story== ===''The Warrior-Prophet''=== During the [[Holy War]], men under the command of Cerjulla storm the walled town of [[Chiama]] and massacre all within.<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 11</ref>
Cerjulla later dies of disease during the siege of [[Caraskand]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Cerjulla, Sheorog’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Characters from Ce Tydonn]] [[Category:Earls]] [[Category:Norsirai]]

'''Cern Auglai''' is a fortress and pirate entrepôt located on the coast of [[Thunyerus]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Cern Auglai’</ref>
The Earl of Cern Auglai is [[Goken the Red]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Goken the Red’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

{{Character infobox | name = Trimus Charcharius | titles = Patridomos | nicknames = | appearances =''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]''
''[[The Thousandfold Thought (Book)|The Thousandfold Thought]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned) | lived = 4052 - 4114 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity =[[Ketyai]] | nationality =[[Nansur]] | gender = Male | occupation = Patridomos of [[House Trimus]] | relatives =[[Trimus Meniphas I]] (ancestor) }} '''Trimus Charcharius''' was the Patridomos of [[House Trimus]]Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Charcharius, Trimus'. == Story == === ''The Darkness That Comes Before'' === Charcharius was present at the traditional celebrations of the Feast of Kus­sapokari in [[Momemn]]''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 19. His House was out of favour with the [[Ikurei Xerius III|Emperor]] at the time. === Life in the New Empire === Charcharius died of unknown causes in 4114Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Charcharius, Trimus'. ==References== [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Characters from the Three Seas]]

{{Character infobox | name = Chepheramunni | titles = King-Regent | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]''
''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]'' | lived = 4068 - 4111 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = [[Ainon]]i | gender = Male | occupation = King-Regent of High Ainon | relatives = }} '''Chepheramunni''' is the King-Regent of [[High Ainon]], nominal leader of the Ainoni during much of the [[Holy War|First Holy War]], claimed by disease at [[Caraskand]].Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Chepheramunni' Upon his death, Chepheramunni is discovered to be a [[Consult]] [[skin-spy]].''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 23 It is unknown when the real Chepharmunni was killed and replaced. ==References== [[Category:Characters from High Ainon]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Kings]]

{{Character infobox | name = Musammu Chinjosa | titles = Count-Palatine of Antanamera
King-Regent of High Ainon | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]''
''[[The Thousandfold Thought (Book)|The Thousandfold Thought]]'' | lived = 4078 - | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Ketyai]] | nationality = [[High Ainon|Ainon]]i | gender = Male | occupation = Count-Palatine of [[Antanamera]]
King-Regent of High Ainon | relatives = }} '''Musammu Chinjosa''' is the Count-Palatine of the [[High Ainon|Ainon]]i palatinate of [[Antanamera]], appointed King-Regent of High Ainon shortly after [[Chepheramunni]]’s death in the winter of 4111.Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Chinjosa, Musammu’ ==Appearance== Chinjosa is a fair, large, burly man. He has a black, square-cut beard.''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 23 ==References== [[Category:Characters from High Ainon]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Palatines]]

{{Character infobox | name = Cinganjehoi ab Sakjal | titles = Sapatishah-Governor | nicknames = Tiger of Eumarna | appearances = ''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]''
''[[The Thousandfold Thought (Book)|The Thousandfold Thought]]'' | lived = 4076 - 4112 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Ketyai]] | nationality = [[Kian]]ene | gender = Male | occupation = Sapatishah-Governor of [[Eumarna]] | relatives = }} '''Cinganjehoi ab Sakjal''' is the famed [[Kian]]ene Sapatishah-Governor of [[Eumarna]], known among his people as “the Tiger of Eumarna.”Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Cinganjehoi ab Sakjal’ He has a son who after the Whelming has taken the name [[Inrilil ab Cinganjehoi|Inrilil]]. ==Story== ===''The Thousandfold Thought''=== During the battle for [[Shimeh]], Cinganjehoi slays [[Sheorog Gauslas]].''The Thousandfold Thought,'' Chapter 16 However, he is driven back and trapped by [[Nurbanu Soter]], and his head is taken by [[Sirpal Uranyanka]].''The Thousandfold Thought,'' Chapter 16 ==References== [[Category:Characters from Kian]] [[Category:Sapatishahs]] [[Category:Ketyai]]

{{Character infobox | name = Haarnan Cumor | titles = High Cultist of [[Gilgaöl]] | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]'' | lived = 4043 - 4111 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = | gender = Male | occupation = High Cultist of [[Gilgaöl]] | relatives = }}
'''Haarnan Cumor''' is the High Cultist of [[Gilgaöl]] in the [[Holy War]], claimed by disease at [[Caraskand]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Cumor, Haarnan’</ref>
==Appearance== Cumor is an older man, his square-cut beard as white as hoarfrost.<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 7</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Priests]] [[Category:Characters from the Three Seas]] [[Category:Men]]

{{Character infobox | name = Arnyalsa | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]'' | lived = ? - 4111 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = | gender = Male | occupation = Missionary priest | relatives = }}
'''Arnyalsa''' is a famed missionary priest.
He is killed by [[Galeoth]] freebooters marching south to join the [[Holy War]], who destroy seventeen villages in the course of their march. Because they leave no witnesses, their crimes are not discovered until they attempt to sell possessions looted from Arnyalsa at market in [[Sumna]]. [[Maithanet]] has the Shrial Knights kill all those responsible.<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 8</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Characters from the Three Seas]]

The '''Ballad of the Inchoroi''' is an ancient [[Kûniüri]] folk song. It recounts in poetic form a meeting between an [[Inchoroi]] Emissary and a [[Nonman]] King, likely [[Nin'janjin]]''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 9, p. 254. ==Excerpts== :''And the Nonman King cried words that sting:''
:''"Now to me you must confess,'' :''For death above you hovers!"'' :''And the Emissary answered ever wary:'' :''"We are the race of flesh,'' :''We are the race of lovers."'' ==References== [[Category:Written works]]

'''Sudica''' is a province of the [[Nansur Empire]], largely depopulated by 4111 but among the wealthiest districts of the [[Kyranae Plains]] during the ages of [[Kyraneas]] and the [[Ceneian Empire]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 491, 'Sudica'</ref>.
==Notable Structures== * [[Batathent]]
==References== <references/> [[Category:Provinces]]

{{Character infobox | name = Nentepi Psammatus | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]'' | lived = 4059 - | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = [[Nansur]] | gender = Male | occupation = Shrial Priest | relatives = }}
'''Nentepi Psammatus''' is a [[Sumna|Sumni]] Shrial Priest of [[Shigek]]i descent, and regular customer of [[Esmenet]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Psammatus, Nentepi'</ref>
==Appearance== Psammatus has willowy silver hair and a fatherly face.<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 9</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Priests]] [[Category:Characters from Nansur]] [[Category:Thousand Temples]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Characters from Shigek]]

{{stub}} {{Character infobox | name = Krijates Xinemus | titles = Marshal | nicknames = Zin | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]''
''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]''
''[[The Thousandfold Thought (Book) | The Thousandfold Thought]]'' | lived = 4066 - 4112 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Ketyai]] | nationality = | gender = Male | occupation = Marshal of [[Attrempus]] | relatives = [[Krijates Iryssas]] (cousin) }} '''Krijates Xinemus''' is the [[Conriya]]n Marshal of [[Attrempus]].Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Xinemus, Krijates' ==Appearance== Xinemus is burly, thick-bearded, and bears a striking resemblance to his friend [[Drusas Achamian]].''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 11 ==Story== === ''What Came Before'' === Xinemus was the sword tutor of [[Nersei Proyas]]. In this station, he first met Drusas Achamian, who was serving as the prince's academic tutor. In spite of Xinemus's piety, he befriended the sorcerer. Though Xinemus loves Proyas, he became increasingly alarmed when the prince began developing a rigid and fanatical faith. After Proyas had his cousin [[Nersei Calmemunis]] whipped for impiety, Xinemus commanded him to take up a practice sword and beat the young man bloody. Proyas later decided that the beating was a lesson about his stubbornness and became slightly more flexible and humble in his behavior. ===''The Darkness That Comes Before''=== Xinemus is present when [[Nersei Calmemunis]] meets with [[Ikurei Xerius III]]. Xinemus tries to caution Calmemunis against acting too rashly, but Calmemunis ignores him. Xinemus stays in Momemn when the [[Vulgar Holy War]] departs and awaits the arrival of the rest of the other lords. Xinemus is drinking with his subordinates when Achamian seeks him out. Some of the soldiers are not ready to accept a Schoolman in their midst, but Xinemus insists that they treat him with respect. The two old friends catch up. They next day, they play [[benjuka]]. Xinemus is a better player because he does not try to force victory, like Achamian. The pair discuss the Holy War and their thoughts on Proyas. ===''The Warrior-Prophet''=== Xinemus accompanies the Holy War as it marches, moving with the Conriyan host. Achamian, Kellhus, Cnaiur and Serwe share his fire, among others. ===''The Thousandfold Thought''=== ==References== [[Category:POV characters]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Characters from Conriya]]

{{Character infobox | name = Dinchases | titles = Captain | nicknames = Bloody Dinch | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]''
''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]'' | lived = 4074 - 4111 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = | gender = Male | occupation = Captain of [[Attrempus]] | relatives = }} '''Dinchases''' is a Captain of [[Attrempus]] and lifelong comrade-in-arms to [[Krijates Xinemus]], slain at [[Iothiah]].Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Dinchases' ==Appearance== Dinchases has an X-shaped scar on his forehead.''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 2 ==References== [[Category:Characters from Conriya]] [[Category:Ketyai]]

{{Character infobox | name = Zenkappa | titles = Captain of Attrempus | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]''
''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]'' | lived = 4068 - 4111 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Ketyai]] | nationality = [[Nilnamesh]]i | gender = Male | occupation = Slave
Captain of [[Attrempus]] | relatives = }} '''Zenkappa''' is a Captain of [[Attrempus]], formerly a [[Nilnamesh]]i slave belonging to the household of [[Krijates Xinemus]], slain at [[Iothiah]].Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Zenkappa’ ==References== [[Category:Slaves]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Characters from Nilnamesh]]

{{Character infobox | name = Krijates Iryssas | titles = Majordomo | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]''
''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]'' | lived = 4089 - | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Ketyai]] | nationality = | gender = Male | occupation = Majordomo of House Krijates | relatives = [[Krijates Xinemus]] (cousin) }} '''Krijates Iryssas''' is the young and impetuous majordomo of House Krijates, and cousin to [[Krijates Xinemus]].Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Iryssas, Krijates' ==Appearance== Iryssas has thick black hair. He has a stocky face with a square-cut beard.''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 14 == Story == Iryssas is one of Xinemus's three main subordinates. He does not welcome [[Drusas Achamian]] to Xinemus's fire, but Xinemus insists that he treat Achamian with respect. He does, though never forgetting that Achamian, as a sorcerer, is damned. As the Holy War begins marching, Iryssas gains a reputation for being slow-witted. His attempts to debate with [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Kellhus]] become a common occurrence around Xinemus's fire, to the amusement of the others. ==References== [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Characters from Conriya]]

{{Battle infobox | name = Battle of Zirkirta | partof = | date = 4103 | location = [[Jiünati Steppe]] | army1 = Scylvendi | army2 = Kianene | army3 = | result = Victory for the Scylvendi | army1leader = [[Yursut urs Muknai]] | army1participants = [[Cnaiür urs Skiötha]] | army2leader = [[Hasjinnet ab Skauras]] | army2participants = | army3leader = | army3participants = }}
The '''Battle of Zirkirta''' was a major battle fought between the [[Kian]]ene host of [[Hasjinnet ab Skauras]] and the [[Scylvendi]] under [[Yursut urs Muknai]] on the [[Jiünati Steppe]] in 4103.
Though their cavalry proved no match for the Scylvendi, and Hasjinnet himself was slain, the Kianene were quick in recovering, and most of the ill-fated expedition survived<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, p. 420, 'Battle of Zirkirta'</ref>.
==References== <references/> [[Category:War]] [[Category:Present Era]]

{{Character infobox | name = Panteruth urs Mutkius | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]'' | lived = 4075 - 4111 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Scylvendi]] | nationality = [[Munuäti]] | gender = Male | occupation = Warrior | relatives = }}
'''Panteruth urs Mutkius''' is a [[Scylvendi]] of the [[Munuäti]] tribe.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Panteruth urs Mutkius'</ref>
Panteruth is present at the [[Battle of Kiyuth]]. Afterwards, he and a band of warriors attack [[Cnaiür urs Skiötha]] and [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]] as they attempt to cross the [[Jiünati Steppe]]. Cnaiür kills him and takes possession of his slave, [[Serwë]].
==References== <references/> [[Category:Scylvendi]] [[Category:Characters from the Steppe]]

{{Character infobox | name = Serwë hil Keyalti | titles = | nicknames = Serchaa
The World | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]''
''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]''

''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned) | lived = 4090 or 4091[http://www.second-apocalypse.com/index.php?topic=2498.msg41889#msg41889 See here for estimation] - 4112 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Cepalor|Cepaloran]] ([[Nymbricani]]) | gender = Female | occupation = Concubine
Slave | relatives = [[Ingaera]] (father)
[[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Kellhus]] (husband)
Unnamed child
[[Anasûrimbor Moënghus II|Moënghus]] (son) }} '''Serwë hil Keyalti''' is a major character in the first two novels of ''[[The Prince of Nothing]]'', becoming the first wife of [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]]. ==Appearance== Serwë is an extremely beautiful young woman, with blond hair. ==Story== ===What Came Before=== Serwë's father sold her to House Gaunum as a concubine when she was fourteen. All of the children she bore the Gaunum men were strangled at birth, and the jealous wives would mock her "blue babies." However, when the [[Holy War]] was declared, all the men of the estate left to join it. The undefended villa was then sacked by [[Scylvendi]] of the [[Munuäti]] tribes, lead by [[Panteruth urs Mutkius]], and Serwë and a number of other women were taken as slaves. ===''The Darkness That Comes Before''=== [[Cnaiür urs Skiötha]] and Kellhus encounter and kill Panteruth. Though Cnaiür abandons the other slaves, he keeps Serwë and forces himself on her each night. When she goes to kill him in his sleep, Kellhus stops her. She quickly falls in love with Kellhus, who learns Sheyic from their conversations over the course of a few days. By day she spends all her time doting on Kellhus, but by night Cnaiür continues to force himself on her. She laments the fact that Kellhus won't kill Cnaiür and rescue her from him. When the group comes across a boy by a river, she warns the child to run away. As Cnaiür and Kellhus give chase, Serwë wanders the wilderness until she is accosted by two [[Kidruhil]] cavalrymen. One attempts to rape her, but Cnaiur appears and kills the lookout. Serwë stabs the other in the neck. Cnaiür cuts a [[swazond]] into her forearm for killing the man. While fleeing from a detachment of the Kidruhil, Serwë has difficulty keeping pace with Kellhus and Cnaiür. The Scylvendi recommends abandoning her, but Kellhus refuses. Serwë is solely Kellhus's companion. She falls asleep with her head on Kellhus's lap as Kellhus speaks with Achamian for the first time. In the camp of the Holy War, she has more prestige because she is the concubine of Kellhus, a respected man of rank. She still laments the fact that Kellhus will not rescue her from Cnaiür. She interrupts Kellhus while he is studying holy texts, and he tells her that she has worth, which causes her to break down in sobs. The pair have sex, and Serwë makes a point of letting Cnaiür see and hear the passion she has for Kellhus rather than him. ===''The Warrior-Prophet''=== In [[Caraskand]], Serwë gives birth to the infant [[Anasûrimbor Moënghus II|Moënghus]]. Following the Great Names' denouncement of [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Kellhus]] as a False Prophet, Serwë is executed by a [[Skin-spy|Skin-Spy]] impersonating [[Cutias Sarcellus|Sarcellus]]. Her naked corpse is bound to Kellhus and the two are lashed to a circumfix and hung from a [[Umiaki|great tree]] to die of exposure. Kellhus miraculously survives this ordeal and standing before the exultant masses, he reaches into his own chest and brandishes "Serwë’s burning heart". ==Notes== ==References== [[Category:POV characters]] [[Category:Characters from Cepalor]] [[Category:Concubines]] [[Category:Slaves]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Men]]

''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' | lived = 4082 or 4083[http://www.second-apocalypse.com/index.php?topic=2498.msg45214#msg45214 See here for estimation] - 4132 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Ketyai]] | nationality = [[Conriya]]n | gender = Male | occupation = Crown Prince of Conriya
King of Conriya
Exalt-General | relatives = [[Nersei Eukernas II|Eukernas II]] (father)
[[Nersei Thaila (elder)|Thaila]] (mother)
[[Nersei Tirummas|Tirummas]] (brother)
[[Nersei Calmemunis|Calmemunis]] (cousin)
[[Nersei Sodhoras|Sodhoras]] (cousin)
[[Miramis]] (wife)
[[Nersei Xinemus|Xinemus]] (son)
[[Nersei Thaila (younger)|Thaila]] (daughter) }} '''Nersei Proyas''' is the Crown Prince of [[Conriya]]. ==Appearance== As a Conriyan, Proyas has a dark complexion. He is not tall, but has a noble, impressive bearing nonetheless. Female characters call him "the handsome prince". ==Story== ===''What Came Before''=== Proyas was a student of [[Drusas Achamian]] in his youth. The two shared a close bond, and Achamian loved him, but Proyas turned away from Achamian after becoming a devout follower of Inrithism. [[Krijates Xinemus|Xinemus]] was his swordsmanship tutor. ===''The Darkness That Comes Before''=== Proyas is a devoted follower of Maithanet, and he is present beside Maithanet as the Shriah announces the target of the [[Holy War]]. He recognizes Achamian when the Mandate sorcerer is crowd-surfed to Maithanet's side. He is outraged by the blasphemy in spite of his former devotion to Achamian. Afterwards, Maithanet brings him to witness the [[Tusk]] for the first time. Proyas joins the Holy War as one of its Great Names. leading his contingent of Conriyans. Upon first meeting Ikurei Conphas, the two men develop an instant rivalry and hatred for each other. ===''The Warrior-Prophet''=== Proyas marches with the Holy War leading his Conriyans. When [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Kellhus]] convinces [[Coithus Saubon]] to separate from the rest of the Holy War and take his [[Galeoth]] host to attack [[Gedea]] , Proyas angrily confronts Kellhus at Xinemus's fire. Onlookers are shocked by Proyas's disrespectful treatment of Kellhus. Before leaving in a huff, Proyas accuses Kellhus of dooming the Holy War. ===''The Thousandfold Thought''=== ===''The Judging Eye''=== Proyas is King of Conriya and one of the Exalt-Generals of the Great Ordeal. === ''The Great Ordeal'' === He is deeply hurt and puzzled when Kellhus confesses he is not a true prophet but is just a mad man. While he is experiencing emotional turmoil from this revelation, Kellhus drugs both their wine with chanv and has brutal sex with Proyas. Later he seeks out [[Coithus Saubon]] and in tears confesses the forced sodomy and shares Kellhus's confession. Proyas realizes his buggering may be a test as much for Saubon as for himself. Saubon convinces him that Kellhus is testing them but states they must continue to act even in they lose faith as Kellhus will lead them to victory at [[Golgotterath]]. {{6|4}} At [[Dagliash]], his heart is battered by the proportion of the slaughter of [[Sranc]]. He wonders why he doesn't share in the joy of the others.{{6|13}} After the explosion of the mountain, Kellhus comes to Proyas and takes him to a mountain top and explains the great and tragic victory that has polluted the land. Kellhus explains that Saubon is dead and as lone Exalt General Proyas must rally the remaining Ordeal host and go North. He charged him with keeping everyone away from the polluted land and he must cull the sick suffering from seeming radiation poisoning. Kellhus prepares him that he is the only one who can lead and make decisions that no Believer can saying "''Something'' must eaten."{{6|15}} ==Notes== ==References== [[Category:POV characters]] [[Category:Characters from Conriya]] [[Category:Kings]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Great Ordeal]]
