Unnamed nephew or niece|nationality = [[New Empire]]}} {{Blockquote|Something must be eaten.|Anasûrimbor Kayûtas}} '''Anasûrimbor''' '''Kayûtas '''is the first son and eldest child of [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Kellhus]] and [[Esmenet]], and General of the [[Kidruhil]]. He was named after [[Anasûrimbor Nau-Cayûti]]''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 17. ==Appearance== Kayûtas closely resembles his father, Kellhus. He is tall and slender, and has blond hair''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 10, blue eyes''The Great Ordeal'', Chapter 13 and a long face''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 7. His hair is cropped very short, revealing the contours of his skull (however, by the time the Great Ordeal reaches [[Agongorea]], it has grown enough to be described as "flowing")''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 5. He has a plaited beard. ==Story== === ''What Came Before'' === Kayûtas was born in [[Shimeh]], close enough to Moënghus's birth that the two were raised as fraternal twins''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 3. ===''The Judging Eye''=== Kayûtas rides with his father's [[Great Ordeal]], leading the Kidruhil''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 1. ===''The White-Luck Warrior''=== At the Eleventh Council of Potentates, Anasûrimbor Kellhus declares the breaking of the Great Ordeal, and Kayûtas is given command of the Men of the Middle North''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 2. === ''The Great Ordeal'' === ===''The Unholy Consult''=== At the first Council after [[Dagliash]], Prince [[Nurbanu Ze]] openly confronts Proyas, claiming that Kellhus died in the fire. Kayûtas slays him in the blink of an eye, restoring the Anasûrimbor authority over the Great Ordeal. Despite his Dunyain origins, Kayûtas, along with the whole Ordeal, succumbs to the Meat. He and the Exalt-General Nersei Proyas become lovers for some time. It is Kayûtas who bids Proyas accept cannibalism, claiming that ''something must be eaten''. As the Great Ordeal falls on the Scalded, Kayûtas does participate. When [[Anasûrimbor Serwa|Serwa]] and Sorweel see him, the kilt on his groin is stained with blood, implying that he took part in the unholy congress with dead or dying Ordealmen. Later on, Kayûtas is involved in the assault at [[Golgotterath]]. He and his sister Serwa fight the great dragon [[Scuthula]] guarding the [[Intrinsic Gate]]. Kayûtas' fate after the Resumption is unclear. ==Notes== ==References== [[Category:Dûnyain]] [[Category:Anasûrimbor]] [[Category:Members of the Kidruhil]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Characters from the New Empire]] [[Category:Prince-Imperials]] [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Great Ordeal]] [[Category:Mixed ethnicity]]

''[[The Unholy Consult]]''|nicknames = Podi}}''' '''Anasûrimbor Moënghus II''' is officially the son of [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Kellhus]] and his first wife, [[Serwë]], thus being the eldest of the Prince-Imperials. In truth, he is Serwë's son by [[Cnaiür urs Skiötha]]. ==Appearance== Moënghus strongly resembles his biological father, Cnaiür''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 7''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 15. He has a mane of black hair''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 2, pale blue ("white-blue") eyes''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 2''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 13 and pale skin''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 2. He is described as having a "neck-breaking physique". His features are somewhat more aquiline than Cnaiür's. ==Story== === ''The Warrior-Prophet'' === Moënghus was born in [[Caraskand]] in the early winter of 4111''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 20. After Serwë's death, he was taken by [[Esmenet]] and raised as one of her children''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 3. === ''The Thousandfold Thought'' === ===''The Judging Eye''=== Moënghus marches with his father, [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Kellhus]], in the Great Ordeal. [[Anasûrimbor Kayûtas|Kayutas]] warns [[Varalt Sorweel III|Sorweel]] that Moënghus is mad. ===''The White-Luck Warrior''=== Moënghus, [[Anasûrimbor Serwa|Serwa]], and Sorweel are sent to the [[Nonmen|Nonman]] [[Mansion]] of [[Ishterebinth]] as [[Niom]]. === ''The Great Ordeal'' === Moënghus is tortured in Ishterebinth.{{6|9}} ===''The Unholy Consult''=== ==References== [[Category:Scylvendi]] [[Category:Prince-Imperials]] [[Category:Anasûrimbor]] [[Category:Characters from the New Empire]] [[Category:Men]] [[Category:POV characters]] [[Category:Great Ordeal]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Mixed ethnicity]]

Unnamed nephew or niece|nationality = [[New Empire]]}} '''Anasûrimbor''' '''Theliopa''' was the eldest daughter and second child of [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Kellhus]] and [[Esmenet]]. Over the course of the [[Aspect-Emperor (Title)|Aspect-Emperor]] series, she remained with her mother in [[Momemn]] in her capacity as Imperial Adviser''The White-Luck Warrior'', What Has Come Before. ==Appearance== Theliopa was tall and pale-skinned like her father, with sallow blonde hair and pale blue eyes''The Great Ordeal'', Chapter 3. She was thin to the point of emaciation, her features angular and her skin being referred to as "tented over the woodwork of her bones"''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 3. She was known for wearing outlandish garments of her own design and arranging her hair in equally eccentric hairstyles. == Personality == Theliopa was remarkably intelligent, but almost completely devoid of emotion and oblivious to most social norms. She almost always avoided meeting other people's gazes''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 5, her stare being very intense on the rare occasions she did so''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 5. She spoke with a very high and cold voice and possessed a verbal tic that manifested as the repetition of certain words. She was an avid reader, remembering all she read with perfect detail''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 6. However, she was so consumed by her interests she often forgot to eat or sleep, having to be forced to do so (the latter situation resulting in her emaciated state). ==Story== === ''What Came Before'' === Theliopa was born in [[Nenciphon]] during the [[Unification Wars]]Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Unification Wars', probably in or around the winter of 4113. Due to her prodigious intellect and memory, she was made an Imperial Adviser at the age of twelve. At some point during her youth, she underwent a traumatic experience (presumably involving rape) at the hands of her brother [[Anasûrimbor Inrilatas|Inrilatas]]. This was likely the catalyst for Kellhus' decision to imprison his son (it is implied Esmenet never learned about this). This event remained the only thing to cause Theliopa to show any kind of emotion, as [[Anasûrimbor Kelmomas|Kelmomas]] discovered years later''The Great Ordeal'', Chapter 16. ===''The Judging Eye''=== Theliopa was one of her mother's closest advisers in the [[Andiamine Heights]], using her [[Dûnyain]] mental abilities to provide detailed reports and oversee Esmenet's meetings with various dignitaries. She was also the one to detect a [[skin-spy]] among the stable slaves in Momemn. She was present when [[Anasûrimbor Samarmas|Samarmas]] was killed in an accident engineered by Kelmomas, the latter describing her as observing the scene "with fey curiosity". ===''The White-Luck Warrior''=== After Esmenet started to mistrust [[Maithanet]], she asked her daughter for advice on how to gauge his true intentions. Theliopa eventually suggested that Inrilatas could read their uncle's face, as he had been the only one trained to do so by their father. When the Andiamine Heights were stormed by Maithanet's men in the coup following Inrilatas' murder, Theliopa told her brother Kelmomas to run. Later, during Maithanet's reconciliation with Esmenet, he told her that Theliopa was safe. ===''The Great Ordeal''=== Theliopa advised her mother against forgiving [[Naree]] for betraying her location (and indirectly causing [[Imhailas]]' death). She offered to kill Naree herself, but Esmenet declined. It is revealed that Theliopa had grown increasingly suspicious of Kelmomas's behaviour since the events following Maithanet's murder of Inrilatas. She confronted her younger brother, telling him that she had figured out that he was more than he seemed, and asked him if he had been the one to kill [[Biaxi Sankas]]. When Kelmomas denied it, she left him alone, but not before threatening him, as Momemn needed its Empress, and Kelmomas was making her weak (and the revelation of his crimes would make the situation even worse). Later, while Esmenet was giving Kelmomas a bath, Theliopa arrived to inform her mother that General [[Iskaul]] had arrived. Esmenet promptly left, asking her daughter to finish bathing Kelmomas. Theliopa then told her brother that she knew that he had made the decision to kill her. Kelmomas, in turn, brought up the past incident between her and Inrilatas, reminding her of how he would call her "Sranky". Overcome by uncharacteristic emotion, she quickly fled the room. Some time after that, Kelmomas tracked the [[White-Luck Warrior]] to his own bedroom. He watched as Theliopa walked in and confronted the White-Luck Warrior, who made it clear that she was "already dead", him just being "someone who was there when it happened". At the end of their conversation, an earthquake wracked the city, causing Theliopa to be crushed by falling debris. After the White-Luck Warrior left the now-destroyed room, Kelmomas walked to Theliopa and smashed her head with a brick to make sure she was dead. He then pretended to cry over her body. By the time a grieving Esmenet found her daughter's body, she caught a glimpse of Kelmomas' joyful expression. == Trivia == * Theliopa is the only one of Kellhus and Esmenet's children not to have a clear or probable namesake. [[Anasûrimbor Kayûtas|Kayûtas]], [[Anasûrimbor Serwa|Serwa]] and [[Anasûrimbor Kelmomas|Kelmomas]] are explicitly named after [[Anasûrimbor Nau-Cayûti]], [[Serwë]] and [[Anasûrimbor Celmomas II]], respectively''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 17''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 15''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 13. [[Anasûrimbor Inrilatas|Inrilatas]]' name is likely derived from that of [[Inri Sejenus]], while [[Anasûrimbor Samarmas|Samarmas]]' is quite similar to those of [[Samarmau Uän]] or [[Sag-Marmau]]. ==Notes== ==References== [[Category:Prince-Imperials]] [[Category:Anasûrimbor]] [[Category:Dûnyain]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Characters from the New Empire]] [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Mixed ethnicity]]

He inherited more of his father's traits than any his siblings.{{4|3}}{{5|5}} ==Appearance== Inrilatas has a long face, blue eyes, and a mane of golden hair''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 5. He has stubble covering his chin and the line of his jaw, but not reaching his cheeks. He possesses a muscular body. ==Story== === ''What Came Before'' === Inrilatas spent most of his time screaming and raving in his locked room.{{4|12}} ===''The Judging Eye''=== ===''The White-Luck Warrior''=== He was killed by [[Maithanet]] after he tried to strangle him.{{5|8}} === ''The Great Ordeal'' === ==Notes== ==References== [[Category:Anasûrimbor]] [[Category:Characters from the New Empire]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Dûnyain]] [[Category:Prince-Imperials]] [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Mixed ethnicity]]

'''The Disciple Manning''' is a series of novels following [[R. Scott Bakker]]'s Detective Disciple Manning. It consists of the novel [[Disciple of the Dog|Disciple of The Dog]] and the rumoured second title [[The Enlightened Dead]].
==Premise== No matter how hard he drinks, gambles, or womanizes, Disciple Manning simply cannot forget: not a word spoken, not an image glimpsed, not a pain suffered. Disciple Manning has total recall. Whatever he hears, he can remember with 100% accuracy. He can play it back in his head for an infinite number of times without a single change. This ability makes him a dangerously unorthodox private investigator. [[Category:Other Works]]

{{Template:Infobox book |name = Disciple of The Dog |image = [[Image:8584168.jpg|250px]] |series = [[The Disciple Manning Series|Discilple Manning]] |author = [[R. Scott Bakker]] |publisher = Penguin (Canada), Orion (UK), Forge Books (US) |release_date = 2010 |pages = 287 |followed_by = [[The Enlightened Dead]] (Rumoured)}}'''Disciple of The Dog''' is the first title in [[R. Scott Bakker]]'s[[The Disciple Manning Series| Discilple Manning series]]. It was first published in 2010.
[[The Enlightened Dead]] is a rumoured followup, although there are more rumoures that it may never be published due to the low volume of sales that Disciple of The Dog has generated.
==Premise==
No matter how hard he drinks, gambles, or womanizes, Disciple Manning simply cannot forget: not a word spoken, not an image glimpsed, not a pain suffered. Disciple Manning has total recall. Whatever he hears, he can remember with 100% accuracy. He can play it back in his head for an infinite number of times without a single change. This ability makes him a dangerously unorthodox private investigator.
When a New Jersey couple hires Manning to find their daughter, who joined a religious cult before vanishing in a small rust-belt town called Ruddick, he finds himself embroiled in a mystery that will pit his unnatural ability to remember against his desperate desire to forget. [[Category:Other Works]]

Rumoured second title in the series following [[The Disciple Manning Series|Detective Disciple Manning]].<ref>[https://rsbakker.wordpress.com/2011/01/27/t-zero/ T-Zero]</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Other Works]]
[[Category:Cover art]]

Hi. I’ve given you admin and bureaucrat rights on this wikia as you requested. You now have the tools you need to clean up, customize and maintain the wikia.
*Check out [[Special:WikiFeatures|Wiki Features]] to see which features you can enable (or disable) on your wikia, including [[Help:Chat|chat]], [[Help:Forum|forum]], and many more. If you have adopted an older wikia with talk pages you can also enable [[Help:Message Wall|message walls]] and [[Help:Comments|article comments]] here. *Customize your wikia's look by visiting the [[Special:ThemeDesigner|Theme Designer]], where you can add color and style to your background and wordmark. *Stop by [[w:c:community|Community Central]] to stay informed through our [[w:c:community:Blog:Wikia_Staff_Blog|staff blog]], ask questions on our [[w:c:community:Special:Forum|community forum]], or [[w:c:community:Special:Chat|chat]] with fellow Wikians. *Lastly, visit our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] to learn the ins and outs of using Wikia, including [[Help:Community_Management|tips for managing your community]], [[Help:Attracting contributors|how to attract contributors]], and [[Help:User access levels|how to add other admins]].
Check out your Admin Dashboard, which can by found by clicking "Admin" on the bottom toolbar -- it has links to all your new tools. Please let me know if you have any questions, and good luck with your new (old) wikia! -- [[User:Merrystar|<font color="Blue">Wendy</font>]] ([[User talk:Merrystar|<font color="Blue" size="1">talk</font>]])<staff /> 04:01, March 31, 2014 (UTC)

{{Template:Infobox book |name = Neuropath |image = [[Image:neuropath.jpg|250px]] |author = [[R. Scott Bakker]] |publisher = Penguin (Canada), Orion (UK), Tor Books (US) |release_date = 2008 |pages = 320}}'''Neuropath''' is a psychological thriller written by [[R. Scott Bakker]] and first published in 2008. It follows the Point of View of Thomas Bible, a psychology professor, who is recruited by the FBI in order to help them track down his best friend Neil Cassidy, a neurologist in the employment of the NSA, who has gone rogue and is apparently abducting people and re-wiring their brains as part of an elaborate attempt to demonstrate the illusory nature of the self and much of consciousness.
==Book Description==
Tom's life is not what it once was. His marriage is on the rocks and he is barely allowed to see his two young children. His writing career has stalled with only one successful book, and he is forced to spend his time teaching bored grad students. Then his best friend, Neil, returns from teaching neurology in California and comes back into Tom's life. But all is not what it seems--Neil has been working for the U.S. government cracking the minds of suspected terrorists and has gone AWOL, leaving behind evidence that he has been employing his unique skills on civilians.
Thus begins a terrifying sequence of events as Neil, obsessed with the fact that he can control the human brain, sets out to destroy those who are connected to Tom. And it's only when Neil gets closer to his ultimate target that the full horror of his plan is revealed. [[Category:Other Works]]
[[Category:Cover art]]

{{Stub}}{{Character_infobox |name = Psatma Nannaferi |titles = Mother Supreme |race = Men |gender = Female |occupation = Mother Supreme of the Cult of Yatwer |appearances = ''[[The Judging Eye (Book)|The Judging Eye]]''
''[[The White-Luck Warrior (Book)|The White-Luck Warrior]]}} '''Psatma Nannaferi''' is Mother-Supreme of the [[The Cult of Yatwer|Cult of Yatwer]], a position long outlawed by the [[Thousand Temples]]. She prophesied the coming of the [[White-Luck Warrior]], the god-sent assassin who will murder the Aspect-Emperor and his progeny. ==Appearance== ==Story== ===The Judging Eye=== ===The White-Luck Warrior=== ===The Unholy Consult=== ==References== [[Category:POV characters]] [[Category:Priests]] [[Category:Ketyai]]

'''The Cult of Yatwer''' is the traditional Cult of the slave and menial castes, taking as its primary scriptures, The [[The Chronicle of the Tusk|Chronicle of the Tusk]], the [[Higarata]], and the [[Sinyatwa]]. [[Yatwer]] is the [[Gods|Goddess]] of the earth, fertility and servitude.<ref>''The White-Luck Warrior'', Character and Faction Glossary</ref><ref name=":0">''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 5</ref>
According to census records, six out of ten caste-menials regularly attend some form of Yatwerian rite, making Yatwer the most popular of the Hundred Gods.<ref name=":0" />
Despite the vast numbers of adherents enjoyed by the Cult, it remains one of the more impoverished, and generates a huge number of zealous devotees as a result.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Yatwer'</ref>
==Members==
*'''[[Psatma Nannaferi]]'''— Mother-Supreme of the Cult..
*'''[[Hanamem Sharacinth]]'''— Matriarch of the Cult.
*'''[[Sharhild]]'''— High-Priestess of the Cult.
*'''[[Vethenestra]]'''— Chalfantic Oracle.
*'''[[Eleva]]'''— High-Priestess of the Cult.
*'''[[Maharta]]'''— High-Priestess of the Cult.
*'''[[Phoracia]]'''— High-Priestess of the Cult. *'''[[Aethiola]]'''— High-Priestess of the Cult.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cults]]

One of the Elder Scriptures<ref>The Judging Eye, Chapter Five</ref>, a collection of subsidiary writings that form the scriptural core of the Cults.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Gierra'</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Religious texts]]

{{Character infobox | name = Yatwer | image = [[Image:Yatwer.jpg|260px]] | caption = Art by [http://spiralhorizon.deviantart.com/ Spiralhorizon] | titles = | nicknames = Ur-Mother
Mother of Wombs
Mother of Birth
Goddess of the Earth and Fertility | lived = | race = Gods | ethnicity = | nationality = | gender = | occupation = | relatives = [[Gilgaöl]] (brother)
[[White-Luck Warrior]] (son) | appearances = ''[[The Judging Eye (Book)|The Judging Eye]]''
''[[The White-Luck Warrior (Book)|The White-Luck Warrior]]''
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' }} '''Yatwer''' is the Goddess of the Earth and Fertility, and one of the so-called Compensatory [[Gods]], who reward devotion in life with paradise in the afterlife.{{EG|Yatwer}} Her symbol is a harvest sickle that also forms the outline of a pregnant belly.{{4|5}} Yatwer is a point of view character in ''[[The White-Luck Warrior (Book)|The White-Luck Warrior]]''. Her point of view is the only God point of view in the series.{{5|10}} ==Depiction in the Holy Texts== In the ''[[Higarata]]'', Yatwer is depicted as a beneficent, all-forgiving matron, capable of seeding and furrowing the fields of nations with a single hand. Some commentators have noted that Yatwer is anything but revered in either the ''Higarata'' or ''[[The Chronicle of the Tusk]]'' (wherein “tillers of soil” are often referred to with contempt). Perhaps this is why Yatwerians tend to rely on their own scripture, the ''[[Sinyatwa]]'', for their liturgical rites and ceremonies.{{EG|Yatwer}} ==Cult of Yatwer== : ''Main article: [[Cult of Yatwer]]'' Yatwer is far and away the most popular of the [[Cults|Cultic]] [[Gods|Deities]], she is especially favoured by the lower [[caste|castes]] — some six out of ten caste-menials regularly attend a Yatwerian rite. Based in [[Iothiah]], her Cult enjoys a vast number of adherents, but despite that, it remains one of the more impoverished and seems to generate a large number of zealous devotees as a result.{{EG|Yatwer}} ==Story== ===''The Judging Eye''=== Yatwer manifests as a shadow to the Mother-Supreme of the Cult of Yatwer, [[Psatma Nannaferi]], and informs her that the [[White-Luck Warrior]] has arrived, and that the “Demon,” the [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Aspect-Emperor]], will be driven to his doom.{{4|5}} ===''The White-Luck Warrior''=== Yatwer appears to [[Varalt Sorweel]] and hands him a pouch with a [[Chorae]] in it.{{5|10}} ==References== [[Category:POV characters]] [[Category:Gods]] [[Category:Characters from the Outside]]

{{Character infobox | name = Anasûrimbor Omindalea | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Thousandfold Thought]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned) | lived = 808 - 825 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Ûmeri Empire|Ûmeri]] | gender = Female | occupation = | relatives = [[Anasûrimbor Sanna-Neorjë|Sanna-Neorjë]] (father)
At least one unnamed sisterAs Omindalea is referred to as Sanna-Neorjë's "first daughter", this means he had at least one other younger daughter.
[[Anasûrimbor Sanna-Jephera|Sanna-Jephera]] (son) }} '''Anasûrimbor Omindalea''' was the first daughter of [[Anasûrimbor Sanna-Neorjë|Sanna-Neorjë]] of the house Anasûrimbor[http://forum.three-seas.com/posts/4944 R. Scott Bakker on Three Seas Forum]. She was raped in 824 by [[Jiricet]], a [[Nonmen|Nonman]] [[Siqû]]. This rape resulted in pregnancy, and Omindalea eventually died giving birth to her son, [[Anasûrimbor Sanna-Jephera|Sanna-Jephera]], in 825. ==Notes== ==References== [[Category:Characters from the Ûmeri Empire]] [[Category:Anasûrimbor]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Men]]

[[File:BreakingtheGates.jpg|thumb|300px|Just having some fun. A depiction of the Breaking of the Gates, done in a faux Sumerian style.]] The '''Gates of Eärwa''' or '''Gates of Thayant''' are a series of fortified passes through the [[Great Kayarsus|Great Northern Kayarsus]] Mountains. Their precise location is not known, but is assumed to be north of the [[Cerish|Sea of Cerish]], possibly in the vicinity of the long-fallen [[Nonmen|Nonman]] [[Mansion]] of [[Siöl]]. Some historians hold that the Gates and Siöl are one and the same, and the Breaking of the Gates also refers to the destruction of the mansion of Siöl.
==The Breaking of the Gates== The name given to the assault on the Gates of Eärwa by four of the [[Five Tribes of Men]] from [[Eänna]]. The commandment of [[Gods|the Gods]] to throw down the [[Mansion|mansions]] of the "[[Nonmen|Not Us]]" was given to [[Angeshraël]] on [[Mount Eshki]] and was enscribed on the [[The Chronicle of the Tusk|Tusk]]. Men were led by the Chieftan Kings: [[Mamayma]], [[Inshull]], [[Shelgal]], [[Nomur|Nomer]], and [[Uskelt Wolfheart]]. Since ''[[The Chronicle of the Tusk]]'' ends with the determination to invade [[Eärwa]], or the “Land of the Felled Sun,” and the [[Nonmen|Nonman]] Mansions most involved in resisting the Tribes of Men were all destroyed, very little is known either of the Breaking of the Gates or of the subsequent migratory invasions.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Breaking of the Gates’</ref><ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Nihrimsûl'</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

One of [[Ajencis]]' more speculative works.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, pg. 407, 'Ajencis'</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Written works]]

revision.comment: Sarl is the only skin eater to survive
revision.text:
{{Stub}} {{Character infobox | name = Sarl | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Judging Eye (Book)|The Judging Eye]]''
''[[The White-Luck Warrior (Book)|The White-Luck Warrior]]'' | lived = ? - present | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = | nationality = | gender = Male | occupation = [[Scalpoi]] ([[Skin Eaters|Skin Eater]]) | relatives = }} [[File:Sarl.png|thumb|300px|Sarl by Quinthane.]] '''Sarl''' is sergeant of the [[Skin Eaters]], long-time companion of Lord [[Kosoter]].''The White-Luck Warrior,'' Character and Faction Glossary, ‘The Scalpoi’ Sarl did not just revere his Captain, he worshipped him.''The Judging Eye,'' Chapter 14 He is the only of the [[Skin Eaters]] to have survived the trek to [[Sauglish|Sauglish.]] ==Appearance== * Sarl have “ink-line eyes, age-scorched skin, and gum-glistening smile.”''The Judging Eye,'' Chapter 6 ==References== [[Category:Skin Eaters]] [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Characters from the Three Seas]]

'''Kiampas''' is a Sergeant of the [[Skin Eaters]] and a former [[Nansur]] officer.<ref>''The White-Luck Warrior'', Glossary: The Scalpoi</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Skin Eaters]] [[Category:Characters from Nansur]] [[Category:Men]]

Pokwas ("Pox") is a [[Skin Eater]] and a disgraced [[Zeümi Sword-dancers|Zeümi Sword-Dancer]].<ref>The White-Luck Warrior: Character and Faction Glossary, 'The Scalpoi'</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Characters from Zeüm]] [[Category:Skin Eaters]]

{{stub}} {{Character_infobox |name = Somandutta |nicknames = Soma |lived = ? - 4132 |race = Men |ethnicity = [[Ketyai]] |nationality = [[Nilnamesh | Nilnameshi]] |gender = Male |occupation = [[Skin Eater]] }}
Somandutta ("Soma") is a [[Skin Eater]] and a [[Nilnamesh]]i caste-noble adventurer.<ref>The White-Luck Warrior: Character and Faction Glossary, 'The Scalpoi'</ref> ==Appearance== Soma is relatively young, with amiable eyes and a full-lipped mouth<ref>The Judging Eye, Chapter 8</ref>. He is tall, lean, and broad shouldered.<ref>The White-Luck Warrior, Chapter 3</ref>
==Story== ===The Judging Eye===
===The White-Luck Warrior===
==References== <references/> [[Category:POV characters]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Characters from Nilnamesh]] [[Category:Skin Eaters]]

{{stub}}
Sutadra ("Soot") is a [[Skin Eater]], and a rumoured [[Fanim]] heretic.<ref>The White-Luck Warrior: Character and Faction Glossary, 'The Scalpoi'.</ref> He was a survivor of [[Cil-Aujas]] and journeyed with the Skin Eaters to the Mop.
He was murdered by [[Stone Hags|Stone Hag]] archers during a sneak attack in the Mop. He received an arrow in the cheek that entered his throat. While he was dying, [[Mimara]]'s [[Judging Eye]] opened and saw that Sutadra's entire life was a mix of both weakness and honor. He joined the Skin Eaters as a form of penance for past deeds, but Mimara saw that he was ultimately damned. As Mimara weeped for him, [[Kosoter]] pressed the arrow further down Sutadra's throat killing him instantly.
==References== <references/> [[Category:Skin Eaters]] [[Category:Characters from Kian]] [[Category:Ketyai]]

'''Xonghis''' is a [[Skin Eaters|Skin Eater]] and former Imperial Tracker.<ref>''The White-Luck Warrior:'' Character and Faction Glossary, 'The Scalpoi'</ref>
==References== <references/> {{Stub}} [[Category:Skin Eaters]] [[Category:Characters from Nansur]] [[Category:Satyothi]]

'''Zaudunyani''' (“Tribe of Truth” in Kûniüric) is the name taken by [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]]’s followers during the [[Holy War|First Holy War]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Zaudunyani’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Organizations]]

'''Zeümi Sword-Dancers''' are the members of an exotic [[Zeüm]]i Cult that worships the sword and has developed sword fighting to an almost supernatural level.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Zeümi Sword-Dancers’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Organizations]]

The name given to defensive [[Sorcery|sorceries]] in contradistinction to offensive sorceries, or Cants.
The most common types of Wards (found in both [[Anagogic]] and [[Gnostic]] sorceries) are: Wards of Exposure, which provide advance warning of intruders or imminent attacks; Shield-Wards, which provide direct protection against offensive sorceries; and Skin-Wards, which provide “protection of last resort” against all types of threat.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Wards'</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Magic]]

'''Year-of-the-Tusk''' is the primary dating system for most mannish [[nations]], which takes the legendary [[Gates of Eärwa|Breaking of the Gates]] to be year zero.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Year-of-the-Tusk’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Culture]]

'''Venicata''' ia an [[Inrithism|Inrithi]] holy day celebrated in late spring, commemorating the so-called First Revelation of [[Inri Sejenus]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Venicata’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Religion]] [[Category:Culture]]

A chamber located in the [[Thousand Thousand Halls|labyrinth]] below [[Ishuäl]] where [[Dûnyain]] children are taught the connections between facial musculature and passions.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Unmasking Room'</ref>
The room is hexagonal with racks of candles covering its walls. Faceless Dûnyain defectives are shackled in its centre, naked, and bound with copper straps. These men are used in the education of the younger Dûnyain.<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 17</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Structures]]

{{stub}} '''Malowebi''' is a [[Mbimayu]] Schoolman, and the emissary sent by the Satakhan of [[Zeüm]] to assess [[Fanayal ab Kascamandri|Fanayal]] and his insurrection.<ref>The White-Luck Warrior, Character Faction and Glossary, 'The Fanim'</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:POV characters]] [[Category:Characters from Zeüm]] [[Category:Satyothi]] [[Category:Mbimayu]] [[Category:Anagogic sorcerers]]

The institution that oversees the Judges, the New Imperium's religious secret police.<ref>The White-Luck Warrior, Character Faction and Glossary, 'The Ministrate'.</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Organizations]]
