{{Character infobox | name = Gin’gûrima | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = mentioned only | lived = ? - ? | race = [[Nonmen]] | ethnicity = | nationality = [[Viri]] | gender = Male | occupation = [[Ishroi]] | relatives = }}
'''Gin’gûrima''' was the greatest [[Nonmen|Nonman]] Hero of the ancient Mansion of [[Viri]]. He was the first to turn on [[Nin’janjin]] and his [[Inchoroi]] allies at the [[Battle of Pir Pahal]].
Gin’gûrima was killed by a [[Wracu|Dragon]] on the [[Inniür-Shigogli]] during the [[Cûno-Inchoroi Wars]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Cûno-Inchoroi Wars’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cûnuroi]] [[Category:Ishroi]] [[Category:Characters from the Ancient North]]

revision.comment: Created page with "Hi, Serwë. You are right, but I don’t hurry up. And check all text on every page, not only change ' to ’."
revision.text: Hi, Serwë. You are right, but I don’t hurry up. And check all text on every page, not only change ' to ’.

'''Viri''' was one of the Nine High Mansions of [[Eärwa]]. It was located in the [[Urokka Mountains]] north of the Sea of [[Neleöst]].<ref>''The Great Ordeal''</ref>
According to the ''[[Isûphiryas]],'' the [[Incû-Holoinas]], plunged to earth to the west of the [[Neleöst|Sea of Neleöst]] in land ruled by [[Nin’janjin]], the [[Nonmen|Nonman]] King of Viri. The fall of the Ark-of-the-Skies caused a natural disaster and sent up ash-clouds that darkened the skies, resulting in a famine.
Nin’janjin begged [[Cû’jara-Cinmoi]], the King of [[Siöl]] for help. Rather than send aid to Nin’janjin, Cû’jara-Cinmoi assembled an army and invaded the lands of Viri. Nin’janjin and his [[Ishroi]] capitulated without battle; Viri became a bloodless tributary of Siöl.
Many years later embassy of [[Inchoroi]] reached Nin’janjin at Viri. They reminded Nin’janjin of Cû’jara-Cinmoi’s treachery in his time of need, and offered an alliance to break the yoke of Siöl over Viri. Despite the warnings of his Ishroi, Nin’janjin accepted the Inchoroi terms. Viri revolted. The Siölan Ishroi within its halls were slain; the rest were enslaved.
[[Sil]], the Inchoroi King, and Nin’janjin assembled their hosts to meet Cû’jara-Cinmoi on the [[Fields of Eleneöt|Fields of Pir Pahal]], which [[Men]] would call Eleneöt in a later age. According to the ''Isûphiryas,'' the Nonmen of Viri were dismayed by the sight of their allies, who wore fierce and festering bodies as garments of war.
[[Gin’gûrima]], the greatest hero among them, pointed to Nin’janjin and declared, “Hate has blinded him.” This treason within a treason was repeated by others, until it became a thundering chorus. Nin’janjin fled, seeking protection from Sil. The Inchoroi then turned upon their allies, hoping to destroy the host of Viri before Cû’jara-Cinmoi and the great host of Siöl could close with them.
Overmatched by the Inchoroi and their weapons of light, the Nonmen of Viri were driven back with horrendous losses. Only Cû’jara-Cinmoi and his Ishroi Chariots saved them from utter destruction.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Cûno-Inchoroi Wars’</ref>
In later epochs, the great fortress of [[Dagliash]] was built atop the ruins of Viri.<ref>''The Great Ordeal''</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Mansions]]

revision.text: #REDIRECT [[Qûya]]

{{Character infobox | name = Sin’niroiha | titles = King | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Thousandfold Thought]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned) | lived = ? - ? | race = [[Cûnuroi]] | ethnicity = | nationality = [[Nihrimsul|Nihrimsûl]] | gender = Male | occupation = King of [[Nihrimsul|Nihrimsûl]]
King of [[Ishoriöl]] (by marriage) | relatives =[[Tsinirû]] (wife)
[[Nil'giccas]] (son)
Unnamed daughter-in-law
Several unnamed grandsons
Several unnamed granddaughters }} '''Sin’niroiha''' (“First Among Peoples” in Ihrimsû), was the High King of the [[Nonmen|Nonman]] [[Mansion]] of [[Nihrimsul]]. For millennia, Nihrimsul and [[Siöl]] feuded over their respective claims to be the House Primordial of the Nonmen. Nihrimsul endured the [[Thousand Year Siege]] and other conflicts, and survived each time. Some time before [[Arkfall]] Sin’niroiha inherited the rule of the mansion and defied [[Cû’jara-Cinmoi]]'s power. In the wake of Arkfall, Siöl conquered [[Viri]] and was able to seize Nihrimsul and [[Cil-Aujas]] by force of arms. A defeated Sin’niroiha was forced to wash the sword of the High King of Siöl as an act of supplication. After the [[Battle of Pir Pahal]], emboldened by Siöl’s distraction, Nihrimsul and [[Cil-Aujas]] revolted under Sin’niroiha's leadership. After years of hard campaigning, Cû’jara-Cinmoi finally brought the [[Ishroi]] of Cil-Aujas to heel, but King Sin’niroiha and the Ishroi of Nihrimsul continued to resist him. The ''[[Isûphiryas]]'' chronicles dozens of bloody yet indecisive confrontations between the two Kings: the Battle of Ciphara, the Battle of Hilcyri and the Siege of Asargoi. Proud beyond reason, Cû’jara-Cinmoi refused to relent, and put to death every embassy Sin’niroiha sent to him.{{EG|Cûno-Inchoroi Wars}} Nihrimsul's hopes in the conflict were few; although well-defended, the Mansion had long irked the other mansions (all descended from the [[House of Tsonos]]) and without allies it could not endure against the combined might of Siöl, Viri and Cil-Aujas. However, Sin’niroiha won a tremendous boon when [[Emilidis]] gifted him with a gift beyond compare: the fabled [[False Sun|Day Lantern]]. With this boon, Sin’niroiha won the alliance of [[Ishoriöl]] and the hand of [[Tsinirû]] in marriage.Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Emilidis' Thus did Sin’niroiha become High King of Ishoriöl and Nihrimsul together, and removed his court to Ishoriöl. Perhaps wary of their combined strength (Ishoriöl was mighty in power), the King of Siöl conceded to peace. “A King of Three Mansions,” he is said to have declared, “may be Brother to a King of Two.”{{EG|Cûno-Inchoroi Wars}} In the following years, Sin’niroiha and Tsinirû had a son, [[Nil'giccas]]. Sin’niroiha grew older, like Cû’jara-Cinmoi, and his mortality approached. However, where Cû’jara-Cinmoi accepted the [[Inchoroi]] treatment against death - the [[Inoculation]] - Sin’niroiha refused it, but did not bar his followers or his family from accepting it. When the [[Womb Plague]] struck down all of the Nonmen women (presumably including Tsinirû), Sin’niroiha made common cause and alliance with Cû’jara-Cinmoi and marched to the [[Battle of Pir Minginnial]]. He saw how [[Nin’janjin]] struck down Cû’jara-Cinmoi, how the Copper Tree of Siöl fell into pitching masses of [[Sranc]], and the Cûnuroi were dismayed. Sin’niroiha, the High King of Nihrimsul and Ishoriöl, fought his way to Cû’jara-Cinmoi’s position, but found only his headless body. Realizing their plight, Sin’niroiha rallied his people and began fighting his way into the [[Ring Mountains]]. A greater part of the surviving Cûnuroi followed him. Once clear of their foe, the glorious Ishroi of [[Eärwa]] fled, gripped by a mad fear.{{EG|Cûno-Inchoroi Wars}} Sin’niroiha became the effective leader of the Nonmen in their wars against the Inchoroi, but found his lack of Tsonos blood occasioned disrespect from the other Mansions, despite their mutual peril. Ishoriöl's proximity to the Ark resulted in frequent battles, with Ishoriöl besieged on no less than five occasions with spans exceeding ten years.Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Ishterebinth' Some years after the Battle of Pir Minginnial, during the [[Siege of the Second Delve]], Sin’niroiha died of old age and his son Nil'giccas succeeded him, eventually leading the Nonmen to victory at the [[Battle of Isal’imial]] and the cleansing of the Ark. Some believe that Nil'giccas succeeded because his Tsonos blood gave him greater legitimacy and respect in the eyes of the other Mansions. In some traditions, Sin’niroiha was the last Nonman to die of age.Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Sin’niroiha' ==References== [[Category:Characters from the Ancient North]] [[Category:Cûnuroi]] [[Category:Kings]]
[[Category:People]]

'''Sumagalt''' is a fiefdom of [[Ce Tydonn]].<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought,'' Chapter 4</ref>
The Earl of Sumagalt is [[Dogora Teör]].<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought,'' Chapter 4</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Fiefdoms]]

[[File:Ajokli.jpg|thumb|300px|The god of deception and trickery, Ajokli is also known as the Four-Horned Brother.]] '''Ajokli''' is the God of thievery and deception. Though listed among the primary [[Gods]] in ''[[The Chronicle of the Tusk]],'' there is no true Cult of Ajokli, but rather an informal network of devotees scattered across the great cities of the [[Three Seas]].
Ajokli is oft mentioned in the secondary scriptures of the different [[Cults]], sometimes as a mischievous companion of the Gods, other times as a cruel or malicious competitor.
In the ''[[Mar’eddat]],'' he is the faithless husband of Gierra.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ajokli’</ref>
Idols of Ajokli show him as a leering figure with a huge penis that reaches up to his chin.<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought,'' Chapter 10</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Gods]] [[Category:Characters from the Outside]]

[[File:Gilgaol.jpg|thumb|300px|The god of conflict and war, Gilgaöl is the brother of Yatwer.]] '''Gilgaöl''' is the [[Gods|God]] of war and conflict. He is one of the so-called [[Compensatory Gods]], who reward devotion in life with paradise in the afterlife.
Gilgaöl is the second most popular of the Hundred Gods, only after his sister [[Yatwer]].
In the ''[[Higarata]],'' the collection of subsidiary writings that form the scriptural core of the [[Cults]], Gilgaöl is depicted as harsh and sceptical of [[Men]], continually demanding proof of worth from those who would follow him. Though subordinate to the [[Thousand Temples]], the Gilgallic Cult boasts nearly as many priests, and perhaps receives more in the way of sacrificial donations<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Gilgaöl’</ref>.
Gilgaöl is also known as the '''Shield-Breaker'''<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Shield-Breaker, the’</ref> and '''One-Eyed War'''<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 5</ref>.
At least the position of High Cultist of Gilgaöl is hereditary. The priests took part in the celebration of [[Ikurei Conphas]]’s victory over the [[Scylvendi]]: :“In accordance with custom, the hereditary priests of Gilgaöl brought basins of water. As Conphas expected, they smeared lion’s blood on his limbs and, muttering prayers, cleansed his symbolic wounds.”<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before,'' Chapter 7</ref>
They also sacrifice goshawks, dogs and lions, by burning them in godfires for the sake of those at war<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before,'' Chapter 7; ''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 6; ''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 18</ref>. Other goshawks are released into the setting evening sun<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 18</ref>. At least in one case, the hide of a lion was retained by the offerer<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before,'' Chapter 7</ref>.
After battle the priests of Gilgaöl preside over the declaration of [[Battle-Celebrant]]. In their ornamental red hauberks, the Gilgallic Priests rise to declare the Battle-Celebrant. The High Cultist of Gilgaöl steps to the forefront of the others, performs the Gilgallic rites, and moves to stand over the Battle-Celebrant. He is told to kneel, and a circlet woven of thorns and olive sprigs, is placed on his head; the High Cultist of Gilgaöl finally cries, “Rise, [name], … Battle-Celebrant!”<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 7</ref>
It is also the task of the High Cultist to consult his omen-texts to determine the will of the God<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 20</ref>.
In ancient [[Sakarpus|Sakarpi]] legend, Gilgaöl is said to have had a mortal daughter named [[Aelswë]]<ref>''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 15</ref>.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Gods]] [[Category:Characters from the Outside]]

revision.comment: Bogobor moved page [[Cet'ingira]] to [[Cet’ingira]] over redirect: correct
revision.text: #REDIRECT [[Cet’ingira]]

'''Junriüma,''' also known as the '''Vault-of-the-Tusk,''' is the ancient fortress-temple that houses the [[The Chronicle of the Tusk|Tusk]], located in the heart of the [[Hagerna]] in [[Sumna]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Junriüma’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

'''Irreüma''' is a so-called “all-Gods temple” located in the administrative quarter of the [[Hagerna]]. Though its architecture belongs to the classical [[Kyraneas|Kyranean]] period, its provenance is unknown.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Irreüma’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

'''Ishoiya''' (Sheyic for “uncertainty”) is the so-called Day of Doubt, an [[Inrithism|Inrithi]] holy day celebrated in late summer, commemorating the spiritual turmoil and renewal undergone by [[Inri Sejenus]] during his imprisonment in [[Xerash]]. Among the less pious, Ishoiya is renowned as a day of copious drinking.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ishoiya’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Religion]] [[Category:Culture]]

'''Feast of Kussapokari''' is a traditional [[Inrithism|Inrithi]] holy day marking the summer solstice.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Feast of Kussapokari’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Religion]] [[Category:Culture]]

'''Ûmerau''' was one of ancient cities of [[Kûniüri]] and the administrative capital of [[Ûmeri Empire]] before. Like all other greatest cities of the [[River Aumris]] Valley it was destroyed in the [[Apocalypse]] in 2147.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kûniüri’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Cities]]

'''Solitary God''' (“Allonara Yulah” in Kianni) is the name used by [[Fanimry|Fanim]] to denote the transcendent singularity of their supreme deity. According to Fanim tradition, the [[God of Gods|God]] is not, as the [[Inrithism|Inrithi]] claim, immanent in existence, nor is He manifold in the way described by the [[Inri Sejenus|Latter Prophet]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Solitary God’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Gods]]

The '''God of Gods''' in [[Inrithism|Inrithi]] tradition, is the unitary, omniscient, omnipotent, and immanent being responsible for existence, of which the [[Gods|Hundred Gods]] (and in some strains [[Men]]) are but “aspects.” In the [[Kiünnat]] tradition, the God is more an abstract placeholder than anything else. In the [[Fanimry|Fanim]] tradition, the God is the unitary, omniscient, omnipotent, and ''transcendent'' being responsible for existence (thus the “[[Solitary God]]”), against which the Hundred Gods war for the hearts of men.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘God, the’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Gods]]

Hi, welcome to {{SITENAME}}! Thanks for your edit to the [[:Xonghis]] page.
'''[[Special:Userlogin|Please sign in and create a user name]]'''. It's an easy way to keep track of your contributions and helps you communicate with the rest of the community.
Please leave me a message if I can help with anything!<ac_metadata title="Welcome to Prince of Nothing!"> </ac_metadata>

[[File:Anagke.jpg|thumb|300px|The goddess of fortune, Anagkë is also called the Whore of Fate, and is the younger sister of Bukris, god of famine.]] '''Anagkë''' is the [[Gods|Goddess]] of fortune. Also known as “the Whore of Fate.” Anagkë is one of the primary [[Compensatory Gods]], which is to say, one who rewards devotion in life with paradise in the afterlife. Her [[Cults|Cult]] is extremely popular in the [[Three Seas]], especially among the higher, political [[caste]]s.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Anagkë’</ref> According to old [[Kiünnat]] tradition, Anagkë is the younger sister of [[Bukris]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Bukris’</ref> Anagkë is also commonly called simply the Whore,<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Whore, the’</ref> or the Whore of Fate.<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before,'' Chapter 5</ref> Anagkë also seems to be associated with the stars. In the text is said that a star “had just entered the horizon of Anagkë, the Whore of Fate.” The augur calls this “an excellent conjunction.”<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before,'' Chapter 5</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Gods]] [[Category:Characters from the Outside]]

[[File:Bukris.jpg|thumb|300px|The god of famine, Bukris is the older brother of Anagkë, the Whore of Fate.]] '''Bukris''' is the [[Gods|God]] of famine. As one of the so-called [[Punitive Gods]], who command sacrifices through threat and the imposition of suffering, Bukris has no real [[Cults|Cult]] or priesthood. According to [[Kiünnat]] tradition, Bukris is the older brother of [[Anagkë]], which is why Anagkean Cultic Priests typically administer the rites of propitiation during times of hunger.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Bukris’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Gods]] [[Category:Characters from the Outside]]

revision.comment: Created page with "Thanks, Bogobor. I don't know, tbh. I felt like, seeing the images out of context (without the words), they could be pictures of any old alien or monster or whatever. So..."
revision.text: Thanks, Bogobor. I don't know, tbh. I felt like, seeing the images out of context (without the words), they could be pictures of any old alien or monster or whatever. Sort of wanted to tag them so, the internet being what it is, people would see them and associate them with something, hopefully giving Bakker another possible lead on readers who may not have heard of him. That was my reasoning, anyway.

[[File:Akkeagni.jpg|thumb|300px|The god of disease, Akkeägni is the patron of most physicians in the Three Seas, rewarding those who strive against his influence.]] '''Akkeägni''' is the [[Gods|God]] of disease. Also known as the God of a Thousand Hands. Scholars have oft noted the irony that the Priesthood of Disease provides the primary repository of physicians for the [[Three Seas]]. How can one at once worship disease and war against it? According to the scriptures of the [[Cults|Cult]], the ''[[Piranavas]],'' Akkeägni is a so-called [[Bellicose Gods|Bellicose God]], one who favours those who strive against him over sycophants and worshippers.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Akkeägni’</ref>
Some of Akkeägni’s priests bear tattoos. They also use small prayer chimes which sound thanks to Akkeägni,<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before,'' Chapter 19</ref> and use pharmaka and reliquaries to combat illness.<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 18</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Gods]] [[Category:Characters from the Outside]]

{{Tje chapters hor}} ==Epigraph== ''When a man possesses the innocence''
''of a child, we call him a fool.''
''When a child possesses the cunning''
''of a man, we call him an abomination.''
''As with love, knowledge has its season.''
—[[Ajencis]], ''[[The Third Analytic of Men]]'' ==Synopsis== ''Autumn, 19 [[New Imperial Year]] (4131 [[Year-of-the-Tusk]]), the “[[Dameöri Wilderness|Long Side]]”'' ''Sranc'' A human horn sounds followed by a moment of silence. Then [[Sranc]] come, running and howling with fury. They smell mannish blood. They run with joy, but the ground breaks beneath them. They’ve been ambushed. A handful of [[Men]] lunge into the Sranc’s midst and hack them to pieces. ''Traveller'' A lone traveller calls out to a group of [[Scalpoi]]. They stare in his direction, ‘Just like animals,’ he thinks. He continues to approach passing a dead Sranc. The men return to their work save for three who continue to watch him warily. He has no doubt that the one he seeks is among them. The traveller walks into the scalpers’ midst as they cut flaps of skin from the crown of each dead Sranc. They are extremely conscious of his arrival, but they pretend otherwise. The [[Scalping Years]] began nearly eleven years ago, when the [[Aspect-Emperor (Title)|Aspect-Emperor]] [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]] declared the bounty on Sranc scalps. Most scalpers died within weeks, some prospered, and a few became legendary. The traveller finds the man he seeks watching the others work. Behind him sits a [[Nil’giccas|second man]], his face concealed by a black cowl. He is looking for an [[High Ainon|Ainon]]i called [[Kosoter|Ironsoul]], he declares. The man, who is a veteran of the [[Holy War|First Holy War]], asks how he had found him, to which the traveller replies that they ‘find everyone,’ and that they want him. ''Late Autumn, 19 New Imperial Year (4131 Year-of-the-Tusk), [[Momemn]]'' ''Anasûrimbor Kelmomas'' His [[Whelming]] complete, young [[Anasûrimbor Kelmomas]] watches a beetle as it hurries across the floor of the Allosium in Momemn. He follows it to the outermost aisle of the [[Allosium Forum]], where the idols of the Hundred [[Gods]] resided. The beetle approaches the idol of [[Ajokli]], the Four-Horned Brother. The Thief. Kelmomas observes that the godhouse of Ajokli is much poorer than the godhouses of his brothers and sisters. He thinks that the idol is also watching the beetle. He smiles and nods at the God. Suddenly, Kelmomas is moved by an unaccountable whim; he pins the beetle to the floor and pinches off two of its legs. He laughs to the Idol and begs it watch as the beetle spins around in panic. They “laugh together.” His [[Esmenet|mother]] approaches from behind him. Kelmomas is not surprised by her; he knew where she was all along. She has been painted white as part of his Whelming ceremony. He’s very excited to see her and thinks that she is the “world’s most beautiful thing.” She embraces him. “Never was there such a sanctuary,” he thinks. He follows her out of the Allosium. Looking back at Ajokli, he finds him still laughing at the beetle. Kelmomas’ secret voice reminds him that he must hate and fear his father. He must never forget that the Strength burns brightest in his father. Outside, they stand on the crest of the monumental steps that fanned down to the expanse of the [[Scuäri Campus]] looking upon the vast and mottled vista of the Momemn, the capital of the [[Three Seas]]. The [[Imperial Precincts]] are flooded with pilgrims and Momemnites who have come for the Whelming ceremony. Kelmomas, however, is repulsed and thinks that people are bugs. His mother leads him down the steps. A group of his father’s bodyguards escorts them through the Scuäri Campus toward the [[Andiamine Heights]]. Kelmomas asks Esmenet about her first daughter, [[Mimara]]. He is jealous of his mother’s love for her and recalls that it was the secret voice that made him drive her away, but now he thinks that maybe he should have killed her. Kelmomas asks about his father and smiles at the thought that he might die if the [[Great Ordeal]] fails. Then there is commotion. Assassins approach. ==Characters== ===Point of View=== * [[Sranc]] * Traveller * [[Anasûrimbor Kelmomas]] ===Appearing=== * [[Sranc]] * Traveller * [[Kosoter]] * [[Nil’giccas]] * [[Anasûrimbor Kelmomas]] * [[Ajokli]] (Idol) * [[Esmenet]] * [[Thopsis]] * [[Ngarau]] * [[Phinersa]] * [[Imhailas]] * [[Sainhail Werjau]] * [[Vem-Mithriti]] * [[Maithanet]] ===Mentioned=== * [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]] * [[Yatwer]] * [[Anasûrimbor Samarmas]] * [[Anagkë]] * [[Mimara]] * [[Anasûrimbor Kayûtas]] * [[Anasûrimbor Moënghus II]] [[Category:Chapters/The Judging Eye]]

[[File:New Empire.png|thumb|center|650px|The Kellian Empire in 4132 Year-of-the-Tusk]] The '''New Empire''' (the '''Kellian Empire''') is the Empire founded by [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]] following the [[Holy War|First Holy War]] and the [[Unification Wars]].
It spans the entirety of the [[Three Seas]], from the legendary fortress of [[Auvangshei]] on the frontiers of [[Zeüm]] to the shrouded headwaters of the [[River Sayut]], from the sweltering coasts of [[Kutnarmu]] to the wild rim of the [[Osthwai Mountains]]—all the lands that had once been [[Fanimry|Fanim]] or [[Inrithism|Inrithi]].
It was easily the equal of the old [[Ceneian Empire]] in terms of geographical extent, and likely far greater when it came to population.
A hundred great cities, and almost as many languages. A dozen proud nations. Thousand of years of mangled history.<ref>''The Judging Eye,'' What Has Come Before …</ref>
Anasûrimbor Kellhus was proclaimed [[Aspect-Emperor (Title)|Aspect-Emperor]] after the defeat of [[Fanayal ab Kascamandri]] at [[Shimeh]] in 4112. Both the [[Kian]]ene and the [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] empires collapsed shortly thereafter, leaving him the undisputed master of the Western Three Seas. Thirteen years of internecine and expansionist war followed. Many factors were instrumental to his success, including his martial brilliance and the fanaticism of his [[Zaudunyani]] Inrithi. But it would be his control of the [[Thousand Temples]] (which allowed him to so quickly consolidate his gains) and his alliance with the [[The Schools|School]] of [[Mandate]] (which gave him the sorcerous advantage on every field of battle) that would prove decisive. The so-called Unifications Wars ended with the final capitulation of [[Nilnamesh]] in 4126, rendering Anasûrimbor Kellhus the greatest conqueror since [[Far Antiquity]]. Not even the legendary [[Triamis the Great]] (2456-2577) achieved so much in so short a time.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Nations]]

'''Padirajah''' is the traditional title of the ruler of [[Kian]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Padirajah’</ref>
==Known Padirajahs== *[[Fan’oukarji I]] (3716-3771): Eldest son of the Prophet [[Fane]] and the first Padirajah of Kian.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Fan’oukarji I’</ref> *[[Fan’oukarji III]]: Leader of the successful [[Dagger Jihad]] in 3933.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Nansur Empire’</ref> *[[Pherokar I]] (3666-3821): One of Kian’s earliest and fiercest Padirajahs.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Pherokar I’</ref> *[[Kascamandri ab Tepherokar]] (4062-4112): The last Padirajah of Kian, slain by [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]] at the [[Battle of Caraskand]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kascamandri ab Tepherokar’</ref> *[[Fanayal ab Kascamandri]] (4075- ): The Bandit Padirajah.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Fanayal ab Kascamandri’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Occupations]]

'''Gandoki''' (“shadows” in Gallish) is a traditional [[Galeoth]] sport where two men, their wrists bound to either end of two poles, attempt to knock each other off their footing.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘gandoki’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Culture]]

'''Galeoth Wars''' are the wars fought between [[Galeoth]] and the [[Nansur Empire]], first in 4103-4104, then again in 4106. In each case the Galeoth, under the generalship of [[Coithus Saubon]], enjoyed early successes, only to be subsequently defeated in more decisive engagements, the last of which was the [[Battle of Procorus]], where [[Ikurei Conphas]] commanded the Imperial Army.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Galeoth Wars’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:War]] [[Category:Present Era]]

{{Character infobox | name = Tisthanna | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Judging Eye (Book)|The Judging Eye]]'' | lived = ? - ? | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Galeoth]] | gender = Female | occupation = Slave | relatives = [[Idrusus Geraus]] (husband)
Silhanna (daughter)
Yorsi (son) }} '''Tisthanna''' is [[Drusas Achamian]]’s slave and wife of [[Idrusus Geraus]]. Her two children are son Yorsi and daughter Silhanna. ==Appearance== Tisthanna has blonde hair and an apple round face. ==Story== ===''The Judging Eye''=== Tisthanna greets [[Mimara]] at Achamian’s tower and shows her to him.{{4|2}} ==References== [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Characters from Galeoth]] [[Category:Slaves]]

{{Character infobox | name = Idrusus Geraus | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Judging Eye (Book)|The Judging Eye]]''
''[[The White-Luck Warrior (Book)|The White-Luck Warrior]]'' | lived = ? - ? | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Galeoth]] | gender = Male | occupation = Slave | relatives = [[Tisthanna]] (wife)
Silhanna (daughter)
Yorsi (son) }} '''Idrusus Geraus''' is [[Drusas Achamian]]’s [[Galeoth]] slave. Geraus visits the [[Scalpoi]] entrepôt of [[Marrow]] three or four times a year, to sell his pelts and, with the gold Achamian gave him, secure goods for his family and Achamian. An even-tempered, slow-speaking man, he always came back with stories of his visits.''The Judging Eye,'' Chapter 6 ==References== [[Category:Characters from Galeoth]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Slaves]]

'''New Imperial Year''' is the primary dating system of the [[New Empire]], which takes the declaration of [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]] as [[Aspect-Emperor (Title)|Aspect-Emperor]] of the [[Three Seas]] (in 4112 [[Year-of-the-Tusk]]) to be year one.<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought,'' Chapter 17</ref><ref>''The Judging Eye,'' What Has Come Before …</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Culture]]

[[File:Unification_Wars.jpg|thumb|400px|Major battles of the Unification Wars (4113-22).]]The '''Unification Wars''' were the wars waged by [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]] to unite the [[Three Seas]] under the rule of his [[New Empire]] following the defeat of the [[Fanimry|Fanim]] [[Kian]]ene in the [[Holy War|First Holy War]].{{4|1}}
The wars unfolded as follows:
* '''4112-4126'''—[[Unification Wars]]. The [[Kellian Empire]] accumulates from the detritus of the nations that preceded it. ** '''4113'''-The Year of the Child Grandees; Nenciphon falls, Kianene Empire dissolved. ** '''4114'''-The ''[[Novum Arcanum]]'' is circulated throughout the Three Seas; [[Rash Soptet]] (4088— ) is hailed as “Lord of the Sempis” after quelling Fanim uprisings. Schismatics denounce Maithanet; the [[War-between-Temples]] begins. Kellhus issues the [[Rehabilitation of Sorcery]], rescinding all Shrial and Tusk condemnations of sorcery. Kellhus also issues the [[Manumission of the Feminine]], awarding equal social, legal and moral status to the the women of the Three Seas. Combined, the two also allow the legitimising of female sorcerers. The [[Swayal Compact]] is founded shortly after this time, with Kellhus ordering them to be trained in the Gnosis by the Mandate. ** '''4115'''-Prince [[Shoddû Akirapita]] (4099—4123) routes the first Zaudunyani invasion of Nilnamesh at the [[Battle of Pinropis]]. ** '''4116'''-The death of King Eryeat, combined with the secret conversion of his eldest surviving son, Coithus Narnol, delivers Galeoth to the Empire nearly intact. King Hringa Vûkyelt expels Schismatics from Thunyerus. ** '''4117'''-The first songs extolling the exploits of [[Sasal Charapatha]] against the Nilnameshi Orthodox begin circulating throughout the Three Seas; First Carythusali uprising; Earl Couras Nantilla is Whelmed, raises Cengemic provincesin revolt against Meigeiri; the Tydonni Orthodox begin massacring Ketyai villages and towns along the Eleterine Coast. ** '''4118'''-Meigeiri falls; Anasûrimbor Kellhus orders the Orthodox of Numaineiri blinded; [[Eselos Mursidides]] (4081—4132) conquers Cironj for the Zaudunyani losing, miraculously, only one hundred and eighteen souls. ** '''4119'''-The [[Koraphean Uprising]]; [[Hoga Hogrim]] (4093— ) is declared Zaudunyani Believer-King of Ce Tydonn; King Hringa Vûkyelt of Thunyerus declares himself a Believer-King as well; the Mandate takes up residence in Kiz. ** '''4120'''-Anasûrimbor Kellhus declares Imperial Bounty on Sranc scalps; [[Sack of Sarneveh]]; Circulation of the [[Toll]] pamphlet, and subsequent Toll uprisings. ** '''4121'''-[[Nurbanu Soter]] (4069— ) declared King-Regent of High Ainon; Invishi falls after the famed [[Throwing-of-the-Hulls]]. ** '''4122'''- Nilnameshi Orthodox crushed at the [[Battle of Ushgarwal]]. Anasûrimbor Kellhus declares the Unification Wars concluded. The Shriah of the Thousand Temples, Maithanet, proclaims him Holy Aspect-Emperor of the Three Seas. * '''4123'''-Prince Shoddû Akirapita (4099—4123) is found drowned in a well in Girgash. Only Fanayal ab Kascamandri remains of the Empire’s notorious enemies. * '''4124'''- Reconstruction of Auvangshei begins. * '''4125'''- First of the [[Angnaya]] are sent to the Palace of Plumes in Zeum.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Unification Wars'</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:War]] [[Category:Present Era]]

'''Scuäri Campus''' is the main parade ground of the [[Imperial Precincts]] in [[Momemn]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Scuäri Campus’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

'''Imperial Precincts''' is the name given to the grounds of the [[Andiamine Heights]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Imperial Precincts’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

'''Allosium Forum''' (or simply '''Allosium''') are the great judicial galleries located at the foot of the [[Andiamine Heights]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Allosian Forum’</ref>
==Trivia== * Allosium Forum is alternately spelled “Allosian Forum” in ''The Darkness That Comes Before'' and in the Encyclopedic Glossary and “Allosium Forum” in ''The Judging Eye'' and in ''The White-Luck Warrior.''
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

'''Hapetine Gardens''' are one of many architectural idylls on the [[Andiamine Heights]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Hapetine Gardens’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

'''Great Names''' is the epithet for the ranking [[caste]]-nobles leading the various contingents of the [[Holy War|First Holy War]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Great Names’</ref>
* [[Coithus Saubon]] of [[Galeoth]] * [[Nersei Proyas]] of [[Conriya]] * [[Chepheramunni]] of [[High Ainon]] * [[Heänar Tharschilka]] of Galeoth * [[Nersei Calmemunis]] of Conriya * [[Akori Kumrezzer]] of High Ainon * [[Hoga Gothyelk]] of [[Ce Tydonn]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Organizations]]

'''Shrial Knights''', also known as Knights of the [[The Chronicle of the Tusk|Tusk]]. The monastic military order founded by [[Shriah]] [[Ekyannus III|Ekyannus III the Golden]] in 2511, charged with prosecuting the will of the Shriah.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Shrial Knights’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Religious organizations]]

{{Stub}} {{Character infobox | name = Gawol Imhailas | titles = Exalt-Captain | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Judging Eye (Book)|The Judging Eye]]''
''[[The White-Luck Warrior (Book)|The White-Luck Warrior]]''
''[[The Great Ordeal (Book)|The Great Ordeal]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned) | lived = 4093 - 4132 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] | nationality = [[Cepalor]]an | gender = Male | occupation = Exalt-Captain of the [[Eöthic Guard]] | relatives = }} '''Gawol''' '''Imhailas''' was the Exalt-Captain of the [[Eöthic Guard]] of the [[New Empire]]''The Judging Eye,'' PrologueEncyclopedic Glossary II, 'Imhailas, Gawol'. He was killed by [[Shrial Knights]] looking for [[Esmenet]] hiding in a whorehouse where he hid her with the prostitute [[Naree]]''The White-Luck Warrior,'' Chapter 14. == Story == === ''The Judging Eye'' === === ''The White-Luck Warrior'' === === ''The Great Ordeal'' === ==References== [[Category:Members of the Eöthic Guard]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Characters from Cepalor]]

{{Tje chapters hor}} ==Epigraph== ''We burn like over-fat candles, our centres gouged,''
''our edges curling in, our wick forever outrunning our wax.''
''We resemble what we are: Men who never sleep.''
—Anonymous Mandate Schoolman, ''[[The Heiromantic Primer]]'' ==Synopsis== ''[[Hûnoreal]]'' ''Early Spring, 19 [[New Imperial Year]] (4132 [[Year-of-the-Tusk]]), Southwestern [[Galeoth]]'' ''Drusas Achamian'' Although [[Drusas Achamian]] has renounced his [[The Schools|School]], he still suffers the same nightmares of the [[Apocalypse|First Apocalypse]] that plague all [[Mandate]] Schoolmen. At a great feast, [[Seswatha]] watches as [[Anasûrimbor Celmomas II]], High-King and his best friend, drinks himself into unconsciousness. He then leaves and finds his way to the High-King’s chambers where [[Suriala]], the High-King’s wife, awaits him. The two make love. Achamian wakes up gasping. He has been a [[Wizard]] for nearly twenty years, and he has slept and studied the [[Seswatha’s Dreams]] in his room for nearly as long. He walks to his worktable and braces himself for the recital to come. ''Drusas Achamian'' He tries to write down a detailed account of the Dream, but all he ends up with is “[[Anasûrimbor Nau-Cayûti|NAU-CAYÛTI]]?” Celmomas’ famed son, whose heroic exploits against the [[No-God]] and his [[Consult]] are recited on hundreds of tomes in the libraries of the Mandate. Achamian has noticed that the frequency of the Dreams involving Nau-Cayûti was far out of proportion to his short-lived role in the Apocalypse. He wonders if Nau-Cayûti was in truth Seswatha’s son. He tries to date the Dream but he’s interrupted by his slaves again. Outside, a woman approaches his tower on a mule. She speaks Sheyic, the common tongue of the [[New Empire]]. It’s been five or six years since he’s had visitors. “Visitors meant grief,” Achamian thinks. ''Drusas Achamian'' The woman is [[Esmenet]]’s first daughter, [[Mimara]]. Achamian wonders if she was the reason why Esmenet had chosen [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Kellhus]] over him. Mimara says that she came to him because she wanted to know if he’s her father. He tells her that he met her mother after she had sold her into slavery, and that the daughters of whores have no fathers. She’s about thirty years of age, he thinks. Her mother must have recovered her years ago, for her manner is too studied and graceful. Achamian bids her go home, back to her mother. They have no connection, he says. She informs him that she is one of the [[The Few|Few]], and that she did not really come to find her father, but her teacher. She wants to learn the [[Gnosis]]. ''Mimara'' Mimara thinks that Achamian possesses the “soul of a teacher,” just as her mother—the old whore—had told her. She left the [[Andiamine Heights]] about three months ago, travelling alone. The place was just as she expected it, except for one thing, the Wizard. She is surprised to see that Achamian is a “wild-haired hermit with limbs like barked branches and eyes that perpetually sort grievances. Bitter. Severe.” She sees the [[Mark]] on him. How could anyone sing songs about such a man? She wonders. She tells him about the [[Swayal Compact]], the only School for [[Witch]]es in the [[Three Seas]], and how her mother would not allow her to join it. Achamian tells her to go home again. He would sooner be her father than her teacher. ''Mimara'' At night, Mimara builds a bonfire and waits outside the old Wizard’s window. “Teach me!” She screams. At first there is no answer, but then the Wizard comes out to confront her. They stare at each other for a moment before he hits her with his staff and enters the tower again. She falls down and begins to laugh, and once again she screams ''“Teeeach meeeee!”'' ==Characters== ===Point of View=== * [[Drusas Achamian]] * [[Mimara]] ===Appearing=== * Drusas Achamian * [[Anasûrimbor Celmomas II]] * [[Seswatha]] * [[Suriala]] * Silhanna * Yorsi * [[Tisthanna]] * Mimara ===Mentioned=== * [[Anasûrimbor Nau-Cayûti]] * [[No-God]] * [[Tanhafut]] * [[Iëva]] * [[Idrusus Geraus]] * [[Esmenet]] [[Category:Chapters/The Judging Eye]]
[[Category:Organizations]]

{{Stub}} {{Character infobox | name = Porsparian | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Judging Eye (Book)|The Judging Eye]]''
''[[The White-Luck Warrior (Book)|The White-Luck Warrior]] | lived = ? - 4132 | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Ketyai]] | nationality = [[Shigek]]i | gender = Male | occupation = Slave | relatives = |image=|caption1=}} '''Porsparian nesh Varalti''' was a slave provided to [[Varalt Sorweel]] by [[Anasûrimbor Kayûtas]] to attend to his needs. Porsparian is a wizened old man who is anything but the submissive thrall he pretends to be. One night Sorweel watches him tear away the turf and mould the face of the Goddess [[Yatwer]] from the dirt. Before his eyes, mud bubbles up as spit from her earthen lips. The slave palms this mud and smears it across the incredulous King’s cheeks.''The Judging Eye,'' Chapter 13 ==References== [[Category:Characters from Shigek]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Slaves]] [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Great Ordeal]]

revision.comment: Removed a couple of "s"s added a "The", and changed an "is" to an "are".
revision.text:
'''Scalpoi''' (or simply '''scalpers''') are mercenaries that hunt and kill [[Sranc]] and take Holy Bounty for their scalps.<ref>''The Judging Eye,'' Prologue</ref>
The [[Skin Eaters]] are the most famous Scalpoi company.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Occupations]]

{{Stub}} {{Character infobox | name = Thanteus Eskeles | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Judging Eye (Book)|The Judging Eye]]''
''[[The White-Luck Warrior (Book)|The White-Luck Warrior]]'' | lived = ? - ? | race = [[Men]] | ethnicity = [[Ketyai]] | nationality = | gender = Male | occupation = [[Mandate]] [[Sorcerer]] | relatives = }} '''Thanteus Eskeles''' is a [[Mandate]] Schoolman and tutor to [[Varalt Sorweel]].''The Judging Eye,'' Chapter 10 ==Story== ===''The Judging Eye''=== ===''The White-Luck Warrior''=== ==References== [[Category:Mandate]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Characters from the Three Seas]] [[Category:Gnostic sorcerers]] [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Great Ordeal]]

{{Character infobox | name = Maëngi | titles = | nicknames = | appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]''
''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]'' | lived = ? - 4111 | race = [[Skin-spies|Skin-spy]] | ethnicity = | nationality = | gender = Male | occupation = [[Consult]] spy | relatives = }} '''Maëngi''' is a [[Consult]] [[Skin-spies|skin-spy]] who kills and impersonates the Knight-Commander of the [[Shrial Knights]], [[Cutias Sarcellus]].Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Sarcellus, Cutias’ ==Story== ===''What Came Before''=== Maëngi kills and replaces Sarcellus. ===''The Darkness That Comes Before''=== While [[Drusas Achamian|Achamian ]]and [[Paro Inrau|Inrau ]]are having a heated conversation at a tavern in [[Sumna]], Maëngi (as Sarcellus) arrives with two other Shrial knights and recognizes Inrau. Maëngi intercedes and asks Inrau if Achamian is bothering him. Achamian affects the persona of Inrau's rude and drunken uncle, which causes Maëngi to strike him to the ground and express a desire to kill him. Achamian notices that the eyes of "Sarcellus" are curiously empty. Maëngi and the [[Synthese]] ambush [[Paro Inrau]] in [[Sumna]] before Inrau commits suicide.''The Darkness That Comes Before,'' Chapter 4 In the guise of Sarcellus, Maëngi breaks up the stoning of [[Esmenet]] at a town outside Sumna. A local priest objects to his interference, but Maëngi strikes him with his mailed fist, asserting his authority through force. He takes Esmenet with him to [[Momemn]] where the [[Holy War]] gathers.''The Darkness That Comes Before,'' Chapter 10 ===''The Warrior-Prophet''=== Maëngi is killed at the [[Fifth Battle of Mengedda]], and another skin-spy, [[Gaörta]], takes over the role of Cutias Sarcellus.''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 6''The Warrior-Prophet,'' Chapter 22 ==References== [[Category:POV characters]] [[Category:Skin-spies]] [[Category:Characters from Golgotterath]] [[Category:Consult members]]

'''Sign of Gierra''' are the twin serpents that [[Sumna|Sumni]] harlots must have tattooed on the back of their left hand, apparently in imitation of the Priestesses of [[Gierra]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Sign of Gierra’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Culture]]

'''Gierra''' is the [[Gods|Goddess]] of carnal passion. One of the so-called [[Compensatory Gods]], who reward devotion in life with paradise in the afterlife, Gierra is very popular throughout the [[Three Seas]], particularly among aging men drawn to the “aphrodisica,” Cultic nostrums reputed to enhance virility. In the ''[[Higarata]],'' the collection of subsidiary writings that form the scriptural core of the [[Cults]], Gierra is rarely depicted with any consistency, and is often cast as a malign temptress, luring men to the luxury of her couch, often with fatal consequences.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Gierra’</ref> In the ''[[Mar’eddat]],'' she is wife of the faithless [[Ajokli]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ajokli’</ref> Gierra’s “voluptuous” idol, depicts “wide-thrown ankles.”<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought,'' Chapter 10</ref>
“The temple prostitutes of Gierra believes, that despite the hundreds of men who uses them, they couples with only ''one,'' [[Hotos]], the Priapic God.”<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought,'' Chapter 6; This is the only known mention of Hotos</ref> Priestesses of Gierra tattoo their limbs in inscriptions and cover their bodies with oil.<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before,'' Chapter 3</ref> Part of their duties is to have sex with male worshippers.<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before,'' Chapter 11</ref> [[Sumna|Sumni]] harlots must have the [[Sign of Gierra]], twin serpents, tattooed on the back of their left hand, apparently in imitation of the Priestesses of Gierra.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Sign of Gierra’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Gods]] [[Category:Characters from the Outside]]

'''Shinoth''' is the legendary main gate of ancient [[Trysë]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Shinoth’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

'''Csokis''' is a derelict [[Inrithism|Inrithi]] temple complex located in the great campus of [[Kalaul]] in the city of [[Caraskand]], which was the site of the [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Warrior-Prophet]]’s Circumfixion beneath [[Umiaki]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Csokis’</ref><ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kalaul’</ref><ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Umiaki’</ref>
==Refernces== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

'''Kalaul''' is the great campus of the [[Csokis]] temple complex in [[Caraskand]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kalaul’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

revision.text:
{{Stub}} '''The Four Revelations of Cinial’jin''' is an Atrocity Tale published by R. Scott Bakker in November 7, 2011 [http://rsbakker.wordpress.com/stories/the-four-revelations-of-cinialjin/ here] and [http://www.rscottbakker.com/atrocity-tales/the-four-revelations-of-cinialjin/ there].
This Atrocity Tale, along with [[The False Sun]], was included as appendix in [[The Unholy Consult]] under the title, ''Four Revelations.'' [[Category:Atrocity tales]]

'''Celmomian Prophecy''' is the dying words of [[Anasûrimbor Celmomas II]] to [[Seswatha]] on the [[Fields of Eleneöt]] in 2146 to the effect that an Anasûrimbor would return at “the end of the world.” Given that the prevention of the so-called [[Second Apocalypse]] is the [[Mandate]]’s entire reason for existence, it is perhaps no surprise that most Mandate scholars think the Celmomian Prophecy authentic. Few others in the [[Three Seas]] credit their claims, however.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Celmomian Prophecy’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Culture]] [[Category:Metaphysics]]

'''Anasûrimbor Dynasty''' is the ruling dynasty of [[Kûniüri]] from 1408 to 2147.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Anasûrimbor Dynasty’</ref>
==Known High-Kings of Kûniüri== * [[Anasûrimbor Nanor-Ukkerja I]] * [[Anasûrimbor Celmomas II]] * [[Anasûrimbor Ganrelka II]]
==Partitioning of Greater Kûniüri== At his death, c. 1556, Nanor-Ukkerja I divided his empire between his sons, creating [[Aörsi]] and [[Sheneor]] in addition to Kûniüri proper.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kûniüri’</ref>
==Known High-Kings of Aörsi== * [[Anasûrimbor Mygella]] * [[Anasûrimbor Nimeric]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Houses]]

'''Tesperari''' is a [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] term for naval captains who retire to command merchant ships.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘tesperari’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Occupations]]

'''Amortanea''' is the merchant carrack that bore [[Drusas Achamian]] and [[Krijates Xinemus]] to [[Joktha]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Amortanea’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Artifacts]] [[Category:Structures]]

revision.text: No problem! I'm not sure if you visit the TSA forums but name there is Francis Buck. I was tossing a few of my drawings on some characters that didn't have an image, and happened to see a few little spelling things that I figured I'd fix up! This wiki is AMAZING, I somehow didn't even know about it until recently (I know there was another one, but it's not nearly as good as this, at least it doesn't feel like it). Mad props to you for making/maintaining this!
[[Category:Fan art]]

{{Stub}} The '''Battle of Trantis Bay''' was the decisive sea battle where the [[Kian]]ene fleet, using [[Cishaurim]], was able to annihilate the [[Nansur Empire|Imperial Nansur]] fleet under General [[Pomarius Sassotian]] in 4111, thereby denying the [[Holy War|First Holy War]] its primary source of water for its march across [[Khemema]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Battle of Trantis Bay’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:War]] [[Category:First Holy War]]

The '''''Sinyatwa''''' is the primary scripture of the [[The Cult of Yatwer | Cult of Yatwer]]. Yatwerians tend to rely for their liturgical rites and ceremonies on ''Sinyatwa'' rather than on ''[[Higarata]]''.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Yatwer’</ref>
==Excerpts== “From seed to womb, from seed to furrow. The right hand cannot give to the left …”<ref>''The Judging Eye,'' Chapter 5</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Religious texts]]

'''Ancilline Gate''' is one of the so-called [[Lesser Gates]] of [[Momemn]], located to the immediate south of the [[Girgallic Gate]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glosary, ‘Ancilline Gate’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Structures]]

'''Ascension''' is the direct passage of [[Inri Sejenus]] to the [[Outside]] as described in “The Book of Days” in ''[[The Tractate]].'' According to [[Inrithism|Inrithi]] tradition, Sejenus ascended from the [[Juterum]], or the Sacred Heights, in [[Shimeh]], though ''The Tractate'' seems to suggest that [[Kyudea]] and not Shimeh was the location. The [[First Temple]] was purportedly raised on the very location.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ascension’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Religion]] [[Category:Metaphysics]]

The '''Juterum''' (also known as the '''Holy Heights''' and the '''Hill of Ascension'''), are the so-called '''Sacred Heights''' in [[Shimeh]]. On the Juterum’s summit located the [[First Temple]], the great circular gallery of columns that marks the site of [[Inri Sejenus]]’s alleged [[Ascension]] to the [[Nail of Heaven]].{{EG|Juterum, the}}{{3|13}}{{3|15}}
==References== <references /> [[Category:Mountains]]

== Summary == Su’juroit, the great Nonman Witch-King. Only mentioned once, and probably not to be featured again in the narrative, but evokes a mysterious character nonetheless. R. Scott Bakker’s The Second Apocalypse series of books. == Licensing == {{Fairuse}} [[Category:Fan art]]
== Summary == The notorious Cishaurim sorcerer-priest, Mallahet. R. Scott Bakker’s The Second Apocalypse series of books. == Licensing == {{Fairuse}} [[Category:Fan art]]
== Summary == A trinket, from the superlative fantasy works of R. Scott Bakker, collectively known as The Second Apocalypse. == Licensing == {{Fairuse}} [[Category:Fan art]]

'''Xoägi’i''' are a [[Sranc]] tribe from the [[Plains of Gâl]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Xoägi’i’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Tribes]]

'''Kig’krinaki''' are a [[Sranc]] tribe from the [[Plains of Gâl]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Kig’krinaki’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Tribes]]

[[File:Kelmomaswhelming by quintvc-d87bfnb.png|thumb|300px|Whelming ceremony of Kelmomas by [http://quintvc.deviantart.com/ Quinthane]]] '''Whelming''' is a hypnotic trance instrumental to [[Dûnyain]] [[Conditioning]], and a purificatory rite of induction for the [[Zaudunyani]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Whelming’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Metaphysics]]
[[Category:Fan art]]

'''Age of Cenei''' (also known as '''Ceneian Golden Age''') is the era of [[Ceneian Empire|Ceneian]] dominance of the [[Three Seas]], from the ascension of [[Triamis the Great]] in 2478 and the conquest of [[Nilnamesh]] in 2483 until the [[Sack of Cenei]] in 3351.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Age of Cenei’; ‘Ceneian Empire’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Near Antiquity]]

The '''Second Apocalypse''' is the successor conflict to the [[Apocalypse|First Apocalypse]], during which time the [[No-God]] was summoned by the [[Consult]] to bring about the annihilation of humankind and the sealing of [[the World]] against the [[Outside]], thus saving a minority from damnation at the expense of the majority. The No-God was defeated at the [[Second Battle of Mengedda]] in 2155 by King [[Anaxophus V]] of [[Kyraneas]], who used the [[Heron Spear]], an [[Inchoroi]] [[Spears of light|spear of light]], to penetrate the Sarcophagus and apparently kill the No-God. In some traditions, the Sarcophagus was completely incinerated and the ashes scattered across [[Eärwa]], triggering the [[Indigo Plague]]. [[Mandate]] warnings to the contrary were ignored.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Second Apocalypse’</ref>
In reality, however, the Sarcophagus was only damaged, not destroyed. It was recovered by the Consult and returned to [[Golgotterath]], where it was repaired to the best of their knowledge. The Consult then spent the next two thousand years attempt to reactivate the Sarcophagus. In 4132, at the conclusion of the [[Great Ordeal]]'s disastrous campaign against Golgotterath, they succeeded. The Second Apocalypse has begun and the No-God walks the earth once more.<ref>[[''The Unholy Consult'']]</ref>
According to the Mandate tradition, [[Anasûrimbor Celmomas II]], the High King of [[Kûniüri]] during the [[Apocalypse]], [[Celmomian Prophecy|prophesied]] that the No-God will in fact return but an Anasûrimbor would return to stop him. The prevention of the Second Apocalypse was the Mandate’s ultimate goal, in which they failed. It was [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]]'s campaign which in fact led to the Second Apocalypse, as the Consult wanted to trap Kellhus himself within the Sarcophagus. This failed and Kellhus was slain. His son [[Anasûrimbor Kelmomas]] was instead placed within the Sarcophagus, triggering the resurrection of the No-God, which promptly destroyed the Great Ordeal. The resurrection of the No-God triggered the beginning of the [[Years of the Crib|Second Years of the Crib]], preventing the birth of any further children.
The outcome of the Second Apocalypse remains to be seen, but the destruction of the Great Ordeal has denuded the [[Three Seas]] of almost all men of fighting age and health. Only the military and sorcerous potential of the nation of [[Zeüm]] remains unspent. The No-God has access to far vaster numbers of [[sranc]] than existed during the First Apocalypse and the support of [[Dûnyain]] sorcerer-advisors, as well as the allegiance of the [[Scylvendi]]. The odds would appear hopeless.
==References== <references /> [[Category:War]] [[Category:Present Era]]

revision.comment: Created page with "The '''Conditioning''' is specifically, the arduous physical, emotional, and intellectual training undergone by [[Dûnyain]] monks, though the term has more general and far-re..."
revision.text:
The '''Conditioning''' is specifically, the arduous physical, emotional, and intellectual training undergone by [[Dûnyain]] monks, though the term has more general and far-reaching connotations as well.
The Dûnyain believe that everything is conditioned in some way, but they draw a principled distinction between the arbitrary conditioning of the world and the rational conditioning of [[Men]]. Conditioning in the light of the [[Logos]], they believe, allows ''more'' such conditioning, which in turn leverages more such conditioning, and so on.
This virtuous circle, they believe, finds its apotheosis in the [[Absolute]]: the Dûnyain believe that, using reason, they can condition themselves to the point of becoming ''unconditioned,'' a perfect, self-moving soul.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Conditioning, the’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Metaphysics]]
Synthese from MCEscher [[Category:Fan art]]

'''Near Antiquity''' (sometimes called the '''Ceneian Age''') is the historical period beginning in 2155 (the end of the [[Apocalypse]]) and ending with the [[Sack of Cenei]] in 3351.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Near Antiquity’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Near Antiquity]]

'''Far Antiquity''' is the historical period beginning with the [[Gates of Eärwa|Breaking of the Gates]] and ending with the [[Apocalypse]] in 2155.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Far Antiquity’</ref>
'''Age of Bronze''' is another name for Far Antiquity, during which bronze was the dominant technology of [[Men]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Age of Bronze’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Far Antiquity]]

'''Age of Warring Cities''' is the era following the dissolution of [[Kyraneas]] (''c.'' 2158) until the rise of [[Cenei]], characterized by perpetual warfare between the cities of the [[Kyranae Plains]].<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Age of Warring Cities’</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Near Antiquity]]

'''Sack of Cenei''' is destruction of the capital of [[Ceneian Empire]] by the [[Scylvendi]] under [[Horiötha]] in 3351.<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Cenei’</ref>
This event marks the end of [[Near Antiquity]].
==References== <references /> [[Category:War]] [[Category:Near Antiquity]]

New Empire [[Category:Maps]]

'''House Zerxei''' is a former [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] [[Houses of the Congregate|House of the Congregate]], and the empire’s ruling dynasty from 3511 to 3619<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Nansur Empire'</ref><ref name=":1">Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Zerxei, House’</ref>.
==Known Zerxei Emperors== * [[Zerxei Triamarius I]] (reigned 3511-3517)<ref name=":0" /><ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Triamarius I'</ref> * [[Zerxei Triamarius II]] * [[Zerxei Triamarius III]] (reigned ?-3619)<ref name=":1" /><ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Triamarius III'</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Houses]]

The '''Houses of the Congregate''' are a quasi-legislative assembly consisting of the primary landholding families of the [[Nansur Empire]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Houses of the Congregate’</ref>.
==Known Houses of the Congregate== * [[House Biaxi]] * [[House Cutias]] * [[House Daskas]] * [[House Gaunum]] * [[House Ikurei]] * [[House Israti]] * [[House Kiskei]] * [[House Ligesseras]] * [[House Sorgis]] (former) * [[House Surmante]] (former) * [[House Thallei]] * [[House Trimus]] * [[House Zerxei]] (former)
==References== <references /> [[Category:Houses]]

'''House Ikurei''' is a [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] [[Houses of the Congregate|House of the Congregate]], with holdings concentrated in and about [[Momemn]]. It was the Imperial House from 3941<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ikurei, House’</ref> to 4112 (when the [[New Empire]] was established).
Always one of the more powerful Houses of the Congregate, the Ikurei seized the Imperial Mantle in 3941, capitalizing on the turmoil following the loss of [[Shigek]] and then [[Gedea]] to [[Kian]] in the [[Dagger Jihad]]. [[Ikurei Sorius I]] became the first of a line of shrewd yet defensive Ikurei Emperors<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Ikurei Dynasty’</ref>.
==Known Ikurei Emperors== * [[Ikurei Anphairas I]] (reigned 4066-4081)<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Ikurei Anphairas I'</ref> * [[Ikurei Conphas|Ikurei Conphas I ]](reigned 4112-4112)<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 5</ref><ref>''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 16</ref> * [[Ikurei Sorius I]] (reigned 3941-?)<ref name=":0" /> * [[Ikurei Xerius III]] (reigned ?-4112)<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 4</ref> * [[Ikurei Xerius III's father]]
==Known Members== * [[Ikurei Conphas' father]] * [[Ikurei Conphas' half-sister]] (by marriage; unknown if also by birth) * [[Ikurei Istriya]] (by marriage)
==References== <references /> [[Category:Houses]]
#REDIRECT [[File:Cu’jara-Cinmoi.jpg]]

'''House Biaxi''' was one of the [[Houses of the Congregate]], and traditional rival to [[House Ikurei]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, ‘Biaxi, House’</ref>.
==Known Members== * [[Biaxi Coronsas]] * [[Biaxi Sankas]] * [[Biaxi Scoulas]] * [[Biaxi Sompas]] * [[Biaxi Tarpellas]]
==References== <references /> [[Category:Houses]]

:''This article is a [[:Category:Article stubs|stub]] and in need of signification revisions. You can help '''{{SITENAME}}''' by [{{fullurl:{{FULLPAGENAME}}|action=edit}} expanding it].''
The '''Thousandfold Thought''' is the thread of act and consequence that would prevent the [[Consult]] from resurrecting the [[No-God]] and bringing about the [[Second Apocalypse]]. It was crafted by [[Anasûrimbor Moënghus]] in the years he spent among the [[Cishaurim]] of [[Kian]].<ref>''[[The Judging Eye (Book)|The Judging Eye]]'', What Has Comes Before...</ref>
==References== <references /> [[Category:Article stubs]] [[Category:Metaphysics]]

revision.comment: Created page with "The Thousandfold Thought is beyond comprehension to those who can’t comprehend it? That isn’t a very useful entry IMO. Also, ''"It is pure enlightenment beyond imaginatio..."
revision.text:
The Thousandfold Thought is beyond comprehension to those who can’t comprehend it? That isn’t a very useful entry IMO.
Also, ''"It is pure enlightenment beyond imagination"'', I don’t see any support in the text for this.
Maybe this entry should be removed for now or revised significantly. [[User:Qma|Qma]] ([[User talk:Qma|talk]]) 14:57, November 17, 2014 (UTC)

[[Category:Timeline]]

: ''For a comprehensive timeline of events see [[Timeline]].''
The period following [[Near Antiquity]]. Not named in the text. [[Category:Second Age]]

: ''For a comprehensive timeline of events see [[Timeline]].''
'''Far Antiquity''' is the period extending from the [[Gates_of_Eärwa|Breaking of Gates]] to the end of the [[Apocalypse]] (0 - 2155, [[Year-of-the-Tusk]]). [[Category:Second Age]]

: ''For a comprehensive timeline of events see [[Timeline]].''
'''Near Antiquity''' (sometimes called the '''Ceneian Age''') is the historical period beginning in 2155 (the end of the [[Apocalypse]]) and ending with the [[Sack of Cenei]] in 3351. [[Category:Second Age]]

How else could you be possible?”|Anasûrimbor Moënghus}} Example using the '''' tag, {{blockquote|And the Nonman King cried words that sting: “Now to me you must confess, For death above you hovers!” And the Emissary answered ever wary: “We are the race of flesh, We are the race of lovers.”|“Ballad of the Inchoroi,” Ancient Kûniüri Folk Song}} [[Category:Utility templates]]

revision.comment: Created page with "Just wanted to point out that the imperative to persecute and murder those who use sorcery was also an Inchoroi addition to the Tusk, as the very existence of 'Shamans' sugges..."
revision.text: Just wanted to point out that the imperative to persecute and murder those who use sorcery was also an Inchoroi addition to the Tusk, as the very existence of 'Shamans' suggests that not all sorcery was understood to be an affront to God in the past.[[Special:Contributions/73.164.181.196|73.164.181.196]] 09:36, January 1, 2015 (UTC)James Sheather

Hi Serwe,
Yes, I remember. Sorry, I just haven't had the time/inspiration for much yet. I'm looking into creating a custom PON font based on the Kuniuric script on the books, but tbh that's a slow burner for now. Maybe I can run it by you before I make any changes to the wiki. I have a few irons in the fire, though, so not sure how soon this will be.
Thanks again,
