The Urokkas (Virolotoi, by the Nonmen of Viri) is a low range of five mountains located north-northwest of the [[Neleost|Neleost Sea]] in what was once [[Aörsi]], between the rivers [[River Sursa|Sursa]] and [[Hinsursa]]<ref name=":0">The Encyclopaedic Glossary II</ref>.
The five mountains, west to east are [[Antareg]] (or Iros), Ingol, Oloreg, Mantigol, and Yawreg<ref name=":0" />.
Antareg is mountain which housed the Nonman mansion of [[Viri]], and later the mannish fortress of [[Dagliash]].
== References == <references /> [[Category:Mountains]]

A sister of the renowned [[Heron Spear]], the Sun Lance is [[Spears of light|weapon of light]] developed by the [[Inchoroi]].<ref>The Encyclopaedic Glossary II, "Black Iron Seat"</ref>
== Appearance == The beam produced by the Sun Lance was "blood-red" in colour<ref>''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 15 (Page 334)</ref> and the weapon was attached to a "metallic coffer" via a "rope."<ref>''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 16 (Page 337)</ref>
== References == <references /> [[Category:Tekne artifacts]]

revision.comment: Created page with "I'm concerned that the connection between the Spear used by the Nonman situated on the Upright Horn in TUC and the Sun Lance is not concrete. It was discussed on the SA foru..."
revision.text:
I'm concerned that the connection between the Spear used by the Nonman situated on the Upright Horn in TUC and the Sun Lance is not concrete. It was discussed on the SA forum as the two being one and the same, however it's not explicitly stated in the text nor the Glossary. That said, I put it up anyway. Please edit if necessary.
[[User:Anaxophus V|Anaxophus V]] ([[User talk:Anaxophus V|talk]]) 04:06, July 26, 2017 (UTC)

Hi, Anaxophus. Thanks a lot for your contributions so far. I just wanted to note a couple of things. If you're going to use page number in references it's better to also mention which copy of the book you have. For example, The Great Ordeal, Chapter 10, US HC p.273 Or another format that makes it clear because page numbers are different in each copy. Otherwise, just use the book name and chapter without page numbers. Also, Werthead said that it's better to wait a month or so after the North American release (yesterday) before adding story spoilers from TUC to the wiki. Info that doesn't spoil the plot is fine, though. Thanks again. [[User:Neorem|Neorem]] ([[User talk:Neorem|talk]]) 08:37, July 26, 2017 (UTC)

Putting Kellhus' Dunyain son under his children info is definitely needed, and there is no need to worry about spoilers as that info was revealed in The Great Ordeal. And for the record, we also need pages for Korringhus and his son on the wiki now that I think about it...

{{Character_infobox|name = Sûjara-nin|nicknames = Red Ghoul|lived = ? - ?|race = [[Nonmen]]|nationality = [[Siöl]]|gender = Male|occupation = [[Ishroi]]|image=|caption1=|titles=|appearances=[[The Great Ordeal]]
[[The Unholy Consult]]|ethnicity=|relatives=}}'''Sûjara-nin''' is a [[Cunuroi]] [[Ishroi]] known as the '''Red Ghoul''' due to his crimson nimil armor the [[Immaculate Rim]]. He appeared during the Battle of [[Golgotterath]] and slew many countless men thinking him to be an ally. Finally, he was hit by a Chorae and turned into a statue of salt, but his attack broke the defence lines of men, allowing the Sranc to push them back. [[Category:Cûnuroi]] [[Category:Characters from the Ancient North]] [[category:Ishroi]]

revision.comment: Created page with "'''''The No-God''''' is the title of the third and concluding sub-series in ''[[The Second Apocalypse]]'' fantasy series by [[R. Scott Bakker]], following on from ''[[The Prin..."
revision.text:
'''''The No-God''''' is the title of the third and concluding sub-series in ''[[The Second Apocalypse]]'' fantasy series by [[R. Scott Bakker]], following on from ''[[The Prince of Nothing]]'' and ''[[The Aspect-Emperor]]'' sub-series.
''The No-God'' will start several weeks after the events of ''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' and is expected to span at least two books, although Bakker has acknowledged it may expand to three volumes. No publication date is set for the first book, although Bakker has already begun work on it. [[Category:Main series]]

'''Norwain I '''was a king who united [[Galeoth]] in ''c.''3683 after twenty years of campaigning against his enemies.
He apparently butchered his foes en masse in the reception hall of [[Moraör]], the great palace complex of the Galeoth kings.<ref>Encyclopaedic glossary, Galeoth</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Kings]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Characters from Galeoth]]

The '''Progenitors''' are the species which created the [[Inchoroi]], built the [[Incû-Holoinas]] and mastered the art of the [[Tekne]]. Their true name is unknown.
The progenitors are native to another planet elsewhere in the void. They achieved total technological and biological mastery and were close to grasping the [[Absolute]] before discovering - possibly through the creation of the [[Inverse Fire]] - that they were doomed to eternal damnation after death. They created the Incû-Holoinas to carry their genetically-engineered servitors, the Inchoroi, through the void to obliterate life on other worlds until this removed the threat of damnation. It is unknown why the progenitors themselves did not join the expedition.
The fate of the progenitors is unknown. By [[Cet’ingira]]'s reckoning, the Incû-Holoinas crashed on [[The World]] over eight thousand years ago and, according to [[Wutteät]], it travelled through the void to "countless" other worlds before that. It may be that after such a long time, maybe tens of thousands of years, the progenitors are extinct, or drove themselves insane through the knowledge of the Inverse Fire.
The Inchoroi themselves remember nothing of their origins; what scant information is known was extracted by Cet’ingira and the Dûnyain from the Ark over the course of many years.<ref>''[[The Unholy Consult]]''</ref>
==References== <references/> [[Category:Races]] [[Category:Inchoroi]]

revision.comment: Created page with " '''Ninnant '''is a province of [[High Ainon]] . The city of [[Moserothu]] is located within this area."
revision.text: '''Ninnant '''is a province of [[High Ainon]] . The city of [[Moserothu]] is located within this area.

'''Marrow '''is a small town generally entered around the trade of [[Scalpoi|scalping]]. It is located in the eastern spur of the [[Osthwai Mountains]]. [[Drusas Achamian]] and [[Mimara]] assemble their group there for the trek to [[Sauglish]].

{{Character_infobox|name = Sag-Marmau|titles = General|appearances = ''[[The Thousandfold Thought]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned)|lived = ca. 2094 - 2143|race = [[Men]]|ethnicity = [[Norsirai]]|nationality = [[Kûniüri|Kûniüric]]|gender = Male|occupation = General|relatives = [[Ysilka]] (wife)}}'''Sag-Marmau '''was a [[Kûniüri|Kûniüric]] general during the [[First Apocalypse]], and a prominent figure in the Book of Generals from ''[[The Sagas]]''Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Apocalypse'Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Sag-Marmau'''. ''He was the husband of [[Ysilka]]Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Ysilka'. Sag-Marmau is known as the general who saved the Ordeal from the disarray and dismay which followed the death of [[En-Kaujalau]]. In 2142, he led the army of Kûniüri to victory against [[Aurang]] and his [[Consult]] legions at the [[Battle of Twenty-Yokes]]Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Yoke'. By autumn of that year he had hound­ed the rem­nant of their horde to the Gates of [[Golgotterath]] it­self, during which time he issued an ultimatum to [[Shaeönanra|Shauriatas]]''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 8. In 2143, Sag-Marmau and "the greater glory" of the Kûniüric army were annihilated with the rise of the [[No-God]]. He lived long enough to witness Initiation and the very beginning of the [[Apocalypse|First Apocalypse]]. == References == [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Characters from the Ancient North]] [[Category:Characters from Kûniüri]]

Unnamed nephew or niece|nationality = [[New Empire]]}}The''' "nameless one"''' was the fourth child of [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Kellhus]] and [[Esmenet]]. Their gender is unknown. As they were born with severe deformities, they were killed by the physician-priests overseeing the birth soon after being born''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 3. == Appearance == The "nameless one" had no eyes and possessed a total of eight arms. == Story == === ''What Came Before'' === The nameless one was the first of Kellhus and Esmenet's children to be born in the [[Andiamine Heights]]. They were born after a long and difficult labour, which was life-threatening to Esmenet. Upon their birth, they were drowned in unwatered wine by physician-priests, in accordance to [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] custom. === ''The Judging Eye'' === Esmenet briefly recalls the birth of her fourth child when reminiscing about all of her children. ==Notes== == References == [[Category:Anasûrimbor]] [[Category:Dûnyain]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Characters from the New Empire]] [[Category:Prince-Imperials]] [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Mixed ethnicity]]

[[Nersei Thaila (younger)|Thaila]] (daughter)}}'''Nersei''' '''Miramis''' is the wife of [[Nersei Proyas]] and the Queen of [[Conriya]]''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 2. She is also the niece of [[Coithus Saubon|Saubon]]''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 14, though it is unknown which of Saubon's siblings is her parent. == Story == === ''What Came Before'' === At some point following the [[Holy War|First Holy War]], Proyas married Miramis. The two later had two children, [[Nersei Xinemus|Xinemus]] and [[Nersei Thaila (younger)|Thaila]]. === ''The White-Luck Warrior'' === Proyas briefly thinks of home and of his wife and children. He reflects on how Miramis "still wept when­ev­er he left her bed for the wide world". After [[Fanayal ab Kascamandri|Fanayal]]'s army attacks [[Aöknyssus]], Miramis and her children are removed to [[Attrempus]] for their safety''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 5. Following [[Maithanet]]'s coup, Esmenet thinks of fleeing to Aöknyssus and considers that Miramis would at least give her sanctuary. === ''The Unholy Consult'' === After Proyas is denounced as a traitor and strung up to be slowly left to die, [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Kellhus]] brings up Miramis, Xinemus and Thaila as lives that will be saved by his decision to set up Proyas as an agent of the [[Consult]]''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 10. == References == [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Characters from Galeoth]] [[Category:Queens]]

[[Nersei Thaila (younger)|Thaila]] (sister)}}'''Nersei Xinemus''' is the only son and heir of King [[Nersei Proyas]] of [[Conriya]] and his wife [[Miramis]]''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 2Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Xinemus, Nersei'. He was named after [[Krijates Xinemus]]. == Story == === ''What Came Before'' === His parents were married at some point after the [[Holy War|First Holy War]]. Xinemus was their first child, his sister [[Nersei Thaila (younger)|Thaila]] being born two years laterEncyclopedic Glossary II, 'Thaila, Nersei'. === ''The White-Luck Warrior'' === Proyas thinks of his family, including Xinemus and Thaila, whom he saw so rarely they had to be re­mind­ed he was their fa­ther whenever he returned home. When [[Fanayal ab Kascamandri|Fanayal]]'s army attacks [[Aöknyssus]], Xinemus and his mother and sister are removed to [[Attrempus]] for their safety''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 5. === ''The Unholy Consult'' === After Proyas is denounced as a traitor and strung up to be slowly left to die, [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Kellhus]] brings up Miramis, Xinemus and Thaila as lives that will be saved by his decision to set up Proyas as an agent of the [[Consult]]''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 10. Following his father's death, Xinemus is presumably now the King of Conriya. == References == [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Characters from Conriya]] [[Category:Kings]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Mixed ethnicity]]

[[Nersei Xinemus|Xinemus]] (brother)}}'''Nersei Thaila''' is the only daughter and second child of King [[Nersei Proyas]] of [[Conriya]] and his wife [[Miramis]]''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 2Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Thaila, Nersei'. She is presumably named after her [[Nersei Thaila (elder)|paternal grandmother]]''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 11[[Nersei Thaila (elder)|.]] == Story == === ''What Came Before'' === Her parents were married at some point after the [[Holy War|First Holy War]]. Thaila's brother [[Nersei Xinemus|Xinemus]] was their first child, and she was born two years laterEncyclopedic Glossary II, 'Xinemus, Nersei'. === ''The White-Luck Warrior'' === Proyas thinks of his family, including Xinemus and Thaila, whom he saw so rarely they had to be re­mind­ed he was their fa­ther whenever he returned home. When [[Fanayal ab Kascamandri|Fanayal]]'s army attacks [[Aöknyssus]], Thaila and her mother and brother are removed to [[Attrempus]] for their safety''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 5. === ''The Unholy Consult'' === After Proyas is denounced as a traitor and strung up to be slowly left to die, Kellhus brings up Miramis, Xinemus and Thaila as lives that will be saved by his decision to set up Proyas as an agent of the [[Consult]]''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 10. == References == [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Characters from Conriya]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Mixed ethnicity]]

''[[The Great Ordeal]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned)|lived = ? - ?|race = [[Men]]|ethnicity = [[Ketyai]]|nationality = [[Conriya]]n|gender = Female|occupation = Queen of [[Conriya]]|relatives = [[Nersei Eukernas II|Eukernas II]] (husband)
[[Nersei Tirummas|Tirummas]] (son)

[[Nersei Miramis|Miramis]] (daughter-in-law)
[[Nersei Xinemus|Xinemus]] (grandson)
[[Nersei Thaila (younger)|Thaila]] (granddaughter)}}'''Nersei Thaila''' was a Queen of [[Conriya]], wife to King [[Nersei Eukernas II]] and mother to [[Nersei Tirummas]] and [[Nersei Proyas]]. While she is mentioned in most books of the series, she is only named in ''[[The Unholy Consult]]''''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 11. Her [[Nersei Thaila (younger)|granddaughter]] was presumably named after her. == Story == === ''The Darkness That Comes Before'' === Achamian remembers falling in love with Proyas' "legendary mother" over the years he spent as Proyas' tutor in [[Aöknyssus]]''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 10. Later on, he also mentions how Thaila was furious over her son's delight at the answer Achamian had given him after being asked about the [[God of Gods|God]] ("I've heard many ru­mours, but I've nev­er met the man.") and almost dismissed him''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 15. === ''The Warrior-Prophet'' === Achamian thinks about how Proyas still looks much the same as he did as a boy, including his curly black hair, which his moth­er had "both cursed and adored"''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 23. === ''The Thousandfold Thought'' === Achamian remembers ac­com­pa­ny­ing Proyas and his moth­er to her dowa­ger es­tates in [[Anplei]]''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 4. At [[Shimeh]], Proyas casts his [[Chorae]] against one of the [[Cishaurim]], and thinks about how it had been a gift from his mother on his seventh birthday''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 16. === ''The White-Luck Warrior'' === Proyas recalls how, as a child, one of his duties had been to bear his moth­er's train at pub­lic ceremonies''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 10. === ''The Great Ordeal'' === Proyas remembers how his mother would sometimes weep over the dangerous things he used to do as a child, such as climbing trees to the peak''The Great Ordeal'', Chapter 4. === ''The Unholy Consult'' === Proyas thinks about how he had inherited the face and eyes of his mother, "just as the po­ets said"''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 8. == References == [[Category:Characters from Conriya]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Queens]]

The '''Company of Scions''' was a [[Kidruhil]] company in the [[Great Ordeal]] consisting solely of treaty hostages (male heirs of nations obligated to the [[New Empire]])<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Scions'</ref><ref name=":0">''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 10</ref>. It was the smallest of all Kidruhil companies, only having about a hundred members<ref name=":0" />.
The captain of the Scions was [[Xarotas Harnilas]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Harnilas, Xarotas'</ref><ref>''The Judging Eye'', Character and Faction Glossary</ref>.
== Known Members == * [[Baribul]] * [[Charampa]] * [[Tinurit]] * [[Tzing]] * [[Varalt Sorweel III|Varalt Sorweel]] * [[Zsoronga ut Nganka’kull|Zsoronga ut Nganka'kull]]
== References == <references /> [[Category:Organizations]]

The '''Stone Hags''' were a renegade [[Scalpoi|scalper]] com­pa­ny infamous for at­tack­ing oth­er com­pa­nies<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Stone Hags'</ref>. The captain of the Stone Hags was [[Pafaras]], a former [[Mysunsai]] Schoolman<ref>''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 3</ref>.
== Known Members == * [[Belmorn]] * [[Erydides]] * [[Heresius]] * [[Hilikas]] * [[Koll]] * [[Osilwas]] * [[Pafaras]] * [[Scroll]] * [[Tûborsa Hurm]] * [[Wulgulu]]
== References == <references /> [[Category:Organizations]]

'''House Daskas''' is one of the [[Houses of the Congregate]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Daskas, House'</ref>.
Men from this House were present at the at the celebrations of the Feast of Kus­sapokari in [[Momemn]] in 4111<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 19</ref>.
== References == <references /> [[Category:Houses]]

'''House Kiskei''' is one of the [[Houses of the Congregate]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Kiskei, House'</ref>.
== References == <references /> [[Category:Houses]]

'''House Ligesseras''' is one of the [[Houses of the Congregate]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Ligesseras, House'</ref>.
Men from this House were present at the at the celebrations of the Feast of Kus­sapokari in [[Momemn]] in 4111<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 19</ref>.
A member of this House, [[Ligesseras Arnius]], was a General in the [[Great Ordeal]] of [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]]<ref>''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 15</ref>.
== Known Members == * [[Ligesseras Arnius]]
== References == <references /> [[Category:Houses]]

'''House Gaunum''' is a [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] [[Houses of the Congregate|House of the Congregate]], with holdings scattered across the western [[Kyranae Plains|Kyranae Plain]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Gaunum, House'</ref>.
[[Serwë]] was sold by her father as a concubine to this House<ref name=":0">''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 13</ref>.
After the Patridomos and all his men left in the spring of 4111 following a summons by the [[Ikurei Xerius III|Emperor]], House Gaunum was sacked by a group of [[Scylvendi]] led by [[Panteruth urs Mutkius]]<ref name=":0" />. Most of the Gaunum wives and all the children were put to the sword by Panteruth and his [[Munuäti]], with the surviving women being taken as captives<ref name=":0" />.
Later that year, men of this House were present at the at the celebrations of the Feast of Kus­sapokari in [[Momemn]]<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 19</ref>.
== Known Members == * [[Gaunum Barastas]] * [[Gaunum Peristus]] * [[Patridomos of House Gaunum|Unnamed Patridomos]]
== References == <references /> [[Category:Houses]]

'''House Israti''' is one of the [[Houses of the Congregate]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Israti'</ref>.
The Patridomos of this House was one of the suitors spurned by [[Mimara]] during her time in the [[Andiamine Heights]]<ref name=":0">''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 6</ref>. He then brought a suit before the Judges, claiming she should be forced to marry him, but was dealt with by [[Esmenet]]<ref name=":0" />.
== References == <references /> [[Category:Houses]]

'''House Surmante''' was a for­mer [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] [[Houses of the Congregate|House of the Congregate]], and the Em­pire's ruling dynasty from 3619 to 3941<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Surmante, House'</ref>.
== Known Surmante Emperors == * [[Surmante Caphrianus I]] (reigned ?-3785)<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Caphrianus I'</ref> * [[Surmante Skilura II]] (reigned ?-3668)<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Skilura II'</ref> * [[Surmante Xatantius I]] (reigned 3668-3693)<ref name=":0" /><ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Xatantius I'</ref>
== References == <references /> [[Category:Houses]]

'''House Sorgis''' was a former [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] [[Houses of the Congregate|House of the Congregate]]. It was the Empire's ruling dynasty during a period of about ten thousand days at an unknown time in history<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Homirras, Ersa'</ref>.
[[Ersa Homirras]] wrote a history of this short-lived dynasty, titled ''[[The Ten Thousand Day Dynasty]]'', which was later banned by both the [[House Ikurei|Ikurei]] and the [[House Anasûrimbor|Anasûrimbor]]<ref name=":0" />.
== References == <references /> [[Category:Houses]]

'''Parthelsus''' was a [[Mandate|Mandate Schoolman]].
== Story ==
=== ''The Darkness That Comes Before'' === [[Seidru Nautzera|Nautzera]] informs [[Polchias Simas|Simas]] that Parthelsus has reported the mysterious disappearance of his primary informant in the [[Ce Tydonn|Tydonni]] court<ref>''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 2</ref>.
== References == <references /> [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Mandate]] [[Category:Gnostic sorcerers]] [[Category:Characters from the Three Seas]]

'''Nirimenes''' is an [[Great Ordeal|Ordealman]] and a sorcerer-of-rank in the [[Mandate|School of Mandate]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Nirimenes'</ref>.
== References == <references /> [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Mandate]] [[Category:Gnostic sorcerers]] [[Category:Characters from the Three Seas]] [[Category:Great Ordeal]]

"'''Zikas'''" is a term used to refer to the multiple women taken as concubines by [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]]<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Zikas'</ref><ref name=":1">''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 6</ref>. This name derives from the small libation bowls used on the Day of Ascension<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />.
There were at least seventeen Zikas, ten of which, according to [[Esmenet]], died in childbirth<ref name=":2">''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 3</ref>. A total of thirteen children resulting from these unions were born alive, but possessing severe deformities<ref name=":2" />. These were all drowned in wine according to [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]] custom<ref name=":2" />. Esmenet recalls that many people were murdered to keep this secret<ref name=":2" /> (it's unknown if this included the surviving Zikas).
== References == <references /> [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Characters from the Three Seas]] [[Category:Concubines]]
[[Category:Characters by affiliation]]
[[Category:Characters by occupation]]

'''House Nersei''' is the rul­ing House of [[Conriya]] since the [[Aöknyssian Uprisings]] of 3742, which saw the en­tire line of King [[Nejata Medekki]] mur­dered<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Nersei, House'</ref>. The Black Ea­gle on White is their de­vice<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Nersei, House'</ref>.
King Nersei Onoyas II was responsible for forging the al­liance be­tween the [[Mandate|School of Mandate]] and his House<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Onoyas II, Nersei'</ref>.
The fortress of [[Attrempus]] has been held in trust by House Nersei since 3921<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Attrempus'</ref>.
== Known Nersei Kings == * [[Nersei Eukernas II]] (reigned ?-?) * [[Nersei Onoyas II]] (reigned ?-3878)<ref name=":0" /> * [[Nersei Proyas]] (reigned ?-4132)<ref name=":1">''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 15</ref> * [[Nersei Xinemus]] (reigned 4132-present)<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Xinemus, Nersei'</ref><ref name=":1" />
== Known Members == * [[Nersei Calmemunis]] * [[Nersei Miramis]] (by marriage) * [[Nersei Sodhoras]] * [[Nersei Thaila (elder)|Nersei Thaila the Elder ]](by marriage) * [[Nersei Thaila (younger)|Nersei Thaila the Younger]] * [[Nersei Tirummas]]
== References == <references /> [[Category:Houses]]

'''House Coithus''' is the ruling dynasty of [[Galeoth]]<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Coithus, House'</ref>. Their device is the Red Li­on on Blue<ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 4</ref><ref>''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 5</ref>.
== Known Coithus Kings == * [[Coithus Eryeat]] (reigned ?-4116)<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Eryeat, Coithus'</ref> * [[Coithus Narnol]] (reigned 4116-present)<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Narnol, Coithus'</ref><ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Unification Wars'</ref>
== Known Members == * [[Coithus Agabon]] * [[Coithus Asilda]] * [[Coithus Athjeäri]] * [[Coithus Saubon]] * [[Nersei Miramis]]
== References == <references /> [[Category:Houses]]

'''House Hoga''' is the rul­ing dy­nasty of [[Agansanor]]<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Hoga, House'</ref>. The Black Stag on Green is their tra­di­tion­al de­vice<ref name=":0" />.
Under the [[New Empire]], House Hoga became the ruling dynasty of [[Ce Tydonn]], with Hoga Hogrim being declared Believer-King in 4119<ref name=":1">Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Unification Wars'</ref>.
== Known Hoga Kings == * [[Hoga Hogrim]] (reigned 4119-4132)<ref name=":1" /><ref>''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 18</ref>
== Known Members == * [[Hoga Gonrain]] * [[Hoga Gotheras]] * [[Hoga Gothyelk]] * [[Hoga Gurnyau]]
== References == <references /> [[Category:Houses]]

'''House Hringa''' has been the ruling dynasty of [[Thunyerus]] since 3987, when Hringa Hur­rausch was elected King by the Thunyeri tribes<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Thunyerus'</ref>.
== Known Hringa Kings == * [[Hringa Hurrausch]] (reigned 3987-?)<ref name=":0" /> * [[Hringa Rauschang]] (reigned ?-4114)<ref name=":1">Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Rauschang, Hringa'</ref> * [[Hringa Vûkyelt]] (reigned 4114-present)<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Vûkyelt, Hringa'</ref><ref name=":1" />
== Known Members == * [[Hringa Hulwarga]] * [[Hringa Magga]] * [[Hringa Narradha]] * [[Hringa Skaiyelt]]
== References == <references /> [[Category:Houses]]

'''Iërus Ilimenni''' was an [[Great Ordeal|Ordealman]] and [[Mandate|Mandate Schoolman]].{{Character_infobox|name = Iërus Ilimenni|appearances = ''[[The Unholy Consult]]''|lived = ? - 4132|race = [[Men]]|gender = Male|occupation = [[Mandate|Mandate Schoolman]]}}
== Story ==
=== ''What Came Before'' === Ilimenni was known as a childhood prodigy among the Mandate sorcerers<ref name=":0">''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 17</ref>. Shortly before the time of the Great Ordeal, he had joined the Quorum as its youngest member<ref name=":0" />.
=== ''The Unholy Consult'' === Ilimenni and his triunaries (one of which was [[Thanteus Eskeles]]) formed the van of the five triunes sent into the Obmaw<ref name=":0" />. However, unbeknownst to them, [[Skuthula]] guarded the Intrinsic Gate. The [[Wracu]] killed Ilimenni and most of his fellow Mandati, with only Eskeles managing to flee<ref name=":0" />.
== References == <references /> [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Characters from the Three Seas]] [[Category:Mandate]] [[Category:Great Ordeal]]

The '''Mbi­mayu '''are the major sor­cer­ous [[School]] of [[Zeüm]], based in [[Domyot|High Domyot]]<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Mbimayu'</ref>. They function un­der the auspices of the Satakhan, much as the [[Imperial Saik]] once served the Em­per­ors of [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]]<ref name=":0" />.
This School follows the [[Iswazi]] branch of sorcery. Mbimayu sorcerers wear gowns known as Erzû, stitched with one hundred and thirteen pockets for the corresponding number of fetishes they traditionally use<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Erzû'</ref>. They also don omba, face masks of black gauze used to better cope with the glare of sorcery<ref>Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'omba'</ref>.
== Known Members == * [[Likaro]] * [[Malowebi]] * [[Wobazul]] * [[Zabwiri]] (Grandmaster)
== References == <references /> [[Category:Schools]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Nersei Eukernas II|titles = King|nicknames = Onoyas|appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Warrior-Prophet]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Thousandfold Thought (Book)|The Thousandfold Thought]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned)|lived = ? - ?|race = [[Men]]|ethnicity = [[Ketyai]]|nationality = [[Conriya]]n|gender = Male|occupation = King of [[Conriya]]|relatives = [[Nersei Thaila (elder)|Thaila]] (wife)
[[Nersei Tirummas|Tirummas]] (son)
[[Nersei Proyas|Proyas]] (son)
[[Nersei Miramis|Miramis]] (daughter-in-law)
[[Nersei Calmemunis|Calmemunis]] (nephew or cousin)
[[Nersei Sodhoras|Sodhoras]] (nephew or cousin)
[[Nersei Xinemus|Xinemus]] (grandson)
[[Nersei Thaila (younger)|Thaila]] (granddaughter)}}'''Nersei Eukernas II''' was a King of [[Conriya]], husband to Queen [[Nersei Thaila (elder)|Thaila]] and father to [[Nersei Tirummas]] and [[Nersei Proyas]]. == Story == === ''What Came Before'' === Before his son Proyas was born, Eukernas was bested by [[Hoga Gothyelk]] in the [[Battle of Maän]]''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 17. From then on, he called his limp "Gothyelk's gift". The last of [[House Nersei]]'s ancestral rivals, the [[House Nejata|Nejati]], were executed during his reign, which was the cause of an argument between Eukernas and Proyas''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 8. Eukernas considered that the murder of these children was necessary to protect his sons and his people from a future war. When Eukernas' older son and heir Tirummas died at sea in 4100, his younger son Proyas became Crown PrinceEncyclopedic Glossary, 'Tirummas, Nersei'. === ''The Darkness That Comes Before'' === When talking to [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Kellhus]] about Hoga Gothyelk, Proyas mentions the Battle of Maän and his father's injury. === ''The Warrior-Prophet'' === Proyas thinks to himself that [[Cnaiür urs Skiötha|Cnaiür]] is not that much younger than his father''The Warrior-Prophet'', Chapter 19. === ''The Thousandfold Thought'' === Proyas writes a letter to his father retelling the encounter between Kellhus and a mysterious blind beggar in Gim''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 11. === ''Life in the New Empire'' === Eukernas died at some point after the conquest of [[Shimeh]] and the beginning of the [[Great Ordeal]], with Proyas succeeding him as King of Conriya. On his deathbed, he called for his son, knowing (and maybe even hoping) he would not come''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 10. === The Unholy Consult === Faced with his own impending death, Proyas thinks of his father, and comes to the conclusion that he was right all along in his decision to have the Nejati killed, and in his belief that "power is damnation". He also recalls how Eukernas had called for him on his deathbed. == Trivia == This character is named for the first time in ''The Thousandfold Thought'', where his name is given as "Eukernas II"''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 4. However, in ''The Unholy Consult'', he is referred to as "Onoyas"''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 11. It's unknown which of the two is his actual canon name. == References == [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Characters from Conriya]] [[Category:Kings]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Eppaltros|appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]'' (mentioned)|lived = ? - ?|race = [[Men]]|gender = Male|occupation = Groom}}'''Eppaltros''' was a groom in the [[House Gaunum|Gaunum]] household.
== Appearance == According to [[Serwë]], Eppaltros was a beautiful man<ref name=":0">''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 19</ref>.
== Story ==
=== ''What Came Before'' === At some point during Serwë's years as a Gaunum concubine, Eppaltros stole into the dormitory and made love to [[Aälsa]]<ref name=":0" />. However, he was later denounced by someone unknown and put to death<ref name=":0" />.
=== ''The Darkness That Comes Before'' === Serwë remembers the incident leading to Eppaltros' death<ref name=":0" />.
== References == <references /> [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Characters from the Three Seas]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Aälsa|appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]'' (mentioned)|lived = ? - present?|race = [[Men]]|gender = Female|occupation = Concubine}}'''Aälsa''' was (presumably) a concubine of [[House Gaunum]].
== Story ==
=== ''What Came Before'' === At some point during Serwë's years as a concubine, [[Eppaltros]] stole into the dormitory and made love to Aälsa, which later led to his death after he was denounced<ref name=":0">''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 19</ref>.
=== ''The Darkness That Comes Before'' === Serwë remembers the incident between Eppaltros and Aälsa<ref name=":0" />.
It's unknown if Aälsa was among the women taken as captives by [[Panteruth urs Mutkius|Panteruth]] urs Mutkius and his [[Munuäti]] and later set free by [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]] and [[Cnaiür urs Skiötha]].
== References == <references /> [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Characters from the Three Seas]] [[Category:Slaves]] [[Category:Concubines]]
[[Category:Characters by race/ethnicity]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Anasûrimbor Sanna-Jephera|nicknames = Twoheart|appearances = Mentioned online only|lived = 825 - 1032|race = [[Men|Man]]-[[Nonmen|Nonman]] hybrid|ethnicity = (Half-)[[Norsirai]]|nationality = [[Ûmeri Empire|Ûmeri]]|gender = Male|relatives = [[Anasûrimbor Sanna-Neorjë|Sanna-Neorjë]] (grandfather)
[[Anasûrimbor Omindalea|Omindalea]] (mother)
[[Jiricet]] (father)
At least one unnamed auntAs Omindalea is referred to as Sanna-Neorjë's "first daughter", this means he had at least one other younger daughter.}}'''Anasûrimbor Sanna-Jephera''', known as "Twoheart", was the son of [[Anasûrimbor Omindalea]], conceived when she was raped by the [[Nonman]] [[Siqû]] [[Jiricet]][http://forum.three-seas.com/posts/4944 R. Scott Bakker on Three Seas Forum]. His mother died giving birth to him. After Sanna-Jephera impregnated a house-slave at some point during his youth, he was officially adopted as his grandfather [[Anasûrimbor Sanna-Neorjë|Sanna-Neorjë]]'s heir. House Anasûrimbor thus continued through his line. ==Notes== == References == [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Cûnuroi]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Characters from the Ûmeri Empire]] [[Category:Anasûrimbor]] [[Category:Hybrids]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Anasûrimbor Sanna-Neorjë|appearances = Mentioned online only|lived = 772 - 858|race = [[Men]]|ethnicity = [[Norsirai]]|nationality = [[Ûmeri Empire|Ûmeri]]|gender = Male|relatives = [[Anasûrimbor Omindalea|Omindalea]] (daughter)
At least one unnamed daughterAs Omindalea is referred to as Sanna-Neorjë's "first daughter", this means he had at least one other younger daughter.
[[Anasûrimbor Sanna-Jephera|Sanna-Jephera]] (grandson)}}'''Anasûrimbor Sanna-Neorjë''' was the head of House Anasûrimbor in the [[Ûmeri Empire]] by 824, and the father of [[Anasûrimbor Omindalea|Omindalea]][http://forum.three-seas.com/posts/4944 R. Scott Bakker on Three Seas Forum]. His daughter's rape by the [[Nonmen|Nonman]] [[Jiricet]] eventually resulted in the expulsion of all Nonmen from the empire, ending the [[Nonman Tutelage]]Encyclopedic Glossary, 'Nonmen Tutelage'. Later in life, Sanna-Neorjë adopted his hybrid grandson, [[Anasûrimbor Sanna-Jephera|Sanna-Jephera]], as his heir after the latter impregnated a house-slave. The line of Sanna-Neorjë and House Anasûrimbor thus continued through Sanna-Jephera. ==Notes== == References == [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Characters from the Ûmeri Empire]] [[Category:Anasûrimbor]]

'''House Anasûrimbor''' (not to be confused with the [[Kûniüri|Kûniüric]] [[Anasûrimbor Dynasty|Anasûrimbor dynasty]]) is the ruling dynasty of the [[New Empire]]<ref>''The Judging Eye'', Character and Faction Glossary</ref>. It was established in 4112, when [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Anasûrimbor Kellhus I]] was declared [[Aspect-Emperor (Title)|Aspect-Emperor]]<ref name=":0">The Thousandfold Thought, Chapter 17</ref>.
== Anasûrimbor Aspect-Emperors == * [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Anasûrimbor Kellhus I]] (reigned 4112-4132)<ref name=":0" /><ref>''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 20</ref>
== House Anasûrimbor Members == * [[Anasûrimbor Inrilatas]] * [[Anasûrimbor Kayûtas]] * [[Anasûrimbor Kelmomas]] * [[Anasûrimbor Moënghus II]] (by adoption) * [[Anasûrimbor Samarmas]] * [[Anasûrimbor Serwa]] * [[Anasûrimbor Theliopa]] * [[Esmenet]] (by marriage) * [[Maithanet]] * [[Mimara]] (by marriage)
== References == <references /> [[Category:Houses]]

{{Character_infobox|titles = Empress|appearances = ''[[The Darkness That Comes Before]]'' (mentioned)|lived = ? - present?|race = [[Men]]|ethnicity = [[Ketyai]]|nationality = [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]]|gender = Female|occupation = Empress of [[Nansur Empire|Nansur]]|relatives = [[Ikurei Istriya|Istriya]] (mother-in-law, possibly grandmother)
[[Ikurei Conphas|Conphas]] (half-brother)
[[Ikurei Xerius III|Xerius]] (husband, possibly uncle)}}This unnamed character was the half-sister of [[Ikurei Conphas]] and wife to [[Ikurei Xerius III]]''The Darkness That Comes Before'', Chapter 7. It is unknown whether she was Conphas' paternal or maternal half-sister. == Story == === ''The Darkness That Comes Before'' === As the Imperial Family sails through the [[River Phayus]], Conphas asks Xerius about his half-sister. Xerius replies that she is a "satisfactory wife", with [[Ikurei Istriya|Istriya]] remarking that "her womb remains closed" nonetheless. === Later Events === It is not known if this character survived the events of ''[[The Prince of Nothing]]''. == References == [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Ketyai]] [[Category:Characters from Nansur]] [[Category:Empresses]]
[[Category:Men]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Nurbanu Ze|titles = Palatine
Prince|appearances = ''[[The White-Luck Warrior]]''
''[[The Great Ordeal]]''
''[[The Unholy Consult]]''|lived = 4105 - 4132|race = [[Men]]|ethnicity = [[Xiuhianni]]|nationality = [[Jekhia|Jekki]] (by birth)
[[High Ainon|Ainoni]] (by adoption)|gender = Male|occupation = Palatine of [[Jekhia|Jekk]]
Prince of [[High Ainon]]
General of the Jekki contingent of the [[Great Ordeal]]|relatives = [[Nurbanu Soter|Soter]] (adoptive father)}}'''Nurbanu Ze''' was an [[Great Ordeal|Ordealman]] and the [[Jekhia|Jekki]] adopted son of King [[Nurbanu Soter]]''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 2Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Ze, Nurbanu'. == Story == === What Came Before === At some point between the conquest of [[Shimeh]] and the beginning of the Great Ordeal's march, Ze was adopted by Soter. It's likely this adoption took place during the [[Unification Wars]]. He was the first known Jekki to be considered a [[caste|caste-noble]]. === ''The White-Luck Warrior'' === Ze led the Jekki contigent of the army of the [[Ketyai]] of the East. === ''The Great Ordeal'' === Under the influence of the Meat, Ze claimed that their [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Lord-and-Prophet]] had became their butcher''The Great Ordeal'', Chapter 10. === ''The Unholy Consult'' === When [[Nersei Proyas]] addressed the Ordealmen, telling them their Holy Aspect-Emperor had charged him with leading the final march to [[Golgotterath]], Ze franctically interrupted him''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 3. He then declared that the [[Scald]] had consumed their Aspect-Emperor, and that his own men had witnessed this. To avoid further chaos among the Great Ordeal, [[Anasûrimbor Kayûtas]] quickly intervened, killing Ze. == References == [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Xiuhianni]] [[Category:Characters from Jekhia]] [[Category:Palatines]] [[Category:Great Ordeal]]
[[Category:Characters from Eärwa]]
[[Category:Men]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Risaphial|appearances = ''[[The Unholy Consult]]''|lived = ? - 4132|race = [[Cûnuroi]]|nationality = [[Cil-Aujas]]|gender = Male|occupation = [[Qûya]]
Member of the [[Consult]]|relatives = [[Gin'yursis]] (uncle)}}'''Risaphial''' was a [[Nonmen|Nonman]] [[Qûya]] and the nephew of [[Gin'yursis]]''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 15. == Story == === What Came Before === Risaphial joined the [[Consult]] at an unknown date. === ''The Unholy Consult'' === Risaphial was part of the group of Qûya that fought the [[Swayal Compact|Swayali]], [[Mandate|Mandati]] and [[Mysunsai]] under [[Anasûrimbor Serwa]] during the battle for [[Golgotterath]]. He was killed during this confrontation. == References == [[Category:Cûnuroi]] [[Category:Qûya]] [[Category:Consult members]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Mimotil|nicknames = Mimotil Cravenhearted|appearances = ''[[The Unholy Consult]]''|lived = ? - 4132|race = [[Cûnuroi]]|nationality = [[Siöl|Siölan]]|gender = Male|occupation = [[Qûya]]
Member of the [[Consult]]}}'''Mimotil''', known as '''Mimotil Cravenhearted''', was a [[Nonmen|Nonman]] [[Qûya]] and member of the [[Consult]]''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 15. == Story == === What Came Before === Mimotil was the Bearer of the Copper Tree at the [[Battle of Pir Minginnial]]. He later joined the Consult under unknown circumstances. === ''The Unholy Consult'' === Mimotil was part of a group of Qûya that fought the mages of the [[Great Ordeal]] led by [[Anasûrimbor Serwa]]. He was killed during this confrontation. == References == [[Category:Cûnuroi]] [[Category:Qûya]] [[Category:Consult members]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Cu'cûlol|appearances = ''[[The Unholy Consult]]''|lived = ? - 4132|race = [[Cûnuroi]]|nationality = [[Siöl|Siölan]]|gender = Male|occupation = [[Qûya]]
Member of the [[Consult]]|relatives = [[Cû’jara-Cinmoi]] (kinsman)}}'''Cu'cûlol''' was a [[Nonmen|Nonman]] [[Qûya]] and member of the [[Consult]]''The Unholy Consult'', Chapter 15. He was a kinsman of [[Cû’jara-Cinmoi|Cû'jara-Cinmoi]]. == Story == === What Came Before === Cu'cûlol joined the Consult at an unknown date. === ''The Unholy Consult'' === Cu'cûlol was among the Qûya who fought the [[Swayal Compact|Swayali]], [[Mandate|Mandati]] and [[Mysunsai]] under [[Anasûrimbor Serwa]] during the battle for [[Golgotterath]]. He was one of the casualties of this confrontation. == Trivia == Cu'cûlol is referred to as "impossibly ancient", meaning he could quite possibly have been the second oldest living Nonman (after [[Morimhira]]) before his death in 4132. == References == [[Category:Cûnuroi]] [[Category:Qûya]] [[Category:Consult members]]

'''Yi'yariccas''' was a venerated [[Qûya]] sage<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Aghurzoi'</ref>.
He was notable for questioning how [[Sranc]] [[Aghurzoi|words]] could have a meaning given their complete lack of experience<ref name=":0" />.
== References == <references /> [[Category:Cûnuroi]] [[Category:Qûya]]

'''Damial'isharin''' was a [[Siöl|Siölan]] [[Ishroi]]<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Aghurzoi'</ref>.
He was once trapped in the heart of an itinerant [[Sranc]] camp for five days (being hidden in a dead fall during that time)<ref name=":0" />. After this experience, he famously claimed that the Sranc possessed social customs and regimes that were almost as complex as that of the [[Cûnuroi]]<ref name=":0" />.
== References == <references /> [[Category:Cûnuroi]] [[Category:Ishroi]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Tsinirû|titles = Queen|appearances = ''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned)|lived = ? - ?|race = [[Cûnuroi]]|nationality = [[Ishoriöl]]|gender = Female|occupation = Queen of [[Ishoriöl]]|relatives = [[Sin'niroiha]] (husband)
[[Nil'giccas]] (son)
Unnamed daughter-in-law
Several unnamed grandsons
Several unnamed granddaughters}}'''Tsinirû''' was the Queen of [[Ishoriöl]]Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Nihrimsûl', wife of [[Sin'niroiha]] and mother of [[Nil'giccas]]Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Emilidis'. == Skills == She was renowned as "one of the most gifted of the [[Qûya|Quyil]]"Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Ishterebinth'. == Story == Tsinirû is known to have married Sin'niroiha after he was given the [[Day Lantern]] by [[Emilidis]] (it is not known if the marriage was a direct or more indirect result of this event). This marriage allowed all the [[Mansions]] to finally be united under the Blood of [[Tsonos]] (as Sin'niroiha was not of this lineage)Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Sin'niroiha'. Nil'giccas was the only known child of Sin'niroiha and Tsinirû. Nothing is known of Tsinirû's life after the birth of her son, though it is possible she perished as a result of the [[Womb-Plague]]. == Trivia == * Tsinirû is the only known female Qûya. * She is also one of only two female monarchs reigning in their own right to be mentioned in the series (the other being the [[Ûmeri Empire|Ûmeri]] Empress [[Avalunsil]]). == References == [[Category:Cûnuroi]] [[Category:Qûya]] [[Category:Queens]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Avalunsil|titles = Empress|nicknames = The Twice-Flowered|appearances = ''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned)|lived = ca. 820 - ca. 860|race = [[Men]]|ethnicity = [[Norsirai]]|nationality = [[Ûmeri Empire|Ûmeri]]|gender = Female|occupation = Empress of the [[Ûmeri Empire]]|relatives = [[Wulta-Ongorean]] (father)}}'''Avalunsil''' was a [[Far Antiquity|Far Antique]] legendary [[Ûmeri Empire|Ûmeri]] Empress<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Avalunsil'</ref>.
== Story == After Avalunsil's father, [[Wulta-​Ongorean]], was executed by the [[Sketti Empire|Skettic]] chieftain [[Symaul]], she took revenge by murdering Symaul with a fish knife<ref name=":0" />. This event led to the creation of the Bardic lays known as Harsunci or "fish knives"<ref name=":0" />.
Avalunsil went on to rule as Empress of the Ûmeri Empire<ref name=":0" />. She eventually became known as the "Twice-Flowered" for refusing to marry<ref name=":0" />. According to legend, she was assassinated by one of her spurned suitors<ref name=":0" />.
== Trivia == * Avalunsil is one of only two female monarchs reigning in their own right mentioned in the series (the other being [[Tsinirû]], Queen of [[Ishoriöl]]).
== References == <references /> [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Characters from the Ûmeri Empire]] [[Category:Empresses]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Wulta-Ongorean|titles = Emperor|appearances = ''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned)|lived = ? - ?|race = [[Men]]|ethnicity = [[Norsirai]]|nationality = [[Ûmeri Empire|Ûmeri]]|gender = Male|occupation = Emperor of the [[Ûmeri Empire]]|relatives = [[Avalunsil]] (daughter)}}'''Wulta-Ongorean''' was a [[Far Antiquity|Far Antique]] [[Ûmeri Empire|Ûmeri]] Emperor and the father of [[Avalunsil]]<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Avalunsil'</ref>.
== Story == Wulta-Ongorean was executed by the [[Skettic]] chieftain [[Symaul]] under unknown circumstances<ref name=":0" />. His daughter and eventual successor Avalunsil avenged his death by murdering Symaul with a fish knife<ref name=":0" />.
== References == <references /> [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Characters from the Ûmeri Empire]] [[Category:Emperors]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Symaul|titles = Chieftain|appearances = ''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned)|lived = ? - ?|race = [[Men]]|ethnicity = [[Norsirai]]|nationality = [[Skettic]]|gender = Male|occupation = Chieftain}}'''Symaul''' was a [[Far Antiquity|Far Antique]] [[Skettic]] chieftain<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Avalunsil'</ref>.
== Story == Symaul executed the [[Ûmeri Empire|Ûmeri]] Emperor [[Wulta-Ongorean]] under unknown circumstances<ref name=":0" />. He was in turn murdered by Wulta-Ongorean's daughter [[Avalunsil]], who used a fish knife to kill him<ref name=":0" />. This event led to the creation of the Bardic lays known as Harsunci or "fish knives"<ref name=":0" />.
== References == <references /> [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Norsirai]]

revision.comment: Created page with "'''Lurijara''' was a famously heretical scholar<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Aghurzoi'</ref>. He was among those who argued that all language was dark, and that m..."
revision.text:
'''Lurijara''' was a famously heretical scholar<ref name=":0">Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Aghurzoi'</ref>.
He was among those who argued that all language was dark, and that meaning was the province of [[sorcerer|sorcerers]] and [[Gods]] alone<ref name=":0" />. This school of thought was based on [[Damial’isharin|Damial'isharin]]'s declarations concerning the social customs of [[Sranc]]<ref name=":0" />.
== References == <references />

{{Character_infobox|name = Suberd|titles = King|appearances = ''[[The Judging Eye]]'' (mentioned)|lived = ? - ?|race = [[Men]]|ethnicity = [[Norsirai]]|nationality = [[Sakarpus|Sakarpi]]|gender = Male|occupation = King of [[Sakarpus]]}}'''Suberd''' was a legendary King of [[Sakarpus]]<ref name=":0">''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 15</ref>.
== Story == According to ancient Sakarpi legend, Suberd tried to seduce [[Aelswë]], the mortal daughter of [[Gilgaöl]], and in doing so doomed his line forever<ref name=":0" />. The legend of Suberd's seduction of Aelswë is known to include the line "Ware her, my King, she walks with the [[Gods]]"<ref name=":0" />.
[[Varalt Sorweel III|Varalt Sorweel]] is reminded of this particular legend and quote by [[Thanteus Eskeles]] when the latter sees him looking at [[Anasûrimbor Serwa]]<ref name=":0" />.
== References == <references /> [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Characters from Sakarpus]] [[Category:Kings]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Aelswë|appearances = ''[[The Judging Eye]]'' (mentioned)|lived = ? - ?|race = [[Men]] (though of [[Gods|divine parentage]])|ethnicity = [[Norsirai]] (presumably)|nationality = [[Sakarpus|Sakarpi]] (presumably)|gender = Female|relatives = [[Gilgaöl]] (father)}}'''Aelswë''' was the mortal daughter of [[Gilgaöl]] according to ancient [[Sakarpus|Sakarpi]] legend<ref name=":0">''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 15</ref>.
== Story == The Sakarpi King [[Suberd]] is known to have tried to seduce Aelswë, which caused his line to be doomed forever<ref name=":0" />. It is unknown if this occurred due to the actions of Aelswë herself, or if it was perhaps a result of divine intervention from Gilgaöl.
[[Varalt Sorweel III|Varalt Sorweel]] is reminded of the legend involving Suberd and Aelswë by [[Thanteus Eskeles]] when caught looking at [[Anasûrimbor Serwa]]<ref name=":0" />.
== References == <references /> [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Norsirai]] [[Category:Characters from Sakarpus]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Aisarinqu|appearances = ''[[The Four Revelations of Cinial’jin|Four Revelations]]'' (flashback)|lived = ? - ?|race = [[Cûnuroi]]|nationality = [[Siöl|Siölan]]|gender = Female|relatives = [[Cinial’jin]] (husband)
[[Immiriccas]] (son)
[[Aisralu]] (daughter)
[[Enpiralas]] (son)
[[Pil’kmiras]] (cousin by marriage)}}'''Aisarinqu''' was the wife of [[Cinial’jin|Cinial'jin]] and (presumably) the mother of [[Immiriccas]], [[Aisralu]] and [[Enpiralas]]''Four Revelations''Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Immiriccas'. == Story == Aisarinqu and Cinial'jin's marriage was not a happy one, which allowed him to be able to recall the memories of their time together even after becoming [[Erratic]]. According to her husband's recollections, Aisarinqu was a victim of the [[Womb-Plague]]. == References == [[Category:Cûnuroi]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Aisralu|appearances = ''[[The Four Revelations of Cinial’jin|Four Revelations]]'' (flashback)|lived = ? - ?|race = [[Cûnuroi]]|nationality = [[Siöl|Siölan]]|gender = Female|relatives = [[Cinial’jin]] (father)
[[Aisarinqu]] (mother)
[[Immiriccas]] (brother)
[[Enpiralas]] (brother)
[[Pil’kmiras]] (cousin)}}'''Aisralu''' was the daughter of [[Cinial’jin|Cinial'jin]] and (presumably) [[Aisarinqu]]''Four Revelations''. == Story == Aisralu contracted the [[Womb-Plague]]. Unable to bear a slow and agonizing death, she asked her father to kill her; he eventually complied. == References == [[Category:Cûnuroi]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Enpiralas|appearances = ''[[The Four Revelations of Cinial’jin|Four Revelations]]'' (flashback)|lived = ? - ?|race = [[Cûnuroi]]|nationality = [[Siöl|Siölan]]|gender = Male|occupation = [[Ishroi]] (presumably)|relatives = [[Cinial’jin]] (father)

[[Aisralu]] (sister)
[[Pil’kmiras]] (cousin)}}'''Enpiralas''' was the younger son of [[Cinial’jin|Cinial'jin]] and (presumably) [[Aisarinqu]]''Four Revelations''. == Story == Enpiralas was killed in the [[Battle of Pir Minginnial]], and his body was then taken to his father on an [[Inchoroi]] shield. == References == [[Category:Cûnuroi]] [[Category:Ishroi]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Pil'kmiras|appearances = ''[[The Four Revelations of Cinial’jin|Four Revelations]]'' (flashback)|lived = ? - ?|race = [[Cûnuroi]]|nationality = [[Siöl|Siölan]]|gender = Male|occupation = [[Ishroi]] (presumably)|relatives = [[Cinial’jin]] (cousin)

[[Enpiralas]] (cousin)}}'''Pil'kmiras''' was the cousin of [[Cinial’jin|Cinial'jin]]''Four Revelations''. == Story == Cinial'jin recalls Pil'kmiras curled up on the dust "like a dog" and coughing. It is unknown when this took place (possibly during the [[Cûno-Inchoroi Wars]]) and what Pil'kmiras' eventual fate was. == References == [[Category:Cûnuroi]] [[Category:Ishroi]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Par'sigiccas|appearances = ''[[The Four Revelations of Cinial’jin|Four Revelations]]'' (flashback)|lived = ? - ?|race = [[Cûnuroi]]|nationality = [[Siöl|Siölan]] (presumably)|gender = Male|occupation = [[Ishroi]]}}'''Par'sigiccas''' was an [[Ishroi]] who fought in the [[Cûno-Inchoroi Wars]]<ref name=":0">''Four Revelations''</ref>.
== Story == [[Cinial’jin|Cinial'jin]] recalls fighting alongside Par'sigiccas, [[Tinnirin]] and [[Rama]] during the Cûno-Inchoroi Wars<ref name=":0" />. Par'sigiccas was ultimately killed by [[Skafra]], half of his body being completely burned<ref name=":0" />.
== References == <references /> [[Category:Cûnuroi]] [[Category:Ishroi]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Tinnirin|appearances = ''[[The Four Revelations of Cinial’jin|Four Revelations]]'' (flashback)|lived = ? - ?|race = [[Cûnuroi]]|nationality = [[Siöl|Siölan]] (presumably)|gender = Male|occupation = [[Ishroi]]}}'''Tinnirin''' was an [[Ishroi]] who fought in the [[Cûno-Inchoroi Wars]]<ref name=":0">''Four Revelations''</ref>.
== Story == [[Cinial’jin|Cinial'jin]] recalls fighting alongside Tinnirin, [[Rama]] and [[Par’sigiccas|Par'sigiccas]] during the Cûno-Inchoroi Wars<ref name=":0" />. Tinnirin's eventual fate is unknown.
== References == <references /> [[Category:Cûnuroi]] [[Category:Ishroi]]

== Story == [[Cinial’jin]] recalls fighting alongside Rama, [[Tinnirin]] and [[Par’sigiccas|Par'sigiccas]] during the Cûno-Inchoroi Wars<ref name=":0" />. Rama was killed by an unnamed [[Inchoroi]] during the wars<ref name=":0" />.
== References == <references /> [[Category:Cûnuroi]] [[Category:Ishroi]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Cet'moyol|titles = Prince|appearances = ''[[The Great Ordeal]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned)|lived = ? - ?|race = [[Cûnuroi]]|nationality = [[Siöl|Siölan]]|gender = Male|occupation = Prince of [[Siöl]]|relatives = [[Cu’huriol]] (father)
[[Morimhira]] (uncle)
[[Linqirû]] (sister/lover)
[[Cû’jara-Cinmoi]] (son)
[[Hanalinqû]] (daughter-in-law)
[[Cu’cûlol]] (kinsman)}}'''Cet'moyol''' was the son of [[Cu’huriol|Cu'huriol]], King of [[Siöl]], and the father of [[Cû’jara-Cinmoi|Cû'jara-Cinmoi]]Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Cû'jara Cinmoi'. == Story == Cet'moyol and his sister [[Linqirû]] engaged in an incestuous affair, leading to the birth of Cû'jara-Cinmoi. After the birth of their son, both Cet'moyol and Linqirû were executed on their father's orders. The affair between Cet'moyol and Linqirû is recounted in the [[Lay of Linqirû]] (also known as the Incest Song of Linqirû)Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Incest Song of Linqirû'''The Great Ordeal'', Chapter 12. It is also frequently compared to the legendary relationship between [[Tsonos]] and his sister [[Olissis]]. == Trivia == * Cet'moyol's name is spelled "Cet'moiol" in chapter 12 of ''The Great Ordeal''. == References == [[Category:Cûnuroi]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Linqirû|titles = Princess|appearances = ''[[The Great Ordeal]]'' (mentioned)
''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned)|lived = ? - ?|race = [[Cûnuroi]]|nationality = [[Siöl|Siölan]]|gender = Female|occupation = Princess of [[Siöl]]|relatives = [[Cu’huriol]] (father)

[[Cet’moyol]] (brother/lover)

[[Hanalinqû]] (daughter-in-law)
[[Cu’cûlol]] (kinsman)}}'''Linqirû''' was the daughter of [[Cu’huriol|Cu'huriol]], King of [[Siöl]], and mother of [[Cû’jara-Cinmoi|Cû'jara-Cinmoi]]Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Cû'jara Cinmoi'. == Story == Linqirû and her brother [[Cet’moyol|Cet'moyol]] engaged in an incestuous affair, which resulted in the birth of Cû'jara-Cinmoi. At some point following the birth of their son, both Linqirû and Cet'moyol were executed on their father's orders. The affair between Linqirû and her brother is recounted in the [[Lay of Linqirû]] (also known as the Incest Song of Linqirû)Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Incest Song of Linqirû'''The Great Ordeal'', Chapter 12. Their relationship has also been compared to that of the legendary [[Tsonos]] and [[Olissis]]. == References == [[Category:Cûnuroi]]

{{Character_infobox|name = Cu'huriol|titles = King|appearances = ''[[The Unholy Consult]]'' (mentioned)|lived = ? - ?|race = [[Cûnuroi]]|nationality = [[Siöl|Siölan]]|gender = Male|occupation = King of [[Siöl]]|relatives = [[Morimhira]] (brother)
[[Cet’moyol]] (son)
[[Linqirû]] (daughter)
[[Cû’jara-Cinmoi]] (grandson)
[[Cu’cûlol]] (kinsman)}}'''Cu'huriol''' was the King of [[Siöl]] before [[Arkfall]] and the grandfather of [[Cû’jara-Cinmoi|Cû'jara-Cinmoi]]Encyclopedic Glossary II, 'Cu'huriol'. == Story == Cu'huriol became King of Siöl after his elder brother [[Morimhira]] refused the Seal of the House PrimordialEncyclopedic Glossary II, 'Morimhira'. He had at least two children, [[Cet’moyol|Cet'moyol]] and [[Linqirû]], whose incestuous affair eventually resulted in the birth of Cû'jara-CinmoiEncyclopedic Glossary II, 'Cû'jara Cinmoi'. Cu'huriol had both of his children executed for their scandalous affair, but spared the life of his grandson and raised him as his heir. After the death of Cu'huriol, Cû'jara-Cinmoi lost much of the popularity he had gained during his early life. == References == [[Category:Cûnuroi]] [[Category:Kings]]

[[File:Oinaral Oirunarig.jpg|thumb|The Last born meets his father in the bowels of the mountain ]] Oinaral Oirunarig, son of [[Oirûnas]], called Lastborn for being the last Cunuroi born after the Womb Plague. He provoked his Erratic father Oirunas into killing him, restoring his memory so that Oirunas could overthrow the Consult-aligned Ninjilciras.

'''Murathaur''' was a [[Wracu|dragon]] of [[Far Antiquity]], called ''Ilnimli ''or "the Silver" for his silver scales and crest, a feature responsible for his other cognomen, "the Dragon of Knives". Famously slain in the [[Cuno-Inchoroi Wars]] by [[Cilculiccas]].

One of the two great siege-towers constructed by the Men of the Tusk in 4112, along with a second siege-tower, "Sister," during the battle for [[Shimeh]].
[[Sristai Ingiaban|Ingiaban]] was heard wondering whether the siege-tower would be tall enough "to give Shimeh's towers a kiss." [[Shressa Gaidekki|Gaidekki]] replied that "she need only stand on her tippytoes."<ref>''The Thousandfold Thought'', Chapter 15</ref>
While Sister was brought down, along with Count-Palatine Gaidekki, before reaching her destination, Tippytoes reached the walls allowing [[Nersei Proyas|Neresi Proyas]] and his [[Conriyan|kinsmen]] to storm the battlements.

{{Character_infobox|name=Eleva|titles=High Priestess|appearances=The Judging Eye (imposter)|lived=? - (before 4132)|gender=Female|occupation=High Priestess of the Cult of Yatwer}}
'''Eleva''' was a High Priestess of the [[Cult of Yatwer]] during the time of the early days of the [[Great Ordeal]].
She had been replaced by a [[Witch]] of the [[Swayal Compact]] sometime prior the convening of the [[Struck Table]] in the spring of 4132. During this convention, the Witch masquerading as Eleva was uncovered and killed by [[Psatma Nannaferi]] through the use of her [[Chorae]].<ref>''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 5</ref>
It is likely that the original Eleva was murdered to ensure the success of her Swayal replacement.
== References == <references />

The '''Struck Table''' is an immense stone table located in the Charnal Hall within [[Ilchara Catacombs]]. Is it where the leadership of the [[Cult of Yatwer]] convenes on rare occasions, the last time occurring in the spring of 4132 where [[Psatma Nannaferi]] announced of the coming of the [[White-Luck Warrior]].<ref name=":0">''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 5</ref>
According to legend, the Struck Table is where [[Yatwer]] herself had once 'chastised her wayward daughters.'<ref name=":0" />
== References ==

A holy site for the Cult of Yatwer, the '''Ilchara Catacombs''' are a maze of subterranean chambers located under the now-destroyed Temple of Ilchara in [[Iothiah]]. Also referred to as the Womb-of-the-Dead, the ashes of Yatwer's priestesses had been interred within the Catacombs for thousands of years, since the days of the Old Dynasty.''The Judging Eye'', Chapter 5
== References ==

revision.comment: Created page with "The [[Scalper]] name for the ruins of the ancient fortress of [[Aenkû Maimor]], located beneath the eastern [[Osthwai Mountains]]<ref>Encyclopaedic Glossary II, "Fatwall"</re..."
revision.text:
The [[Scalper]] name for the ruins of the ancient fortress of [[Aenkû Maimor]], located beneath the eastern [[Osthwai Mountains]]Encyclopaedic Glossary II, "Fatwall", destroyed when the [[Meöri Empire]] fell during the [[First Apocalypse]]. During the early years of the [[Holy Bounty]], Fatwall was occupied by a [[Judge]] and a company of [[Ministrate]] Pikeman during the summer months. When the [[New Empire|Empire]] evacuated Fatwall they set fire to the wooden fortifications they originally erected against the ancient stonework.''The White-Luck Warrior'', Chapter 3
== References ==

revision.comment: "He confronts them asking if his father as grasped the Absolute." I changed the as to has.
revision.text:
[[File:Koringhus.jpg|thumb|Koringhus]] {{Character_infobox|name=Anasûrimbor Koringhus|image=|caption1=|titles=|nicknames=The Survivor
Heaper of the Dead|appearances=''[[The Great Ordeal (Book)|The Great Ordeal]]''|lived=? - 4132|race=[[Men]]|ethnicity=[[Dûnyain]] ([[Norsirai]])|nationality=|gender=Male|occupation=[[Dûnyain]] Monk|relatives=[[Anasûrimbor Moënghus|Moënghus]] (grandfather)
[[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Kellhus]] (father)
[[Maithanet]] (uncle)
[[Mimara]] (step-sister)
[[Anasûrimbor Moënghus II|Moënghus II]] (adopted brother)
[[Anasûrimbor Kayûtas|Kayûtas]] (half-brother)
[[Anasûrimbor Theliopa|Theliopa]] (half-sister)
[[Anasûrimbor Serwa|Serwa]] (half-sister)
[[Anasûrimbor Inrilatas|Inrilatas]] (half-brother)
[[Anasûrimbor Kelmomas|Kelmomas]] (half-brother)
[[Anasûrimbor Samarmas|Samarmas]] (half-brother)
[[The Boy]] (son)}} '''Anasûrimbor Koringhus''' was a [[Dûnyain]] Monk and son of [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus]]. He and his [[The Boy|son]] were the only survivors of the [[Consult]] destruction of [[Ishuäl]].
== Appearance == Anasûrimbor Koringhus has the appearance a Dûnyain [[Norsirai]] with light-coloured skin and blond hair, however he is horribly disfigured from years battling the Consult during the final days of Ishuäl. His skin was heavily scarred, burned and damaged. He was missing one cheek, which left a hollow in his face that exposed gums and broken teeth. Despite his horrible disfigurements, [[Drusas Achamian|Achamian]] was still able to see the physical traits of the [[Anasûrimbor Dynasty|Anasûrimbor]] line.''The Great Ordeal'', Chapter 5
== Story == ==== ''What Came Before'' ==== At some point before leaving Ishuäl, Anasûrimbor Kellhus was selected to be a Father. Whether his son was born before he sent away is unknown. Sometime between the events of ''[[The Warrior Prophet|The Warrior-Prophet]]''Assumption based on the Consult's interrogation of the Werigda at the end of The Warrior-Prophet, suggesting they still did not know of Ishuäl at this point. and ''[[The Great Ordeal (Book)|The Great Ordeal]]'', the Consult finally discovered Ishuäl, the home of the Dûnyain. After legions of [[Sranc]] assaulted the fortress from the [[Demua Mountains]] in the east, to no avail, [[Nonmen]] [[Qûya]] approached from [[Injor-Niyas]] to the west and decimated the exterior of the stronghold. The Dûnyain, having been taught that sorcery is a lie, were completely unprepared. Many simply awaited their death while others barricaded themselves in the [[Thousand Thousand Halls]] below. The Dûnyain fought the Consult within the Labyrinth for years, with immense losses on both sides. When the last of the Sranc finally succumbed, Koringhus and the Boy were the only two Dûnyain remaining.
==== ''The Great Ordeal'' ==== Unbeknownst to Achamiam and [[Mimara]], Korinhgus spies them while they are still descending the glaciers towards Ishuäl. When the pair discover the [[The Fathering|Fathering]] in the Upper Galleries of the Thousand Thousand Halls, Koringhus, still unknown to Achamian and Mimara, instructs The Boy to approach them alone before eventually making himself known. He confronts them asking if his father has grasped the [[Absolute]]. Koringhus decides that he must find his father, and that travelling with Achamian and Mimara is the best way to accomplish this task. He and the Boy travel with them as they head north along the Demua Mountains. During their journey, Koringhus eventually asks Mimara to gaze upon him with her [[Judging Eye|sight]]. He then begins to realize that everything the Dûnyain believed was flawed, if not an outright lie. He knows that he is mad and that the madness is getting worse. Mimara eventually offers him [[Qirri]], which pushes his madness to the brink; he decides that the Shortest Path to the [[Absolute]] is by ending his life. He throws himself off a peak in the northern Demua Mountains, where he plummets to his death some thirty cubits below.
== References ==

'''Biaxi Sankas''' is a Patridomos of [[House Biaxi]] during the events of [[The Aspect-Emperor|''The Aspect-Emperor'']], and an important member of the [[New Empire|New Congregate]]. Sankas became a secret lover of the Blessed Empress [[Anasûrimbor Esmenet|Esmenet]] and was assisting her in ruling the tumultuous Empire in her husband's absence. He died in mysterious circumstances, having fallen from the ladder. It is revealed that [[Anasûrimbor Kelmomas|Kelmomas]] was not behind his murder, and even [[Anasûrimbor Theliopa|Thelli]] didn't know the truth. The mystery of Sankas's death was not revealed in the books.
[[Biaxi Tarpellas]] beceme Patridomos after his death. [[Category:Men]] [[Category:Characters from the Three Seas]] [[Category:Characters from Nansur]] [[Category:Characters from the New Empire]]

'''Warrior Hymn''' is a war song of the [[Great Ordeal|Greal Ordeal]]. The Ordealmen sing in during the [[Resumption]], as they greet their victorious [[Anasûrimbor Kellhus|Aspect-Emperor]], unaware of the resurrection of the [[No-God]]. ''By the waters of Siol,''
''we hung our lyres upon the willows,''
''and abandoned song with our mountain.''
''Ere the doom of Trysë,''
''we hoisted our sons upon our knees,''
''and counted scabs upon our hands and heart.''
'' ''In the fields of Cenei,''
''we broke bread that we had stolen,''
''and tasted the love of those who were dead.''
'' ''Beneath the Ark of horrors,''
''we saw the sun rise upon gold as night fell,''
''and mourned the captivity of tomorrow.''

revision.comment: Created page with "The Niom is a ritual wherein the ancient Nonmen Kings demanded hostages of the Men they dealt with as guarantees: a son, a daughter, and a captive enemy. The two former as a s..."
revision.text: The Niom is a ritual wherein the ancient Nonmen Kings demanded hostages of the Men they dealt with as guarantees: a son, a daughter, and a captive enemy. The two former as a surety against treachery. The latter as a surety against deception.
Koringhus the "survivor" meeting Achamian in the Thousand Thousand Halls
"The Last Born"

Hoga Hogrim, Believer-King of Ce Tydonn, took command of the "[[Scalded]]", all those injured or sickened after the cataclysmic Great Ordeal battle against the Horde in [[Urokkas|the Urokkas]]. Many of the Scalded died the first night of seeming radiation sickness.{{6|15}}
